choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): The earliest external change in putrefaction is a greenish discoloration at the right iliac fossa.
Reason (R): This discoloration begins in the right iliac fossa because the cecum contains abundant bacteria that produce hydrogen sulphide, which combines with haemoglobin to form sulfhemoglobin.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Assertion (A):

  • The earliest external change in putrefaction is greenish discoloration at the right iliac fossa. This typically appears at around 18 hours after death during summer and after about 36 hours during winter.

Reason (R):

  • The green color starts in the right iliac fossa, because the cecum is located there and contains abundant bacteria. These bacteria produce hydrogen sulfide (H2S), which reacts with hemoglobin to form sulfhemoglobin, giving the characteristic greenish discoloration.
  • Since the discoloration occurs at that location precisely because of the bacterial activity in the cecum, the reason correctly explains the assertion.
  • The greenish discolouration in RIF forms by about 18 hrs in summer and 36 hrs in winter.

Decomposition is the biological process where organic substances break down into simpler matter, essential for nutrient recycling.

It occurs via two main mechanisms: Autolysis and Putrefaction.

Autolysis

  • Initiation: Begins immediately after death when metabolic processes cease.
  • Mechanism: The body's own enzymes (lysozymes) cause self-digestion (cell lysis), altering tissue appearance and texture.
  • Examples:
    • Clouding of the cornea - first observable external sign of decomposition.
    • Changes in brain glandular tissue - first internal change, where neuronal and glial cells disintegrate.

Putrefaction

  • Driven by bacterial activity, leading to tissue breakdown and gas production.
  • Bacterial Involvement: Primarily caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Main Enzyme: Lecithinase - breaks down the cell
  • Produces H2S (a combustible gas) that combines with haemoglobin to form sulf-methemoglobin, which gives the greenish discolouration of putrefaction.

Key takeaway:

  • The 1st external sign of putrefaction is greenish discolouration in RIF.
  • The 1st internal sign of putrefaction is reddish-brown discolouration in intima of the aorta.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539741/

choices.text: Increased glucosuria creating a favorable environment for fungal overgrowth
Blockade of sodium channels leading to electrolyte imbalance
Increased insulin sensitivity leading to hypoglycemia
Inhibition of α-glucosidase in intestines causing malabsorption

questions.text:
A 62-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic heart failure was prescribed empagliflozin as an additional medication to improve both glycemic control and heart failure outcomes. After 1 month, she reports recurrent dysuria and genital itching. On exam, there is erythema and pruritus in the perineal area. Her physician explains this is a known adverse effect of the drug.
Which of the following mechanisms best explains her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SGLT2 inhibitors like Empagliflozin increase urinary glucose excretion, which provides a nutrient-rich medium that predisposes patients to genital fungal infections and urinary tract infections.

Mechanism of SGLT2 Inhibitors:

  • SGLT2 inhibitors block the sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 in the proximal renal tubule → Prevent reabsorption of glucose → Increased glucose excretion in urine (glucosuria).
  • This leads to an osmotic diuresis effect → Benefits patients with heart failure.

Side Effects Related to Glucosuria:

  • High glucose concentration in urine favors fungal (e.g., Candida) and bacterial growth → Vulvovaginal candidiasis, balanitis, and recurrent urinary tract infections (UTIs).
  • Other serious but rare side effects include Fournier gangrene and euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis (euDKA).

Drug Class

  • Sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) Inhibitors

Examples

  • Canagliflozin
  • Dapagliflozin
  • Empagliflozin

Mechanism of Action

  • Blocks reabsorption of glucose in the proximal convoluted tubule, promoting the excretion of glucose and sodium in urine

Indications

  • Reduce progression of chronic kidney disease (CKD)
  • Diuretic effect, leading to sodium loss
  • Reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) by 3-6 mmHg
  • Cardiorenal advantage
  • Heart failure to decrease hospitalizations and CV death (with or without DM)

Side Effects

  • Increased risk of urinary tract infections (UTIs)
  • Glucosuria (leading to UTIs and vulvovaginal candidiasis)
  • Dehydration (orthostatic hypotension)
  • Weight loss

Contraindications

  • Relative contraindication - pregnancy (especially 2nd and 3rd trimesters), Type 1 Diabetes; for glycemic control, avoid initiating when eGFR < 30 mL/min/1.73 m²
  • Absolute contraindication - dialysis (and prior serious hypersensitivity to the drug)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Blockade of sodium channels (Option B):

This is a mechanism related to class I antiarrhythmics (e.g., flecainide), not SGLT2 inhibitors. Empagliflozin does not block sodium channels directly.

Increased insulin sensitivity leading to hypoglycemia (Option C):

SGLT2 inhibitors reduce blood glucose by increasing urinary excretion, not by increasing insulin action. Hypoglycemia is uncommon unless combined with insulin or sulfonylureas.

Inhibition of alpha-glucosidase in intestines (Option D):

Voglibose works by inhibiting alpha-glucosidase enzymes to delay carbohydrate absorption (causing flatulence and malabsorption syndromes) and is not related to SGLT2 inhibitors or increased glucosuria.

choices.text: Pneumonia - oral amoxicillin for 5 days, review after 48 hours
Severe pneumonia - first dose of IV ampicillin + gentamicin, oxygen, and referral/admission
Very severe disease - ICU admission with IV antibiotics and ventilatory support

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought with cough and fever for 4 days. Respiratory rate is 42/min. On examination, there is chest indrawing but no stridor at rest. SpO₂ is 88% on room air. The child is lethargic and refuses feeds. According to IMNCI classification, what is the most appropriate diagnosis and next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to IMNCI guidelines, pneumonia in children under five years is classified based on fast breathing, chest indrawing, and danger signs.

  • This child has tachypnea (RR ≥40/min for 1-5 years) and chest indrawing, but most importantly also shows danger signs: SpO² <90%, lethargy, and refusal to feed.
  • Any danger sign automatically classifies the child as severe pneumonia (pink category).
  • Management = first dose of IV ampicillin + gentamicin, start oxygen, and refer/admit to hospital.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Pneumonia - oral amoxicillin for 5 days, review after 48 hours (option A): This is for children with tachypnea/chest indrawing but no danger signs. Here, danger signs are present.

No pneumonia - symptomatic treatment only (option C): This applies only when there is no tachypnea, no chest indrawing, and no danger signs (just cough/cold). Not applicable here.

Very severe disease - ICU admission with IV antibiotics and ventilatory support (option D): IMNCI does not separate "very severe" from severe pneumonia. Danger signs, low SpO², and chest indrawing all classify as severe pneumonia requiring hospital care, not immediate ICU.

Key Takeaway

In IMNCI, pneumonia classification is clinical: fast breathing and chest indrawing = pneumonia; presence of any danger sign (SpO² <90%, lethargy, inability to feed, seizures, stridor at rest) = severe pneumonia. Management requires oxygen, IV antibiotics, and referral/admission.

questions.text: Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) binding to CD14 on monocytes, followed by activation of Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4), plays a central role in the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • LPS (endotoxin) from Gram-negative bacteria → binds to LPS-binding protein.
  • Complex interacts with CD14 on monocytes/macrophages.
  • Activates Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4).
  • Triggers NF-κB signaling pathway.
  • Releases large amounts of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-1, IL-6).
  • Causes vasodilation, capillary leak, hypotension, DIC.
  • Leads to Septic Shock.

questions.text: A family shows intellectual disability across multiple generations, predominantly affecting males. The severity worsens with each generation, and about 20% of affected males remain asymptomatic. Which genetic mechanism best explains this pattern?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The clinical vignette describes a disorder with:
    • X-linked inheritance (predominantly males affected).
    • Anticipation (increasing severity in successive generations).
    • Incomplete penetrance (~20% of affected males asymptomatic).
  • Trinucleotide repeat mutation is a dynamic mutation.
  • This is characteristic of Fragile X syndrome, the prototype of a trinucleotide repeat disorder involving non-coding DNA. The patient with Fragile X-syndrome has mental retardation (2nd most common cause) and macroorchidism.
  • Trinucleotide repeats in coding-regions:
    • Huntington's disease (CAG)
  • Trinucleotide repeats can occur in non-coding regions of DNA:
    • 5′ untranslated region (UTR):g., Fragile X syndrome (CGG repeat in FMR1 gene).
    • Introns:g., Friedreich ataxia (GAA repeat).
    • 3′ untranslated region (UTR):g., Myotonic dystrophy (CTG repeat).

Fragile X Syndrome:

  • Gene involved: FMR1 gene on X chromosome.
  • Mutation: Expansion of CGG repeats (>200) in the 5′ UTR (non-coding region).
  • Molecular mechanism:
    • Repeat expansion → abnormal methylation → gene silencing.
    • ↓ FMRP protein → defective synaptic neuronal function.
  • Inheritance: Expansion occurs during oogenesis → explains anticipation.
  • Clinical features:
    • Intellectual disability (IQ 20-60).
    • Long face, large ears, hyperextensible joints.
    • Macro-orchidism (most characteristic).
    • Behavioral changes (autistic features, ADHD).
  • Other associated conditions:
    • Fragile X-associated tremor/ataxia syndrome (FXTAS): Due to toxic RNA gain of function in premutation carriers.
  • Diagnosis: PCR (amplicon length analysis) or Southern blot.

Explanation of Other Options:

Frameshift Mutation (Option A):

  • Occurs when 1-2 nucleotides are inserted or deleted (not in multiples of 3). Alters the reading frame → produces a completely abnormal protein downstream, often truncated and non-functional.
  • Example: Inserting "A" into the cat ate the rat → the aca tat eth era t → whole message disrupted.
  • Seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, Tay-Sachs disease.
  • Not associated with anticipation or Fragile X features.

Missense Mutation (Option B):

  • A single nucleotide change leads to the substitution of one amino acid for another. Classic example: Sickle cell anemia,
    • On the β-globin gene, at position B7 (previously B6), codon changes from GAG (glutamic acid) → GTG (valine) due to an A → T substitution.
    • Alters hemoglobin solubility → RBCs sickle under hypoxia.
  • Produces a structurally altered but still full-length protein.
  • Does not cause anticipation or X-linked male predominance.

Mitochondrial DNA Mutation (Option C):

  • Inherited maternally (all mitochondria from the oocyte). Key concepts include:
    • Heteroplasmy: coexistence of normal and mutant mitochondria.
    • Threshold effect: disease manifests when mutant load exceeds a critical proportion.
  • Mitochondria contain 37 genes, of which 13 encode oxidative phosphorylation enzymes. Typically affect CNS, eyes, and muscles.
    • Examples:
      • MELAS (Mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, stroke-like episodes).
      • MERRF (Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged-red fibers, highlighted with Gomori trichrome stain).
      • NARP (Neuropathy, Ataxia, Retinitis Pigmentosa).

Both sexes are equally affected; not only male predominance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain, psychiatric disturbances, and dark-colored urine. On examination, there are no cutaneous lesions. Which porphyria best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute intermittent porphyria (AIP) (heme metabolism defect) is due to a deficiency of porphobilinogen deaminase.
  • It presents with acute neurovisceral crises without cutaneous manifestations.
  • The hallmark features are remembered by the 5 P's: Painful abdomen, Polyneuropathy, Psychological disturbances, Port-wine urine, and Precipitation by drugs.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Porphyria cutanea tarda (Option B): Due to uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase deficiency, it presents with chronic blistering photosensitivity and tea-colored urine, commonly triggered by alcohol and hepatitis C. It lacks neurovisceral crises.

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria (Option C): Due to uroporphyrinogen III synthase deficiency, an autosomal recessive disorder presenting in childhood with severe cutaneous photosensitivity, hemolytic anemia, and erythrodontia (red-brown teeth).

Variegate porphyria (Option D): Due to protoporphyrinogen oxidase deficiency, inherited in an autosomal dominant manner, presenting with a mix of neurovisceral crises and cutaneous photosensitivity.

Key Takeaway

  • Differential diagnosis for dark urine:
    • Dark urine + joint pain = Alkaptonuria
    • Dark urine + muscle pain = Mc Ardle disease
    • Dark urine + Abdominal pain = Acute intermittent porphyria

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with advanced dementia is rushed to the hospital with a perforated peptic ulcer requiring urgent surgery. She is unable to comprehend or communicate the nature of the procedure. The medical team fully explains the risks, benefits, and alternatives to her adult son, who then provides authorization for the surgery on her behalf. What is the most appropriate type of consent in this situation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Substituted Consent refers to the process where a surrogate decision-maker (like a family member or legal guardian) gives consent for medical treatment on behalf of a patient who lacks decision-making capacity, such as someone with advanced dementia. The surrogate is expected to make decisions based on what the patient would have wanted, using prior statements, values, or known wishes (this is often called substituted judgment).

In this scenario, the 70-year-old woman cannot understand or make medical decisions due to advanced dementia, so her adult son appropriately provides consent on her behalf. Since the consent is given with the patient's presumed wishes in mind, it is classified as substituted consent.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Waiver of Consent (Option A):

  • Incorrect, because this refers to situations where a competent patient chooses not to receive information and allows the physician to decide on their behalf.
  • In this case, the patient lacks capacity, so she cannot waive consent.

Proxy Consent (Option B):

  • Incorrect, though close. Proxy consent is often used in paediatrics or for those under legal guardianship.
  • While similar, proxy consent does not necessarily consider what the patient would have wanted, whereas substituted consent explicitly involves making decisions in line with the patient's known values.

Therapeutic Privilege (Option D)

  • Incorrect, because this applies when a physician withholds information from a competent patient if disclosure would cause harm.
  • Here, the issue is not about withholding information, but about who can consent when the patient is incompetent.

Key Takeaways:

  • Substituted Consent = Surrogate gives consent based on what the patient would have wanted.
  • Proxy Consent = Consent given on behalf but not necessarily considering the patient's preferences.
  • Waiver of Consent = Patient gives up right to be informed.
  • Therapeutic Privilege = Doctor withholds info to avoid harm.

questions.text: A 58-year-old obese postmenopausal woman presents with vaginal bleeding for the last 2 months. She reports a past history of irregular cycles during her reproductive years suggestive of chronic anovulation. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Postmenopausal bleeding is always abnormal and warrants evaluation for endometrial pathology (especially carcinoma or hyperplasia).
  • This patient is obese, postmenopausal, and has a history of chronic anovulation → all are risk factors for endometrial carcinoma due to prolonged unopposed estrogen.
  • Role of Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVS):
    • First-line, non-invasive, and widely available.
    • Measures endometrial thickness- a key triage tool.
  • A cutoff of >4-5 mm in a postmenopausal woman warrants further histological evaluation (e.g., biopsy) due to the increased risk of endometrial pathology, including endometrial cancer.
  • The endometrial biopsy report says endometrial hyperplasia with atypia then there is 8-30 % risk for malignancy and the next step would be fractional curettage and hysteroscopy.
  • Causes for postmenopausal bleeding are:
    • Polyps (Most common)
    • Endometrial atrophy
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Endometrial carcinoma (10 %)
    • Cancer cervix

Explanation of other options:

  • Pap smear (Option A): Screens for cervical, not endometrial, cancer.
  • Fractional curettage (Option B): It is indicated when:
    • Endometrial biopsy report says : Endometrial hypertrophy with atypia or insufficient sample
    • Incase of cervical stenosis
    • Endometrial hypertrophy with atypia and failure of medical management
  • Hysteroscopy with biopsy (Option C): The gold standard for diagnosis but is typically performed after an abnormal TVS.

Key Takeaways:

  • First-line test for PMB: TVS to measure endometrial thickness.
  • Cutoff for biopsy: >4-5 mm.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with high-grade fever, periorbital edema, and painful ophthalmoplegia. MRI confirms the diagnosis of cavernous sinus thrombosis. On neurological examination, which cranial nerve function is most likely to remain intact?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cavernous sinus contains several cranial nerves closely related to its walls and lumen.
  • Within the lateral wall: CN III (oculomotor), CN IV (trochlear), CN V1 (ophthalmic division of trigeminal), and CN V2 (maxillary division).
  • Within the lumen adjacent to the internal carotid artery: CN VI (abducens).
  • In cavernous sinus thrombosis, ophthalmoplegia is produced due to involvement of CN III, IV, and VI.
  • Sensory loss in the ophthalmic division (V1) is common.
  • However, V2 (maxillary division) usually lies more inferiorly and is least commonly affected in early stages, so it is relatively spared.

Cavernous Sinus

  • Location & Structure:
    • Two venous plexuses on either side of the sphenoid body.
    • Extend from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.
    • Average dimensions: 2 cm length × 1 cm width.
  • Contents:
    • Cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery (ICA) with perivascular sympathetic plexus.
    • ICA segments: short ascending, posterior genu, horizontal, anterior genu → continues as paraclinoid ICA.
    • ICA branches: meningohypophysial trunk (posterior genu) and inferolateral trunk (distal to meningohypophysial trunk).
  • Cranial Nerves in Sinus:
    • Lateral wall: Oculomotor (CN III), Trochlear (CN IV), Ophthalmic division of trigeminal (V1). (Option B, C)
    • Inferolateral position near ICA: Abducens nerve (CN VI) runs medial to CN V1 after exiting Dorello's canal, within the sinus near the ICA. (Option A)
    • Maxillary division (V2): Does not pass through the sinus; runs below the dura of the middle cranial fossa.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Venous connections predispose to cavernous sinus thrombosis.
    • Close relation to cranial nerves explains ophthalmoplegia and sensory deficits in lateral wall lesions.

Key Takeaway:

  • Maxillary nerve (V2) does not pass through the cavernous sinus, so it is typically unaffected in cavernous sinus thrombosis.

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida at 18 weeks gestation presents with acute, severe lower abdominal pain associated with low-grade fever and mild tachycardia. On abdominal examination, a firm, irregular mass is palpable corresponding to the gravid uterus, and the patient reports a prior diagnosis of uterine fibroids. Which of the following pathological changes in fibroids is the most likely cause of her current presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Red degeneration is a specific complication of uterine fibroids in pregnancy, most commonly occurring in the second trimester.
  • The rapid growth of the fibroid causes it to outstrip its blood supply, leading to hemorrhagic infarction, thrombosis of the supplying vessels, aseptic necrosis, and peritoneal irritation.
  • This leads to the classic symptoms of acute abdominal pain, tenderness over the fibroid, and sometimes low-grade fever and leukocytosis, mimicking an acute abdomen.
  • The condition is managed conservativley with analgesics, antiemetics and IV fluids.

Explanation of other options:

  • Hyaline degeneration (Option A): The most common type of degeneration is usually asymptomatic and results in the loss of the whorled appearance, making the fibroid appear homogenous.
  • Calcific degeneration (Option B) : This form of degeneration, most frequently observed in subserosal fibroids of postmenopausal women, is typically asymptomatic. Its classic radiographic feature is a distinctive "popcorn calcification" pattern, often termed a "womb stone."
  • Sarcomatous degeneration (Option D) : This least common type of degeneration occurs in intramural fibroids and is typically seen in peri- or postmenopausal women. It presents with a sudden, painful increase in the size of the fibroid.

Key Takeaways:

  • Red degeneration presents with acute pain in pregnancy (2nd trimester).
  • It is caused by hemorrhagic infarction of the fibroid.

choices.text: Right shift with hyperthermia and left shift with CO poisoning
Left shift with hyperthermia and right shift with CO poisoning

questions.text: How does the oxyhemoglobin dissociation curve shift in hyperthermia compared with carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyperthermia stabilizes T-state → right shift → ↑P₅₀ .
  • Carbon monoxide (CO) locks Hb in R-state for remaining sites → left shift → ↓P₅₀ (and ↓O₂ content).

questions.text: The following kinetics are seen in which type of enzyme inhibition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In uncompetitive inhibition, the inhibitor binds only to the enzyme-substrate complex, not to the free enzyme.
  • This binding prevents product release. Both Km and Vmax decrease, but the ratio Km/Vmax (the slope in Lineweaver-Burk plot) remains unchanged.
  • This explains the parallel lines seen in the graph.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Competitive inhibition (Option A): Inhibitor binds at the active site. Increases Km (lower affinity) but Vmax remains unchanged. Lineweaver-Burk plot shows lines intersecting at the y-axis.

Non-competitive inhibition (Option B): Inhibitor binds at an allosteric site, whether or not substrate is bound. Vmax decreases but Km remains the same. Lines intersect at the x-axis.

Irreversible inhibition (Option D): Inhibitor covalently binds to or permanently inactivates the enzyme. Cannot be overcome by increasing substrate. Includes group-specific inhibitors (DIPF for chymotrypsin, acetylcholinesterase) and suicide inhibitors, where the enzyme activates its own inhibitor (eg, allopurinol for xanthine oxidase, aspirin for COX, penicillin for transpeptidase, 5-fluorouracil for thymidylate synthase).

Key Takeaway:

Uncompetitive inhibition decreases both Km and Vmax, producing parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. Competitive (↑Km, Vmax same), non-competitive (Km same, ↓Vmax), and irreversible inhibitors (permanent loss of activity) are distinguished by their characteristic effects.

questions.text: A 3-day-old male develops poor feeding, vomiting, irritability, and tachypnoea. ABG shows respiratory alkalosis. Plasma ammonia is markedly elevated. Urine GC-MS reports marked increase in a pyrimidine pathway intermediate. Which enzyme defect best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ammonia accumulates and fails to get converted into urea if there is any disorder affecting the urea cycle.
Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency is the most common urea cycle disorder and is X-linked. Ammonia accumulates due to failure of carbamoyl phosphate to enter the cycle. Excess carbamoyl phosphate diverts into pyrimidine synthesis, leading to orotic aciduria. The presence of both hyperammonemia and orotic acid elevation distinguishes OTC deficiency from pyrimidine pathway defects such as UMP synthase deficiency.

Pathophysiology and Clinical Correlations

  • Hyperammonemia type I (CPS-I deficiency): Hyperammonemia without orotic aciduria.
  • Hyperammonemia type II (OTC deficiency): Hyperammonemia with orotic aciduria and sometimes elevated uracil in urine.
  • Citrullinemia: Deficiency of argininosuccinate synthetase → ↑ plasma citrulline.
  • Argininosuccinic aciduria: Deficiency of argininosuccinate lyase → ↑ argininosuccinate; causes brittle hair (trichorrhexis nodosa).
  • HHH syndrome (ornithine transporter defect, SLC25A15): hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, homocitrullinuria, developmental delay/spasticity; not classically associated with gyrate atrophy.
  • Orotic aciduria due to UMP synthase deficiency: ↑ orotic acid but normal ammonia; presents with megaloblastic anemia unresponsive to B12/folate.
  • General clue: ↑ NH₃, ↓ urea = urea cycle defect.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Carbamoyl phosphate synthetase I deficiency (Option B): Causes severe neonatal hyperammonemia but no orotic aciduria, since carbamoyl phosphate is not formed.

UMP synthase deficiency (Option C): Leads to hereditary orotic aciduria with macrocytic anemia and growth retardation, but normal ammonia levels.

Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency (Option D): Causes hyperammonemia and urinary argininosuccinate, often associated with abnormal brittle hair, not orotic aciduria.

Key Takeaway

OTC deficiency is the only X-linked urea cycle defect and presents with hyperammonemia, respiratory alkalosis, and elevated orotic acid. A useful distinction is that orotic aciduria with hyperammonemia - OTC defect, while orotic aciduria with macrocytic anemia but normal ammonia = UMP synthase defect.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female with a recent history of rapid weight loss presents with recurrent episodes of postprandial epigastric pain, nausea, vomiting, and further weight loss. Contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen shows a grossly dilated stomach and proximal duodenum with abrupt narrowing at the third part of the duodenum.
Which anatomical structure's abnormal positioning is most likely associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical and radiological picture is consistent with Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) syndrome.
  • In this condition, the third part of the duodenum is compressed between the SMA and the aorta, especially after rapid weight loss due to loss of mesenteric fat.
  • The ligament of Treitz (suspensory muscle of the duodenum) plays a role in maintaining the duodenojejunal flexure at its normal position.
  • Abnormal shortening, thickening, or altered orientation of this ligament predisposes to duodenal compression in SMA syndrome.

Ligament of Treitz (Suspensory Muscle of Duodenum)

  • Formed by muscular bands arising from the left crus of the diaphragm.
  • Connects to the duodenojejunal (DJ) flexure.
  • Usually located to the left of the L1-L2 vertebral body after normal gut rotation.
  • Appears as a thin, triangular, double fold of peritoneum.
  • Lies posterior to the pancreas and anterior to the left renal vein.
  • Inferior mesenteric artery lies adjacent, marking the transition from duodenum to jejunum (retroperitoneal → peritoneal).
  • Embryological & Functional Role:
    • Holds the duodenum in place during gut rotation around the superior mesenteric artery (SMA).
    • Important landmark for the foregut-midgut junction.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Malrotation of gut → abnormal position of the ligament of Treitz.
    • Abnormal elongation → may cause intestinal malrotation.
    • Abnormal thickening/shortening/hypertrophy → can cause superior mesenteric artery syndrome (SMAS).
    • Landmark for distinguishing upper vs. lower GI bleeding sources in clinical practice.
    • Pathological changes may affect surrounding structures (pancreas, renal vein, SMA).

Explanation of other options:

Falciform ligament (Option B): Connects the anterior abdominal wall to the liver; not related to duodenal compression or SMA syndrome.

Ligamentum teres (Option C): Obliterated fetal umbilical vein; no role in duodenal obstruction.

Ligamentum venosum (Option D): Remnant of ductus venosus; anatomically unrelated to the duodenum or SMA.

Key Takeaway:

  • Superior Mesenteric Artery (SMA) syndrome occurs when the third part of the duodenum is compressed between the SMA and aorta, often due to a short or thickened ligament of Treitz.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ajronline.org/doi/10.2214/AJR.20.23273

choices.text: Immediate right salpingo-oophorectomy to prevent thromboembolism
Detorsion of the right ovary alone without further intervention
Detorsion of the right ovary followed by right ovarian cystectomy
Bilateral ovarian cystectomy after detorsion to rule out occult contralateral pathology

questions.text:
A 19-year-old woman presents with sudden onset right iliac fossa pain and repeated vomiting for 6 hours. On examination, she is afebrile, pulse 104/min, BP 110/70 mmHg, and mild right adnexal tenderness is noted. Ultrasound with Doppler reveals an enlarged right ovary with peripheral follicles and reduced but not absent flow. Emergency laparoscopy shows an enlarged, edematous right ovary with a dusky blue-black surface. The ovary appears congested but there is no frank necrosis or rupture. A 6 cm mature cystic teratoma (dermoid cyst) is identified within the ovary.
What is the most appropriate surgical management in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cornerstone of management is to preserve the ovary if viable. Even a seemingly non-viable (dusky) ovary should be detorsed as its appearance often improves post-detorsion, and function can recover.
  • Laparoscopic detorsion is therefore performed first. To prevent recurrence, the underlying cause must be addressed.
  • As a dermoid cyst (a common risk factor for torsion) is present, cystectomy is indicated. Salpingo-oophorectomy is only for frankly necrotic tissue or postmenopausal women.

Explanation of other options:

Immediate right salpingo-oophorectomy to prevent thromboembolism (Option A): Incorrect. Oophorectomy is reserved for a non-viable necrotic ovary. The old belief that detorsion causes thromboembolism has been disproven. Preserving ovarian function is preferred in this patient.

Detorsion of the right ovary alone without further intervention (Option B): Incorrect. While detorsion restores blood flow, leaving the dermoid cyst untreated risks recurrence of torsion. Definitive treatment requires cystectomy.

Bilateral ovarian cystectomy after detorsion (Option D): Incorrect. Management should be limited to the affected ovary. Routine bilateral cystectomy is not indicated unless cysts are present in both ovaries.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules shares the greatest structural similarity with insulin-like growth factors IGF-1 and IGF-2?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Insulin-like growth factors (IGFs) - specifically IGF-1 and IGF-2 - are peptides that regulate cell growth and development. Structurally, they closely resemble proinsulin, the precursor of insulin.

Structure Comparison:

  • Proinsulin is a single-chain polypeptide composed of:
    • A-chain
    • B-chain
    • C-peptide (C-chain) - which connects A and B chains before insulin becomes active
  • IGF-1 and IGF-2 are also single-chain polypeptides that retain a connecting (C) region, much like proinsulin.
  • Additionally, IGFs have a unique D-domain attached to the A-chain, which is not present in insulin but contributes to their similarity with proinsulin.
  • IGF-1 consists of 70 amino acids and IGF-2 contains 67 amino acids, both stabilized by three disulfide bonds - similar to proinsulin.

Explanation of other option:

Insulin (Option A):

  • Insulin is the final active form of proinsulin after the C-peptide is cleaved off.
  • It consists of two chains (A and B) connected by disulfide bonds, lacking the connecting C-peptide.
  • Because IGFs maintain a continuous, single-chain structure (like proinsulin), insulin is less similar in structure.

Preproinsulin (Option B):

  • Preproinsulin is an even earlier precursor of insulin and includes:
    • A signal peptide (pre-segment)
    • The B-chain
    • The C-peptide
    • The A-chain
  • While it contains all the parts, the signal peptide makes it functionally and structurally different from IGFs, which do not have a signal peptide.

C-peptide (Option C)

  • The C-peptide is just a connecting segment between the A and B chains in proinsulin.
  • On its own, it lacks the complete polypeptide structure of proinsulin or IGFs.
  • It is only a part of the structure and cannot resemble IGF-1 or IGF-2 on its own.

Key Takeaway:

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents with developmental delay, seizures, and a musty body Odor. Despite dietary phenylalanine restriction, neurological deterioration continues. Further testing reveals low levels of dopamine and serotonin in the cerebrospinal fluid. Which of the following is the most likely underlying defect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

BH4 deficiency, also known as malignant PKU, impairs not only the conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine but also the synthesis of dopamine and serotonin, since BH4 is a cofactor for both tyrosine hydroxylase and tryptophan hydroxylase. Thus, patients develop progressive neurologic symptoms even with dietary phenylalanine restriction. Therapy requires sapropterin (BH4 supplementation) and neurotransmitter precursors in addition to dietary control.

  • Phenylalanine is converted into tyrosine by the enzymes phenylalanine hydroxylase and BH2 reductase.
  • BH2 reductase is also necessary for the conversion of tyrosine into dopamine and tryptophan into serotonin.
  • Here the clinical scenario of phenylketonuria, low levels of dopamine and serotonin all point to BH2 reductase deficiency.
  • BH2 reductase also converts BH2 into BH4, and hence, its deficiency will lead to BH4 deficiency.

Pathophysiology and Clinical Correlations

  • Classic PKU (phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency): Musty odor, eczema, seizures, responds to phenylalanine restriction.
  • BH4 deficiency (malignant PKU): Same early signs as PKU but additionally ↓ dopamine and serotonin → refractory neurologic symptoms. Requires sapropterin therapy.
  • Maternal PKU: Uncontrolled PKU in pregnancy → teratogenic effects (microcephaly, growth restriction, congenital heart disease).
  • Newborn screening: Guthrie bacterial inhibition assay is the classic screening test for hyperphenylalaninemia.
  • Other metabolic confusion: UMP synthase deficiency presents with orotic aciduria and macrocytic anemia, not hyperphenylalaninemia.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency (Option A): Causes classic PKU, with musty odor, eczema, seizures, and responds well to phenylalanine restriction. Does not cause neurotransmitter deficiency.

Maternal phenylketonuria (Option C): Results in fetal teratogenic effects such as microcephaly and congenital heart disease, but the infant's neurologic decline in this case is not explained by maternal exposure.

UMP synthase deficiency (Option D): A pyrimidine synthesis defect causing megaloblastic anemia and orotic aciduria with normal ammonia; unrelated to hyperphenylalaninemia.

Key Takeaway

Classic PKU is due to phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency and improves with dietary restriction, while BH4 deficiency (malignant PKU) causes persistent neurologic decline due to impaired dopamine and serotonin synthesis, requiring sapropterin and neurotransmitter replacement.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found dead with a transverse ligature mark below the thyroid cartilage, congested face, petechiae in the eyes, tongue protrusion, and evidence of involuntary discharge of faeces and urine. The subcutaneous tissue under the ligature mark shows ecchymosis. What is the most likely cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The key features such as a transverse ligature mark below the thyroid cartilage, congested face with petechiae, tongue protrusion, ecchymosed subcutaneous tissue under the ligature mark strongly suggest ligature strangulation.

Ligature Strangulation Characteristics:

  • Ligature Mark:
    • Horizontal, continuous, at or below the thyroid cartilage
    • Soft, reddish base
  • Face:
    • Congested, livid with petechiae
    • Marked tongue swelling and protrusion
    • Bleeding from nose, ears, mouth
  • Involuntary Discharge:
    • Feces and urine common
    • Seminal discharge less common
  • Subcutaneous Tissue:
    • Severe ecchymosis under the ligature mark, engorgement of neck tissues
  • Internal Findings:
    • Thyroid cartilage may be fractured
    • Hyoid fracture uncommon
  • Lungs:
    • Emphysematous bullae commonly present
  • Carotid Arteries:
    • Damage rare
  • History & Signs of Struggle:
    • Usually absent previous suicide attempts
    • Signs of struggle commonly present




Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Hanging (Option A):

  • Oblique ligature mark, typically above thyroid cartilage, and less petechiae or tongue protrusion; no transverse continuous ligature mark below thyroid.

Throttling (Manual Strangulation) (Option C):

  • Irregular marks or fingerprints without a well-defined ligature mark; inconsistent with the smooth transverse ligature mark observed.

Drowning (Option D):

  • Characterized by frothy mouth discharge, water in lungs, washerwoman's hands, but no ligature marks or petechiae.

choices.text: Both A and R are true and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.
A is true but R is false.
A is false but R is true.

questions.text:
The question below consists of two statements: an Assertion (A) and a Reason (R).
Assertion (A): The herd immunity threshold for measles is approximately 95%, which is higher than that for polio.
Reason (R): The herd immunity threshold for a disease is inversely proportional to its basic reproduction number (R0); measles has a higher R0 than polio.
Examine both statements carefully and select the correct answer using the options given below:
questions.solution:
Evaluation :

"The herd immunity threshold for measles is approximately 95%, which is higher than that for polio."

  • This assertion is TRUE.
  • Measles is one of the most contagious diseases known, with a very high basic reproduction number (R0 estimated between 12-18). This leads to a very high herd immunity threshold, universally accepted to be 90-95%.
  • Polio (caused by wild poliovirus) is less contagious, with a lower R0 (estimated between 5-7). Consequently, its herd immunity threshold is lower, generally estimated to be around 80-86%.
  • Therefore, it is correct to state that the threshold for measles (~95%) is higher than that for polio (~80-85%).

Evaluation of the Reason (R):

"The herd immunity threshold for a disease is inversely proportional to its basic reproduction number (R0); measles has a higher R0 than polio."

  • This reason is FALSE.
  • The formula for calculating the herd immunity threshold (HIT) is:
    HIT = 1 - (1 / R0)
  • This formula shows that the herd immunity threshold is directly proportional to the basic reproduction number (R0). As R0 increases, the HIT also increases.
    • Example: If R0 = 2, HIT = 1 - (1/2) = 0.5 or 50%.
    • If R0 = 10, HIT = 1 - (1/10) = 0.9 or 90%.
  • The reason correctly states that "measles has a higher R0 than polio," which is true. However, it incorrectly states the relationship is inverse when it is, in fact, direct.

Conclusion:

  • Assertion (A) is True.
  • Reason (R) is False because it misstates the fundamental mathematical relationship between R0 and the herd immunity threshold.

Therefore, the correct option is (C) A is true but R is false.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with gingival bleeding, easy bruising, and fatigue for 2 weeks. Laboratory investigations reveal pancytopenia, prolonged PT and aPTT, and elevated D-dimer levels. Peripheral smear shows the following finding. Which of the following cytogenetic abnormalities is most characteristic of this condition and is central to its pathogenesis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of gingival bleeding, easy bruising, along with elevated PT, aPTT, and D-dimer levels and Auer rods on peripheral smear is suggestive of disseminated intravascular coagulation associated with APML, which is characterised by t(15;17).

Acute myeloid leukaemia is a malignancy of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that block differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the bone marrow.

  • Replacement of marrow with blasts causes failure of normal hematopoiesis, resulting in anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

Morphology

Diagnosis requires ≥20% blasts in the bone marrow.

  • Blasts: delicate chromatin, 2-4 nucleoli, and larger cytoplasm than lymphoblasts.
  • Auer rods (needle-like azurophilic granules) may be seen, especially numerous in APML with t(15;17).
  • Some AMLs show megakaryocytic differentiation with marrow fibrosis.

Cytogenetics

  • Balanced translocations like t(8;21), inv(16), and t(15;17) are frequent in de novo AML of younger adults.
  • t(8;21), inv(16)) that disrupt normal myeloid differentiation.
  • t(15;17), produces a fusion of the RARα gene with PML, blocking promyelocyte maturation. This specific subtype is strongly associated with coagulopathy (DIC). (Options A and D ruled out)
  • MDS-related or therapy-related AMLs often have deletions/monosomies involving chromosomes 5 and 7, with poor prognosis.

Clinical Features

  • Due to marrow failure: fatigue, anemia, infections (from neutropenia), and bleeding (from thrombocytopenia).
  • APML: Marked bleeding tendency from release of procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors, leading to DIC.
  • Leukemia cutis and gingival infiltration may occur with monocytic differentiation.
  • Sometimes presents as extramedullary mass (chloroma).

Prognosis

  • Best outcomes are seen in APML with t(15;17), curable in >90% of patients with ATRA and arsenic.
  • AML with t(8;21) or inv(16) also has favorable prognosis.
  • Older age, TP53 mutations, or AML following MDS/therapy have poor prognosis.

Explanation of other options:

t(9;22) (Option C): The Philadelphia chromosome, resulting from a t(9;22) translocation that fuses the BCR and ABL genes, is the characteristic genetic abnormality of chronic myeloid leukemia (CML).

questions.text: A patient walks with a specific gait as shown in the photograph below. Match the clinical finding, gait pattern, and nerve/muscle involvement in Trendelenburg gait
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Paralysis of the gluteus medius due to superior gluteal nerve injury leads to a positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the unsupported side during single-leg stance.

  • The superior gluteal nerve originates from the dorsal branches of the L4, L5, and S1 ventral rami. It leaves the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and divides into superior and inferior branches.
  • The superior branch accompanies the upper division of the deep branch of the superior gluteal artery and supplies the gluteus medius and occasionally the gluteus minimus.
  • The inferior branch runs with the lower division of the same artery, crosses the gluteus minimus, and supplies the gluteus medius, gluteus minimus, and tensor fasciae latae.
  • Injury to the superior gluteal nerve leads to paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus, muscles that play a crucial role in pelvic stabilization during single-leg stance. The resulting deficit produces a positive Trendelenburg sign, where the pelvis drops on the unsupported side when the patient stands on the affected limb.
  • This produces the Trendelenburg gait, characterized by tilting or dropping of the pelvis:
  • In the compensated type, the patient leans the trunk toward the affected side to shorten the body weight lever arm and maintain balance.
  • In the uncompensated type, the pelvis drops uncontrollably away from the affected side.

questions.text: Match the drugs used in the management of Parkinson's disease in Column A with the most appropriate clinical use in column B
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A correctly matches the drugs given in column A with the most appropriate clinical use given in column B.

  • Parkinson's disease is the second most common age-related neurodegenerative disorder, surpassed only by Alzheimer's disease.
  • The key pathological hallmark of PD is the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), leading to striatal dopamine depletion.
  • Affected neurons exhibit intracellular protein inclusions of α-synuclein, collectively termed Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites (Lewy pathology).

The various drugs used in the management of Parkinson's disease are given below.

  1. Levodopa
    • Mainstay and most effective therapy for symptomatic treatment of Parkinson's disease.
    • Routinely combined with a peripheral decarboxylase inhibitor such as carbidopa or benserazide to prevent peripheral conversion.
    • Limitations: long-term use leads to motor complications like wearing-off, on-off fluctuations, and dyskinesias.
  2. Dopamine Agonists (pramipexole, ropinirole, rotigotine, apomorphine)
    • Directly stimulate dopamine receptors and do not require enzymatic conversion.
    • Particularly useful in younger patients to delay levodopa initiation and reduce the risk of motor complications from levodopa.
  3. MAO-B Inhibitors (Selegiline, Rasagiline, Safinamide)
    • Block breakdown of dopamine in the brain, thereby prolonging its action.
    • It provides mild symptomatic benefit and can be used early in the disease as monotherapy in mild PD.
    • Often used as adjuncts to levodopa to reduce "off" time.
  4. COMT Inhibitors (Entacapone, Tolcapone)
    • Inhibit peripheral metabolism of levodopa, thereby prolonging its half-life and increasing brain availability.
    • Used only as adjuncts to levodopa to reduce "wearing-off" and lengthen "on" periods.
  5. Other Medical Therapies
    • Amantadine: Especially effective for treating dyskinesias in advanced PD
    • Anticholinergics (Trihexyphenidyl, Benztropine): Used mainly in younger patients with predominant tremor. There is limited use in the elderly due to cognitive side effects and risk of confusion.

choices.text: The RMP becomes more negative, and the cell's excitability decreases
The RMP becomes more negative, and the cell becomes more excitable
The RMP becomes less negative, and the cell's excitability decreases
The RMP becomes less negative, and the cell becomes more excitable

questions.text: A patient's laboratory report shows a serum potassium concentration of 3 mEq/L. How would this level affect the resting membrane potential (RMP) of excitable cells such as neurons or muscle fibres?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A serum potassium of 3 mEq/L represents hypokalemia. At rest, the membrane is highly permeable to potassium because many potassium leak channels are open, so the RMP is largely determined by the potassium equilibrium potential (around -90 mV under normal conditions).

  • When extracellular potassium falls, the concentration gradient across the cell membrane increases.
  • More potassium ions leave the cell, making the inside of the cell even more negative (hyperpolarised).
  • A hyperpolarised cell requires a larger stimulus to reach the threshold for action potential generation, so excitability decreases.

Explanation of other options:

The RMP becomes more negative and the cell becomes more excitable (Option B ): A more negative RMP means the membrane potential is farther from threshold, not closer. Hyperpolarisation therefore reduces, rather than enhances, excitability.

The RMP becomes less negative, and the cell's excitability decreases(Option C): A less negative (more positive) RMP would occur with hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia. While excitability can fall if sodium channels inactivate during depolarisation, that is not the effect seen with potassium at 3 mEq/L.

The RMP becomes less negative and the cell becomes more excitable(Option D): This combination describes the initial effect of mild hyperkalemia, where the membrane depolarises slightly and excitability rises, which is the opposite of what happens in low potassium.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A 52-year-old adult patient presenting with right-sided hearing loss has been subjected to audiological investigations and diagnosed to be a case of right-sided serous otitis media. What will be the priority in further management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given scenario is of an adult with unilateral (glue-ear) serous otitis media, which is an uncommon occurrence. This suggests of a suspicion towards nasopharyngeal carcinoma (occult primary) and hence, the next step in management is nasopharyngoscopy and biopsy.

  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) usually arises from the fossa of Rosenmüller.
  • Usually caused by Epstein-Barr virus, NPC is a radiosensitive cancer.
  • Chemoradiation is the best choice of treatment.

Clinical Features of Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma (NPC)

NPC symptoms are often subtle early on and can mimic benign conditions. They can be grouped into:

  • Nasal symptoms (≈50%)
    • Blood-stained nasal discharge or postnasal drip (most common).
    • Nasal obstruction if tumour blocks posterior choana.
    • Cacosmia or metallic/bloody smell.
  • Otological symptoms (30–40%)
    • Caused by Eustachian tube dysfunction.
    • Unilateral hearing loss, muffled sounds, ear fullness, tinnitus.
    • Middle ear effusion on otoscopy.
    • Important: Adult with unexplained persistent middle ear effusion → rule out NPC.
  • Neck symptoms (≈70%)
    • Most common presenting feature: cervical lymphadenopathy.
    • May present as “neck node metastasis of unknown primary.”
  • Neurological symptoms (advanced disease)
    • Headache, facial pain or midface numbness, cranial nerve palsies
    • CN III & IV palsy → cavernous sinus invasion
    • Ophthalmoplegia, proptosis, ↓ vision → orbital apex invasion
    • Trismus → invasion of pterygoid muscles, Horner syndrome (rare, due to carotid sheath encasement).
  • Systemic metastasis (uncommon at presentation)
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome
    • Dermatomyositis in ~1% of cases.
    • In endemic regions, up to 12% of dermatomyositis patients develop NPC. 

Diagnosis of NPC

  • History
    • NPC should be suspected in patients with nasal, ear, neck, or neuro symptoms with no clear cause.
    • Ask ancestry (Chinese origin: esp. Southern/Northern China).
    • Family history: ~10% show familial clustering.
  • General examination
    • Look for OME (otitis media with effusion), cranial nerve palsies, and cervical lymphadenopathy.
    • Record site/size of nodes for staging.
  • Examination of nasopharynx
    • Traditional: indirect mirror exam (often poor visualization, strong gag reflex, limited for biopsy).
      • Modern: nasopharyngoscopy (rigid or flexible endoscope).
      • Rigid: better direct view; 30° telescope for lateral wall/fossa of Rosenmüller.
      • Flexible: useful if the larynx/hypopharynx needs evaluation or the nasal anatomy limits the rigid scope.
    • Preparation: topical anaesthesia + vasoconstrictor (e.g., lignocaine + adrenaline, phenylephrine, or xylometazoline).
    • Typical findings: mass, abnormal capillaries, ulceration, and easy contact bleeding.
    • Submucosal/infiltrative lesions may need MRI to detect.
  • Biopsy
    • If visible tumour → biopsy at outpatient endoscopy.
    • Flexible scopes have smaller biopsy channels → multiple samples needed.
    • Rigid scopes: can pass ethmoid forceps under guidance.
    • Expect mild bleeding (self-limiting).
    • Anticoagulated patients need correction before biopsy.
    • If inconclusive or normal endoscopy but strong suspicion (e.g., nodal spread, raised EBV markers) → biopsy under general anaesthesia (multiple deep samples, incl. roof, central NP, both fossae of Rosenmüller).

Myringotomy (Option B): Involves making an incision in the tympanic membrane to drain fluid, but in adults with unilateral SOM, performing this before ruling out malignancy may mask the underlying disease and delay diagnosis.

Myringotomy and grommet insertion (Option C): While effective for relieving middle ear effusion and improving hearing, this is not the priority in adults because persistent unilateral SOM can be a sign of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Surgical intervention should come after ruling out serious underlying causes.

Antibiotics and decongestants (Option D): Not appropriate as the first step in an adult with unilateral serous otitis media, because the underlying cause may be a nasopharyngeal tumor. These medications are generally used for acute infections or Eustachian tube inflammation, not for chronic fluid accumulation in adults.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 210 mg/dL and a GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 39mg/min

To find the amount of glucose excreted, begin by determining the filtered glucose load.

  • Filtration load = GFR x Blood glucose
  • The glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is 90 mL/min.
  • The plasma glucose concentration is 210 mg/dL, which is equivalent to 2.1 mg/mL (since 1 dL = 100 mL).
  • Thus, the total glucose filtered each minute is: 90 mL/min × 2.1 mg/mL = 189 mg/min.

Next, compare this value to the renal transport maximum (Tm) for glucose reabsorption. From the above graph, it is 150 mg/min. Any filtered glucose beyond this threshold cannot be reabsorbed.

Finally, calculate urinary glucose loss:
Excretion = Filtered load - Tm = 189 mg/min - 150 mg/min = 39 mg/min.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Choose the correct option regarding primary hyperaldosteronism

Assertion (A): An aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) greater than 20 is considered suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism.
Reason (R): The elevated ARR occurs because renin secretion is decreased in primary hyperaldosteronism due to enhanced sodium loss.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

An aldosterone-to-renin ratio (ARR) greater than 20 is considered suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism, and this occurs because renin secretion is decreased due to sodium retention.

Primary mineralocorticoid excess was once considered a rare cause of hypertension but is now recognised more often. The likelihood is higher in cases of hypokalemic hypertension or resistant hypertension.

Etiology:

  • The condition is most commonly caused by primary aldosteronism due to either bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (micronodular, most frequent form) or unilateral aldosterone-producing adenomas (Conn's syndrome).
  • Somatic mutations in ion channels and germline mutations in certain genes contribute to pathogenesis. Rare genetic causes include familial hyperaldosteronism subtypes and glucocorticoid-remediable aldosteronism (GRA).

Pathophysiology

  • Overstimulation of mineralocorticoid receptors results in loss of potassium and enhanced sodium reabsorption, leading to expansion of plasma and extracellular fluid volume.
  • Heightened ENaC activity also promotes hydrogen ion loss, contributing to metabolic alkalosis.
  • Some patients may have normal potassium levels due to concurrent renal adjustments.

Diagnosis:

  • Screening is performed in hypertensive patients with suggestive features such as hypokalemia or resistant hypertension.
  • The initial test is the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR), with values > 20 and plasma aldosterone concentration >15 ng/dL suggesting primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Confirmation is done using suppression tests, such as the saline infusion test or oral sodium loading.
  • Imaging (CT scan) and adrenal venous sampling (AVS) help distinguish unilateral from bilateral disease.

Management:

  • Surgical: Laparoscopic adrenalectomy is the treatment of choice for unilateral adenomas or unilateral disease confirmed by AVS, especially in younger patients.
  • Medical: For bilateral hyperplasia or non-surgical candidates, treatment is with mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (spironolactone or eplerenone), often combined with potassium-sparing diuretics.
  • Special forms: Familial hyperaldosteronism, such as GRA, may respond to glucocorticoids like dexamethasone.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499983/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539779/

questions.text: What is the given imaging modality shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows contrast being injected directly into the renal pelvis through a percutaneous nephrostomy tube, which is characteristic of an antegrade pyelogram.

  • Unlike a retrograde pyelogram (contrast from bladder to ureter), antegrade pyelogram flows from the renal pelvis to the ureter and bladder, matching the image findings.
  • Procedure: Contrast is introduced directly into the renal pelvis via a percutaneous nephrostomy tube, allowing visualization of the renal pelvis, ureter, and bladder on that side.
  • Purpose: Provides detailed anatomical information of the renal pelvis and ureter, often better than ultrasound or IVU.
  • Clinical Use:
  • Usually performed before surgery to guide operative planning.
  • Can be combined with pressure flow measurements or urodynamic studies to assess the physiological significance of a dilated upper urinary tract (known as the Whitaker test).

Explanation of Other Options

IVP (Option A):

  • Contrast is given intravenously, filtered by the kidneys, and excreted into the collecting system.
  • The given image in the scenario shows contrast entering the renal pelvis from a nephrostomy tube, not via the intravenous route → rule out IVP.

Retrograde Pyelogram (Option B)

  • A catheter is placed inside the bladder and advanced into the ureter.
  • Contrast is injected retrograde (from bladder toward kidney).
  • Shows the ureter and renal pelvis.

Retrograde Urethrography (Option D)

  • A catheter or syringe is used to inject contrast into the anterior urethra through the external urethral meatus.
  • Shows the bulbar and penile urethra (anterior urethra) clearly.

Micturating/Voiding Cystourethrography (MCUG)

  • Visualizes the bladder and posterior urethra.
  • Patient is voiding or urinating during imaging.

choices.text: It inhibits viral RNA polymerase and requires phosphorylation by viral enzymes for activation
It prevents viral entry by blocking hemagglutinin binding to sialic acid receptors
It inhibits viral neuraminidase, preventing release of progeny virions from host cells
It irreversibly inhibits M2 ion channels of influenza A virus, preventing uncoating

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic during peak influenza season with fever, myalgia, dry cough, and sore throat for 24 hours. He has no significant comorbidities and is otherwise healthy. The physician decides to prescribe an antiviral agent for treatment. Which of the following statements regarding the pharmacological properties of the most appropriate drug is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oseltamivir is the most appropriate antiviral in this scenario because it inhibits viral neuraminidase, preventing release and spread of influenza A and B virions during early treatment.

Pharmacological Aspects of Oseltamivir:

  • Mechanism of Action:
    • Oseltamivir carboxylate binds neuraminidase → causes conformational change → inhibits enzymatic cleavage of sialic acid → prevents viral release and aggregation at the cell surface → reduces virus spread in respiratory tract.
  • ADME (Absorption, Distribution, Metabolism, Excretion):
    • Oral prodrug (oseltamivir phosphate) → rapidly converted by esterases in GI tract and liver to active carboxylate form.
    • Food does not reduce bioavailability but reduces GI intolerance.
    • Probenecid prolongs half-life (t½) by blocking anionic secretion.
    • Clearance altered in children <2 years.
  • Therapeutic Uses:
    • Treatment and prophylaxis of Influenza A and B.
    • Reduces illness duration by 1-2 days, prevents complications and hospitalization
    • Effective as short-term prophylaxis in exposed individuals.
  • Adverse Effects:
    • Nausea, abdominal discomfort, emesis (resolve in 1-2 days).
    • Headache more frequent in elderly during prophylaxis studies.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

It inhibits viral RNA polymerase and requires phosphorylation by viral enzymes for activation (Option A): Mechanism of drugs like Favipiravir, not oseltamivir.

It prevents viral entry by blocking hemagglutinin binding to sialic acid receptors (Option B): This is the mechanism of action of drugs targeting hemagglutinin, not neuraminidase inhibitors.

It irreversibly inhibits M2 ion channels of influenza A virus, preventing uncoating (Option D): Amantadine and Rimantadine act via M2 channel inhibition (effective only for influenza A and limited by resistance).

questions.text: A 72-year-old man with mechanical heart valves with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus presents with palpitations. An ECG was recorded and is as shown below. He has no prior history of stroke, TIA, or thromboembolism. On examination, BP is 150/90 mmHg. Echocardiography shows normal left ventricular function. Which of the following is the preferred drug for anticoagulation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical presentation and ECG is atrial fibrillation, and the CHADS₂- VASc score for this patient is 3. (age greater than 64 and less than 75, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus) so anticoagulation with warfarin is indicated since he has valvular atrial fibrillation.

  • Atrial fibrillation (AF) is an irregular, rapid arrhythmia caused by disorganised atrial electrical activation, leading to ineffective atrial contraction.
  • The ventricular rate is typically irregular, often ranging from 110 to 160 beats per minute, but may exceed 200 in some cases or be unusually slow in those with conduction abnormalities or high vagal tone.
  • AF is the most common sustained arrhythmia, and its prevalence rises significantly with age, affecting over 95% of people above 60 years.
  • Clinical manifestations vary and include palpitations, fatigue, syncope, dyspnea, and signs of reduced cardiac output.
  • P waves are typically absent on ECG.
  • Stroke is the most serious complication of atrial fibrillation (AF), making prevention central to management.
  • The cornerstone of prevention is long-term anticoagulation, especially in patients with risk factors such as hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, mitral stenosis, or prior stroke.
  • Risk assessment is best guided by the CHA₂DS₂-VASc score.
  • However, anticoagulation carries a significant bleeding risk, commonly assessed using the HAS-BLED score.

Stroke Risk and Bleeding Risk Scoring Systems

Anticoagulation choices:

  • Warfarin has long been the standard, but requires INR monitoring and carries food and drug interactions.
  • Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) such as dabigatran, rivaroxaban, and apixaban are as effective or superior to warfarin in nonvalvular AF and are easier to administer, though dose adjustment is needed in renal impairment.
  • For valvular AF (e.g., rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical valves), warfarin remains superior.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old man presents with progressive urinary hesitancy, weak urinary stream, and nocturia. Digital rectal examination reveals a smooth, firm, symmetrically enlarged prostate without nodules. Serum PSA is slightly elevated but within the age-adjusted range. Transrectal ultrasound demonstrates enlargement of the region encircling the proximal prostatic urethra and bladder neck.
Based on the zonal anatomy of the prostate, which zone is primarily responsible for these obstructive symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has classic BPH symptoms: lower urinary tract symptoms (hesitancy, weak stream, nocturia).
  • DRE: smooth, symmetric, firm enlargement (contrasts with carcinoma, which is hard and nodular).
  • PSA: may be mildly elevated in BPH but typically not as high as in carcinoma.
  • TRUS finding: enlargement around the proximal prostatic urethra is diagnostic of transition zone pathology, which is the site of BPH.

Zonal Anatomy of the Prostate

  • Zonal Division (Glandular Tissue):
    • Peripheral Zone (PZ): ~70% of prostate volume. (Option B)
      • Most common site of Carcinoma.
      • Cup-shaped; surrounds central and transition zones and intramural urethra, except anteriorly (fibromuscular stroma).
    • Central Zone (CZ): ~25% of volume. (Option C)
      • Conical shape, apex at seminal colliculus.
      • Surrounds ejaculatory ducts posterior to intramural urethra.
      • Rarely involved in disease.
    • Transition Zone (TZ): ~5% of volume. (Option A)
    • The transition zone surrounds the proximal prostatic urethra, just below the bladder neck and extends from the bladder neck to the verumontanum, anterior to and partly lateral to the central zone and ejaculatory ducts.
      • Site of BPH.
      • Ducts enter prostatic urethra just below the internal urethral sphincter.
  • Non-glandular Tissue:
    • Fibromuscular stroma: (Option D)
      • Fills anterior space between peripheral zones.
      • Includes smooth muscle of detrusor apron (superoanterior) and striated urethral sphincter fibers.

Key Takeaway:

  • BPH mainly involves the transition zone, and enlargement of this zone causes urinary obstruction in affected males.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in given CT scan:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The marked structure on the CT scan is an air cell located inferomedial to the floor of the orbit, which is characteristic of a Haller cell (infraorbital ethmoidal cell).

  • Location: Found inferomedial to the orbital floor, adjacent to the maxillary sinus ostium.
  • Anatomy: Haller cells are infraorbital ethmoidal cells and represent pneumatization of the ethmoidal air cells.
  • Clinical Significance:
    • Can narrow the maxillary sinus infundibulum, contributing to sinus drainage obstruction.
    • Important to identify before functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) to avoid complications.
    • CT Identification: Seen as a small, air-filled cell adjacent to the orbital floor; often visualized in coronal or axial paranasal sinus CT.
    • Anterior Ethmoidal Canal → Contains the anterior ethmoidal artery, seen as a canal, not an air cell → incorrect.
    • Concha Bullosa (Pneumatized Middle Turbinate) → Air-filled middle turbinate, usually in the nasal cavity lateral wall → incorrect location.
    • Hiatus Semilunaris → Semilunar space around the uncinate process, part of the osteomeatal complex, not an ethmoidal air cell → incorrect.

Explanation of other options:

Anterior Ethmoidal Canal (Option A): Contains the anterior ethmoidal artery, seen as a canal, not an air cell. It must be identified during surgery to avoid vascular injury.

Concha Bullosa (Pneumatized Middle Turbinate) (Option C): Pneumatized (air-filled) portion of the middle turbinate, usually in the nasal cavity lateral wall. It is also called concavullosa

Hiatus Semilunaris (Option D): Semilunar space around the uncinate process, part of the osteomeatal complex, which extends from the maxillary ostium to the middle meatus. It is not an ethmoidal air cell.

choices.text: Start breastfeeding immediately and recheck glucose in 30 minutes
Give IV bolus of 10% dextrose at 2 mL/kg followed by continuous infusion
Start IV dextrose infusion at 6 mg/kg/min without bolus
Observe for spontaneous improvement and repeat glucose after 1 hour

questions.text: A 2.8-kg term neonate, born to a mother with uncontrolled gestational diabetes, is noted to be jittery at 6 hours of life. Blood glucose is 22 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This neonate is symptomatic (jittery) with blood glucose <25 mg/dL, which requires urgent correction.
  • The recommended immediate management is an IV bolus of 10% dextrose at 2 mL/kg, followed by a continuous infusion to maintain glucose levels.
  • This approach prevents neurological injury from severe hypoglycaemia.
  • Infants of diabetic mothers are at particularly high risk due to persistent fetal hyperinsulinemia.
  • Asymptomatic, BG 20-45 mg/dL → trial of oral feeds.
  • BG <20 mg/dL or symptomatic → IV 10% dextrose bolus 2 mL/kg, then infusion (6 mg/kg/min).
  • If infusion requirement >12 mg/kg/min → suspect persistent refractory hypoglycaemia, investigate for metabolic/endocrine causes.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Start breastfeeding immediately and recheck glucose in 30 minutes (option A): Appropriate only for asymptomatic neonates with mild hypoglycaemia (20-45 mg/dL). This baby is symptomatic, so IV therapy is required.

Start IV dextrose infusion at 6 mg/kg/min without bolus (option C): Without an initial bolus, glucose correction will be delayed, risking neuronal injury.

Observe for spontaneous improvement and repeat glucose after 1 hour (option D): Observation alone is unsafe in symptomatic hypoglycaemia; immediate IV therapy is needed.

Key Takeaway:

Symptomatic neonatal hypoglycemia or blood glucose <25 mg/dL requires immediate IV 10% dextrose bolus (2 mL/kg) followed by infusion. Oral feeds and observation are only for asymptomatic mild hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A study finds a strong positive correlation (r = 0.85) across different Indian states between the per capita availability of refrigerators and the rate of diagnosis of foodborne illnesses. The authors conclude that owning a refrigerator increases the risk of food poisoning. This conclusion is most likely an example of which type of error in epidemiological reasoning?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Ecological Fallacy:

  • The ecological fallacy is an error in the interpretation of statistical data that arises when inferences about the nature of individuals are deduced from aggregate or group-level data (e.g., per capita data, national averages, state-level data).
  • It occurs when one assumes that relationships observed for groups necessarily hold true for the individuals within those groups.

In the given scenario:

  • The data is collected at the group level (state-level correlation between per capita refrigerator ownership and disease rate).
  • The conclusion is drawn at the individual level (inferring that an individual who owns a refrigerator is at higher risk).
  • This is a classic example of an ecological fallacy. The observed correlation at the state level could be due to many other factors. For instance:
    • Wealthier states might have higher ownership of refrigerators and better healthcare infrastructure and reporting systems, leading to higher diagnosis rates of foodborne illnesses, not necessarily higher incidence.
    • The conclusion ignores the fact that within each state, the individuals who own refrigerators might actually have a lower risk of food poisoning due to better food storage, while the high state-level rate is driven by those without access to refrigeration.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Confounding (Option A): Confounding occurs when a third factor is associated with both the exposure and the outcome and distorts the observed relationship. While confounding is likely present in the group-level data (e.g., state wealth), the core error here is the act of applying the group-level finding to individuals, which is the definition of ecological fallacy.

Selection bias (Option B): This reers to a systematic error in the selection of study participants (e.g., selecting a non-representative sample). Te error here is in the interpretation of the data, not in the selection of the states for comparison.

Recall bias (Option D): This is a systematic error in which participants in a study inaccurately recall or report past exposures or events. This is a problem in case-control or cohort studies with individual-level data, not in an ecological study using pre-existing aggregate data.

choices.text: Cell-free fetal DNA testing from maternal blood

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida undergoes first-trimester screening at 12 weeks. Her reports show increased nuchal translucency, low PAPP-A, and elevated free β-hCG. What is the next best step for confirmation of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient's first-trimester combined screen (↑ nuchal translucency, ↓ PAPP-A, ↑ free β-hCG) is suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome). While screening tests estimate risk, they do not confirm the diagnosis. Since the patient is 12 weeks, the most appropriate confirmatory test is chorionic villus sampling (CVS) with karyotyping, which provides a definitive diagnosis in the first trimester.

Screening markers for trisomy 21:

  • AFP: decreases
  • Unconjugated estriol (UE3): decreases
  • β-hCG: increases
  • PAPP-A: decreases
  • Inhibin A: increases

Screening tests:

  • Double test (1st trimester): PAPP-A + β-hCG
  • Triple test (2nd trimester, 15-18 weeks): AFP, β-hCG, UE3
  • Quadruple test (2nd trimester): Triple test + inhibin A
  • Combined test (1st trimester): Double test + USG NT measurement
  • Integrated test: 1st trimester combined test + 2nd trimester quadruple test (gives best detection rates)

Diagnostic tests:

  • Karyotyping via invasive sampling is required for confirmation:
    • Chorionic villus sampling (CVS): 10-13 weeks
    • Amniocentesis: 15-20 weeks
    • Cordocentesis: after 20 weeks
  • Non-invasive option: Cell-free fetal DNA sequencing (cffDNA) from maternal serum is highly sensitive but is still considered a screening tool, not definitive.

Key Takeaway

Abnormal first-trimester screening requires confirmation with an invasive diagnostic test. At 12 weeks, chorionic villus sampling for karyotyping is the investigation of choice. Screening (double, triple, quad, cffDNA) estimates risk; only karyotyping confirms.

choices.text: Calcium entry into vascular smooth muscle cells increases during vessel wall stretch
Afferent arteriolar resistance rises when intrarenal pressure goes up
Renal blood flow rises significantly when systemic arterial pressure suddenly increases
This mechanism protects renal vessels from excessive distension

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect with respect to the myogenic mechanism that maintains stable renal blood flow (RBF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The renal blood flow remains constant regardless of the blood pressure as long as the BP is between 80 to 180 mmHg.

  • The myogenic response is an intrinsic property of the afferent arteriole.
  • When arterial pressure suddenly increases, the vessel wall is stretched, which triggers an influx of calcium ions into the smooth muscle cells.
  • The calcium causes the smooth muscle to contract, increasing vascular resistance and thereby preventing a rise in renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate.
  • Because of this rapid constrictor response, renal blood flow does not increase markedly during a sudden elevation in systemic pressure. Therefore, the statement that RBF rises significantly is false.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium entry into vascular smooth muscle cells increases during vessel wall stretch (Option A): This is the key initiating event in the myogenic reflex: stretch-activated channels open, allowing calcium influx and causing smooth muscle contraction.

Afferent arteriolar resistance rises when intrarenal pressure goes up (Option B): Contraction of the afferent arteriole increases vascular resistance, which limits downstream transmission of high pressure to the glomerulus.

This mechanism protects renal vessels from excessive distension (Option D): By constricting rapidly in response to sudden pressure changes, the myogenic reflex shields the delicate glomerular capillaries from hypertension-related injury.

questions.text: Which drug is the specific antidote for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning because it blocks alcohol dehydrogenase?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH). In methanol or ethylene glycol poisoning, ADH converts these alcohols into toxic metabolites (formaldehyde, formic acid, glycolic acid, oxalic acid).
  • By blocking ADH, fomepizole prevents this toxic conversion and is the treatment of choice.
  • Normal pathway:
    • Ethanol → Acetaldehyde (via ADH)
    • Acetaldehyde → Acetate (via ALDH)
  • ADH inhibitor: Fomepizole → used as antidote in methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning.
  • ALDH inhibitor: Disulfiram → used in alcohol aversion therapy by causing acetaldehyde buildup → flushing, nausea, palpitations. (Option A ruled out)
  • Competitive substrate: Ethanol → also blocks methanol metabolism by competing for ADH; historically used when fomepizole was unavailable.(Option C ruled out)
  • Disulfiram-like drugs: Metronidazole, some cephalosporins, and sulfonylureas → cause acetaldehyde accumulation when combined with alcohol but do not directly inhibit ALDH. (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaway

Fomepizole inhibits ADH and is the drug of choice for methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning. Disulfiram inhibits ALDH for aversion therapy, and ethanol competes with methanol for ADH.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought dead after being found unconscious in his locked apartment. At autopsy, the pathologist notes bilateral globus pallidus necrosis on brain examination, and the blood collected from large veins appears unusually cherry red. Which toxic agent is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning produces:
