  • Unusually bright red blood due to formation of carboxyhaemoglobin (CO has 200-250× affinity for Hb than O2).
  • Selective bilateral necrosis of the globus pallidus in the basal ganglia, a classic neuropathological hallmark.
  • Clinical survivors may later develop parkinsonism, memory impairment, or delayed neuropsychiatric sequelae.
  • Pathogenesis: Tissue hypoxia occurs because carboxyhaemoglobin reduces O2 delivery and also shifts the O2-Hb dissociation curve to the left.

Carbon Monoxide (CO):

  • Physical properties:
    • Odourless, colourless, non-irritating gas, lighter than air
  • Sources of Poisoning:
    • Incomplete combustion (wood, charcoal, gas)
    • Automobile exhaust
    • Fires (mass deaths)
    • Paint remover (methylene chloride)
    • Tobacco smoke
  • Normal CO Level in Plasma:
    • 1-5%;
    • 7-8% in smokers
  • Mechanism of Action:
    • 230-270× greater affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen → Forms carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb)
    • Leftward shift of oxyhaemoglobin dissociation curve → Reduced O2 delivery
    • Inactivates mitochondrial cytochrome oxidase → Impaired cellular respiration
    • Brain injury at basal ganglia, hippocampus, cerebellum
  • Clinical Features:
    • Depends on blood CO concentration; teratogenic during pregnancy
  • Diagnosis:
    • Carboxyhaemoglobin (COHb) level in blood
    • Arterial blood gases
  • Treatment:
    • Normobaric O2
    • Hyperbaric O2 in COHb level >25% and in pregnancy >15%
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • Cherry red skin, lips, nail beds, tongue, palms, soles
    • Cherry red blood
    • Cutaneous bullae (calves, buttocks, wrists, knees)
    • Firm white matter of brain
    • Necrosis of globus pallidus, putamen & corpus callosum and cavitation

Note:

  • Globus pallidus and corpus callosum necrosis are features of poisoning by Amphetamine, Barbiturates, CO, Heroin, Cocaine and T
  • Necrosis of the putamen is seen in poisoning by Methanol, CO and c

Postmortem Staining (Livor Mortis):

  • Caused by gravitational settling of blood in dependent body areas after death.
  • The colour of the stain can suggest certain poisons.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cyanide (Option B): Causes bright red/brick red venous blood (cells cannot extract O2 → histotoxic hypoxia). Does not cause globus pallidus necrosis. Putamen necrosis may be seen. neuropathology is different. Blood is bright red or brick red in color.

Methanol (Option C): Causes necrosis of putamen and optic nerve damage. Does not cause globus pallidus necrosis. Also associated with metabolic acidosis.

Aniline derivatives (Option D): Cause methemoglobinemia with reddish-brown coloured blood and sometimes deep blue. Not cherry red blood.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with recurrent joint swelling and pain after minor trauma. There is no history of petechiae or purpura. Laboratory studies show a normal platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, but a prolonged aPTT. Factor 8 levels were found to be 10%. Which of the following is the most likely pattern of inheritance for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Key Features:

  • Recurrent joint swelling and pain → suggests hemarthroses (bleeding into joints).
  • No petechiae or purpura → indicates normal platelet number and function; rules out primary platelet disorders.

Laboratory Findings:

Hence, the likely diagnosis is von Willebrand Disease (vWD), the most common inherited bleeding disorder.

Typical laboratory findings include: prolonged bleeding time, normal PT, prolonged aPTT, reduced factor VIII.

  • Type I vWF deficiency: Autosomal dominant, most common bleedeing disorder, and usually asymptomatic.
  • Type II vWF deficiency: Autosomal dominant, funtioning of vWF is not proper.
  • Type III vWF deficiency: Autosomal recessive, most severe, always symptomatic from birth and has a vWF of 0.

Explanation of Other Options:

Autosomal recessive (Option B): Seen in rare vWD types (Type 3), usually more severe with early onset bleeding. Not consistent with mild/moderate phenotype in this patient.

X-linked recessive (Option C): Characteristic of Hemophilia A (factor VIII deficiency) or Hemophilia B (factor IX deficiency). Typically, only males are affected, presents with hemarthroses, normal platelet function, but family history of affected males. In this case, the absence of family history and the bleeding pattern point toward vWD.

X-linked dominant (Option D): Extremely rare, usually lethal in males or severely affected, not compatible with this mild presentation.

questions.text: Match the following types of drowning with their characteristic features:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CLASSIFICATION OF DROWNING:

  • Wet drowning (Classical/Typical/Primary drowning) → Water is inhaled into lungs → As water acts as foreign body, it stimulates secretion of mucus → Water get churned (mixed) up with mucous (due to violent respiratory efforts) → Forms copious amount of white, fine, leathery froth with pulmonary edema → known as Emphysema acquosum (Drowning lung)

    • When freshwater(hypotonic to plasma) enters the alveolar spaces, it is rapidly absorbed into the pulmonary circulation resulting in gross hemodilution. This massive increase in blood volume leads to hemolysis with the liberation of potassium. This causes hyperkalemia with corresponding dilutional hyponatremia. Hyperkalemia leads to ventricular fibrillation (death in 4-5minutes).
    • When seawaterenters, due to high saline content, reverse osmosis The fluid leaves the circulation and enters the alveolar spaces. This causes hemoconcentration, hypernatremia and pulmonary oedema. Hypernatremia leads to bradycardia and cardiac arrest(death in 8-10 minutes).
  • Submersion of an unconscious person → Water enters lungs → Mixed up with mucous (But ↓ resp. movement due to unconsciousness) → Minimal froth with Pulmonary edema → Edema acquosum
  • Dry drowning - Water trickles the larynx → Laryngospasm → No froth
  • Immersion syndrome (Hydrocution, submersion inhibition) - Death resulting from cardiac arrest due to vagal inhibition → No froth
  • Incidence 1-2% cases of drowning
  • Causes:
    • Icy cold water stimulating the nerve endings at the surface of the body
    • Cold water entering ear drums, nasal passages, pharynx and larynx, stimulating nerve endings at mucosal surfaces
    • Water striking the epigastrium
  • Circumstances:
    • Diving into the water feet first
    • Diving with horizontal entry in water (with consequent blow on the Abdomen)
    • "Duck diving" by the inexperienced ("Duck diving" is a surfing term in
    • which the surfer pushes the surfboard underwater).
    • Aggravating factors: Alcohol and emotional tension (As in cases of suicide)
  • Secondary drowning (Post-immersion syndrome) → An immersed or submerged victim is resuscitated → But dies after 24 hours due to complications such as Post hypoxic encephalopathy (MC), Electrolyte imbalance, ARDS, Pneumonitis, Pneumonia, Cerebral edema, DIC etc. → No froth.

Note:

Near Drowning = The victim survives the drowning episode.

Definite signs of antemortem drowning:

1. Cadaveric Spasm with weeds/grass in the hand

2. Emphysema aquosum

  • The lungs are voluminous, may completely cover the pericardial sac, and bulge out of chest when the sternum is removed. This is known as ballooning and is due to presence of fluid and air in the bronchi.
  • The lungs are overdistended, and the alveolar walls are torn.
  • The oedema fluid in the bronchi blocks the passive collapse that normally occurs at death, holding the lungs in the inspiratory position. In addition, there is often an element of over-distension caused by valvular action of bronchial obstruction. This produces impression of ribs (grooves) on lateral surface of lungs, which is an important sign of drowning.
  • On section, an oedematous condition due to the presence of watery, frothy, sometimes blood-stained fluid is seen.
  • Drowning fluid actually penetrates alveolar walls to enter the tissues and the blood vessels.
  • This has been described as emphysema aquosum

3. Copious amount of white, fine, leathery froth (D/t Emphysema Acquosum)

4. Paltauf's haemorrhages

5. Diatoms (The medico-legal importance of diatoms is controversial. If the same species of diatoms present in the drowning media is present in bone marrow and if the victim had not drunk the same water before submersion is the most important internal sign of antemortem drowning)

Reference:

https://www.healthline.com/health/near-drowning

choices.text: The data is normally distributed; the mean is the best measure.
The data is negatively skewed; the median is the best measure.
The data is positively skewed; the median is the best measure.
There is a calculation error; the mean and median should be equal.

questions.text: In a community health survey, the data for "annual per capita health expenditure" is collected from 500 households. The mean expenditure is calculated to be Rs 15,000, while the median is Rs 8,000. What is the most likely explanation for this discrepancy, and what is the best measure of central tendency to represent this data?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Mean-Median Discrepancy:

  • Mean (Rs 15,000): The arithmetic average. It is highly influenced by extreme values (outliers) in the data set.
  • Median (Rs 8,000): The middle value when all data points are sorted in order. It is resistant to the influence of extreme values.
  • Observation: The mean is significantly higher than the median (Mean > Median).

Interpreting the Skewness:

  • Positive Skew (Right-Skewed Distribution):
    • In a positively skewed distribution, the tail on the right-hand side is longer.
    • A small number of households have very high health expenditures (e.g., due to a major illness, surgery, or chronic disease treatment).
    • These extremely high values "pull" the mean towards the right, making it much larger than the median.
  • This is the classic signature of a positively skewed distribution: Mean > Median > Mode.
  • Health expenditure data is usually positively skewed in most populations, as a majority of people have low to moderate expenses, while a few have catastrophically high ones.

Best Measure of Central Tendency:

  • For symmetrical, normally distributed data, the mean, median, and mode are equal, and the mean is the preferred measure.
  • For skewed distributions, the median is the preferred measure of central tendency because it gives a more accurate representation of a "typical" value. It is not distorted by the extreme values that disproportionately affect the mean.
  • Reporting the mean (Rs 15,000) would overestimate the typical health expenditure for most households in this community.
  • The median (Rs 8,000) provides a better central value for this skewed data.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

The data is normally distributed; the mean is the best measure (Option A): In a normal distribution, the mean and median are equal. The significant discrepancy here rules this out.

The data is negatively skewed; the median is the best measure (Option B): A negatively skewed (left-skewed) distribution has a long tail on the left. In this case, the mean would be less than the median (Mean < Median). Our data shows the opposite.

There is a calculation error; the mean and median should be equal (Option D): This is unlikely. The described pattern is a well-known and expected phenomenon for variables like income and health expenditure, not an error.

questions.text: What is the recommended single prophylactic dose of vitamin A for a 9-month-old child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin A prophylaxis is given as a single age-appropriate mega dose on day 1, ensuring no dose has been given in the previous month. For a 9-month-old child (6-11 months), the correct dose is 100,000 IU.

Additional notes:

  • Children >1 year but <8 kg → give half-dose (100,000 IU)
  • If signs of deficiency are present → give 3 doses (Day 1, Day 2, Day 14)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

150,000 IU (option C): Not part of the recommended dosing schedule at any age.

Key Takeaway

Vitamin A prophylaxis is age-specific: 50,000 IU (<6 months), 100,000 IU (6-11 months), 200,000 IU (≥12 months). For a 9-month-old, the correct dose is 100,000 IU.

questions.text: Match the PAX genes with their associated conditions.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

PAX (Paired Box) genes are a family of transcription factor genes that contain a highly conserved paired-box DNA-binding domain. They play a critical role in regulating embryonic development, including tissue differentiation, organogenesis, and cell lineage specification.

There are 9 PAX genes in humans (PAX1 - PAX9), divided into 4 subgroups based on domain structure and sequence similarity.

questions.text: A 42-year-old recreational cyclist experiences persistent knee pain following a recent injury. To help manage his discomfort, the following technique has been employed. Activation of which of the following types of nerve fibers near the site of injury is done by this method?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief which is based on the Gate Control Theory of Pain.

How Gate Control Theory Works:

  • Pain signals are transmitted to the spinal cord via small-diameter fibers:
    • C fibers: unmyelinated, slow, carry dull, aching pain.
    • Aδ fibers: lightly myelinated, faster, carry sharp, localized pain.
  • Non-painful stimuli, such as touch or proprioception, are transmitted via large-diameter, myelinated fibers:
    • Aβ fibers: carry tactile sensations (e.g., touch, pressure).
    • Aα fibers: carry proprioceptive signals (e.g., limb position).
  • When Aβ and Aα fibers are stimulated, they send signals that:
    • Activate inhibitory interneurons in the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn in the spinal cord.
    • These interneurons suppress transmission of pain signals from C and Aδ fibers.
    • This is metaphorically referred to as "closing the gate" to pain.

TENS Mechanism:

  • TENS delivers mild electrical currents through the skin using surface electrodes.
  • It selectively activates Aβ and Aα fibers near the injury site.
  • As a result, it reduces the perception of pain by inhibiting pain signal transmission in the spinal cord.

Explanation of incorrect options:

C & Aδ (Option A)

  • These fibers transmit pain:
    • C fibers: slow, dull, burning pain.
    • Aδ fibers: sharp, acute pain.
  • Stimulating these fibers would increase pain, not relieve it.

Aα & Aδ(Option B):

  • Aα fibers are involved in proprioception and help inhibit pain, But Aδ fibers transmit pain, not inhibit it.
  • Stimulating Aδ fibers would activate pain, not reduce it.

Aβ & Aδ(Option D):

  • Aβ fibers help with touch and pressure, and their stimulation helps in pain inhibition.
  • Aδ fibers are pain-conducting fibers.
  • Stimulating both simultaneously would send mixed signals, and pain transmission would not be effectively inhibited.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with lesions on body as shown. These are accentuated by Wood's lamp. Which of the following systemic conditions has the strongest association with this dermatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The multiple depigmented (or white) macules and patches with scalloped margins, affecting the skin and mucosa as in the image, point towards the diagnosis of vitiligo vulgaris. Among systemic conditions, thyroid disease (Hashimoto thyroiditis) has the strongest association with this dermatosis.

  • Disease: Autoimmune, TH1 cells.
  • Target: Melanocytes.
  • Lesions: Depigmented, white macules with scalloped margins.
  • Accentuates on Woods lamp examination: Ivory white or milky white under Woods lamp.

Associated Diseases with Vitiligo

  • Autoimmune/Endocrine Disorders:
    • Thyroid disease - hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism (strongest association) (Option B)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Addison disease
    • Diabetes mellitus
    • Hypoparathyroidism
    • Myasthenia gravis
  • Dermatologic/Other Skin Disorders:
    • Alopecia areata
  • Syndromic Associations:
    • Vogt-Koyanagi-Harada syndrome - vitiligo with uveitis, CNS involvement, and premature greying of hair

  • Nevus depigmentosus:
    • Present since birth.
    • It may increase with age but becomes non-progressive later.
    • Unilateral, hypopigmented, non-progressive lesion.
    • Looks dull-white under the Woods lamp.
    • Diascopy differentiates between nevus depigmentosus and anemicus.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Heterochromia iridis (Option A): Part of Wardenburg Syndrome, which is associated with piebaldism. Piebaldism is Autosomal dominant disease, the white patch on forhead is present at birth with islands of sparing. A white forlock of hair is seen.

Epilepsy (Option C): Could be associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. Here, hypomelanotic macules (Ash leaf macules) are present since birth. Accentuates under the Woods lamp. It could be associated with hypomelanosis of Ito.

Mental Retardation (Option D): Could be associated with Tuberous Sclerosis. It can also be seen with Hypomelanosis of Ito. Whorled hypopigmented streaks along a blaschkoid pattern.

Key Takeaway:

  • Vitiligo is strongly associated with thyroid disease, making thyroid evaluation important in affected patients.

questions.text: A textile worker presents with shortness of breath, chest tightness, and cough occurring on the first day after returning to work following a weekend break. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of byssinosis, also known as Monday fever.

  • Cause: Chronic inhalation of cotton fiber dust.
  • Symptoms:
  • Chronic cough
  • Progressive dyspnoea (shortness of breath)
  • Can lead to chronic bronchitis and emphysema
  • Epidemiology:
  • India has a large textile industry employing ~35% of factory workers
  • Incidence reported as 7-8% in surveys from Mumbai, Ahmedabad, and Delhi

Explanation of other options:

Bagassosis (Option B) can be ruled out because it occurs in sugarcane workers exposed to moldy bagasse, not in textile workers.

Farmer's lung (Option C) is caused by inhalation of moldy hay or crops, and the symptoms usually develop gradually rather than acutely on the first day back at work.

Silo filler's disease (Option D) is caused by inhalation of toxic nitrogen oxide gases (NO, NO2, N2O4) that accumulate at the base of recently filled silos and can cause symptoms ranging from cough and respiratory distress to vascular collapse and death in severe exposures. Sources: corn, oats, heavily fertilised crops.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In a patient with severe preeclampsia at 30 weeks gestation, immediate delivery is always the definitive treatment, regardless of maternal stabilization or fetal well-being.
Reason (R): The pathophysiological changes of preeclampsia are reversible only upon termination of the pregnancy, as the placenta is the root cause of the systemic endothelial dysfunction.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The reason is true, the pathophysiology of preeclampsia is rooted in abnormal placentation, leading to placental release of anti-angiogenic factors that cause systemic endothelial dysfunction. This process is indeed reversible only upon delivery of the placenta, which is why delivery is the definitive cure.
  • While delivery is definitive, immediate delivery is not always the first step, regardless of circumstances. For a stable patient at a pre-viable or very premature gestation (e.g., 30 weeks), the risks of extreme prematurity for the newborn must be balanced. The standard of care is maternal stabilization (with MgSO4 seizure prophylaxis and antihypertensives) and administration of corticosteroids for fetal lung maturation, aiming to prolong the pregnancy for 48 hours unless maternal or fetal condition deteriorates.
  • Immediate delivery is reserved for uncontrollable hypertension, eclampsia, HELLP syndrome, or non-reassuring fetal status.

Key Takeaways:

  • Delivery is definitive but timing is a balance between maternal and fetal risks.
  • Stable patients <34 weeks should receive steroids and be managed expectantly for 48 hours if possible.
  • The placenta is the pathogenic source; removal reverses the disease.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man presents with sudden, severe substernal chest pain unrelieved by nitroglycerin. ECG shows ST-segment elevation consistent with acute myocardial infarction. On the second day after symptom onset, which histologic change is most likely to be seen in the infarcted myocardial tissue?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

MI progresses through a predictable sequence of morphologic changes. After ischemia, coagulative necrosis develops in 12-;24 hours.

  • Neutrophils are the first inflammatory cells to infiltrate, starting at ~12 hours and peaking at 48-;72 hours.
  • By day 2 (48 hours) → the infarct is dominated by dense neutrophilic infiltrate around necrotic myocytes.
  • Later:
    • Day 3-;7: macrophages appear (Option C ruled out), phagocytosing necrotic debris.
    • Day 7-;14: vascularized granulation tissue (Option B ruled out)
    • Weeks → months: progressive collagen deposition (Option A ruled out) and scar formation.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) analogs are considered a second-line medical therapy for endometriosis-associated pain in women who are not seeking immediate pregnancy.
Reason (R): GnRH analogs induce a state of medical menopause, effectively suppressing endometriotic implant activity, but their use is limited to 6 months due to the risk of reversible osteopenia and prohibitive cost.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Assertion (A): True.
    • GnRH analogs (e.g., leuprolide) are indeed used for endometriosis-associated pain but are considered second-line, after first-line therapies like combined oral contraceptives and progestins.
  • Reason (R): True.
    • They induce a hypoestrogenic state ("medical menopause"), which suppresses estrogen-driven activity of endometriotic implants.
    • Their use is restricted to 6 months because of reversible osteopenia (bone mineral density loss) and high cost.
  • But R is not the correct explanation of A.
    • The primary reason they are second-line is because first-line agents (OCPs, progestins, NSAIDs) are effective, safer for long-term use, and better tolerated.
    • Osteopenia/cost explains why their duration is limited, not why they are second-line therapy.
  • Endometriosis is defined by the presence of ectopic endometrial glands and stroma outside the uterine cavity. These hormonally responsive implants undergo cyclical shedding and bleeding, leading to local inflammation, fibrosis, and adhesion formation.
  • The condition classically presents with the triad of secondary dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and infertility.
  • Ovarian endometrial deposits may form "chocolate cysts" or endometriomas, characterized by old, hemolyzed blood giving a brown appearance due to hemosiderin deposition. The presence of an endometrioma is a marker of severe endometriosis.
  • Transvaginal sonography serves as the first-line imaging investigation for endometriosis. However, laparoscopy is the investigation of choice as it allows for both definitive diagnosis through direct visualization and biopsy of implants, and simultaneous therapeutic intervention. Histopathological confirmation of ectopic endometrial tissue remains the gold standard for diagnosis.
  • Surgical management via laparoscopy is indicated when medical therapy fails. Procedures include adhesiolysis, fulguration of implants, ovarian cystectomy, and LUNA (laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation) to restore anatomy, excise disease, and relieve symptoms.

choices.text: An Apgar score of 6 at 5 minutes is considered normal and resuscitation can be stopped
Apgar score guides immediate resuscitation decisions in the delivery room
Apgar score <7 at 5 minutes requires reassessment every 5 minutes until ≥7
Apgar score evaluates only respiratory effort and heart rate

questions.text: A newborn has an Apgar score of 5 at 1 minute and 6 at 5 minutes. Which of the following statements regarding the Apgar score is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Apgar score is calculated at 1 and 5 minutes after birth, and then at 10, 15, 20 minutes if resuscitation is ongoing or if the score is <7.

  • It evaluates 5 parameters: Appearance (color), Pulse, Grimace (reflex irritability), Activity (muscle tone), and Respiratory effort.
  • Score ranges: 7-10 normal, 4-6 moderately depressed, 0-3 severely depressed.
  • Importantly, Apgar does not guide resuscitation steps (those depend on heart rate, breathing, tone). Instead, low scores at 5 minutes and beyond are used as prognostic markers for neonatal outcomes, especially risk of neurological injury.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

An Apgar score of 6 at 5 minutes is considered normal and resuscitation can be stopped (option A): A score <7 at 5 minutes is not normal; monitoring and reassessment every 5 minutes must continue until ≥7.

Apgar score guides immediate resuscitation decisions in the delivery room (option B): Resuscitation is guided by heart rate, breathing, and tone, not Apgar.

Apgar score evaluates only respiratory effort and heart rate (option D): The score evaluates five parameters (Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, Respiration), not just two.

Key Takeaway

Apgar score is assessed at 1 and 5 minutes, continued every 5 minutes if <7, and predicts outcome rather than guiding resuscitation. A score of 7-10 is normal, 4-6 moderate depression, and 0-3 severe depression.

questions.text: A 38-year-old HIV-positive male presents with lesions on the lower limbs as shown. What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of HIV, along with the image showing multiple reddish-purple skin lesions, points towards a vascular lesion and the diagnosis of Kaposi sarcoma. The causative agent is Human herpesvirus-8 (HHV-8).

Kaposi Sarcoma (KS)

  • Multifocal endothelial proliferation caused by HHV-8; cutaneous (skin & mucosa) ± visceral involvement.
  • Nature:
    • Low-grade malignant potential
    • Mucocutaneous neoplasm
  • Predisposition: Immunocompromised states (HIV infection, transplant recipients).
  • Predisposing Factors:
    • Causative agent: Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
    • Co-factors:
      • HIV co-infection increases risk up to 20,000-fold.
      • Seen in HIV patients with CD4 <200.
  • Causative Organism:
    • HHV-8 / Kaposi sarcoma herpesvirus:
      • Transmitted via saliva and blood products.
      • Infects endothelial, epithelial, B cells, monocytes, fibroblasts, dendritic cells.
  • Clinical Features:

  • Cutaneous lesions: Extremities (feet > hands), ears, nose.
    • Colour: Brownish-red or violaceous neoplasm.
    • Mucosal lesions are raised flat red lesions on the mucosa.
    • Multifocal, may coalesce into plaques or nodules.
    • Lymph nodes, mucosae, and viscera may be involved.
  • Histopathology:
    • Spindle cell proliferation of irregular, complex vascular channels.
    • Promontory sign is positive
  • Immunohistochemistry shows LANA 1 marker positive.

Explanation of other options:

Human papillomavirus (Option A): This causes viral warts that are raised lesions with rough verrucous surface. These are usually skin coloured. Also, causes warts, condylomas, and certain cancers (cervical, anogenital), not Kaposi sarcoma.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option C): Associated with Oral hairy leukoplakia (white hairy patch often on the tongue), Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorders, not KS.

Herpes simplex virus (Option D): Causes oral/genital ulcers (grouped painful vesicles on a red base) and encephalitis; not implicated in KS pathogenesis.

Key Takeaway:

  • Kaposi sarcoma in HIV patients is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman reports to the hospital after a case of sexual assault. During her medical examination, which of the following procedures is banned by the Supreme Court.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The two-finger test has been banned by the Supreme Court of India because it infringes on the privacy, dignity, and bodily autonomy of rape survivors. It was a degrading and unscientific method that had no place in modern forensic practice.

Supreme Court Ruling:

  • The two-finger test violates the fundamental rights of survivors and is not scientifically valid.
  • It is not permissible in medico-legal rape examinations.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Foley's catheter insertion (Option A):

  • This is used for therapeutic purposes, including in rape victims, and is not banned by any court.

Colposcopy (Option B):

  • Colposcopy is an advanced diagnostic procedure used for detailed cervical examination and is legally valid in forensic practice.

PV speculum insertion (Option C):

  • It is a standard part of the medico-legal examination protocol to inspect the vaginal walls and cervix under proper conditions.

questions.text: A fasting plasma glucose of 128 mg/dL corresponds to which category according to ADA 2024 criteria?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A fasting plasma glucose (FPG) ≥126 mg/dL is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus according to ADA 2024. This patient's FPG of 128 mg/dL crosses the threshold.

  • The normal fasting sugar is up to 99 mg/dL.
  • Prediabetic is 100-125 mg/dL.
  • Diabetic: >/= 126 mg/dL.
  • Normal postprandial serum glucose: up to 139 mg/dL.
  • Prediabetic: 140-199 After 2 hours of meal.
  • Diabetic: >/= 200 mg/dL.

The ADA 2024 criteria allow diagnosis of diabetes by any one of the following (confirmed unless unequivocal):

  • FPG ≥126 mg/dL (after 8-hour fast)
  • 2-hour plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL during 75-g OGTT
  • HbA1c ≥6.5% if measured by NGSP-certified, standardized assays
  • Random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL in the presence of classic hyperglycemia symptoms

Prediabetes is defined as FPG 100-125 mg/dL, 2-hour OGTT 140-199 mg/dL, or HbA1c 5.7-6.4%. Importantly, the 2024 guidelines emphasize assay standardization for HbA1c, as variability can affect accuracy.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Normal glycemia (Option A): FPG <100 mg/dL, HbA1c <5.7%. Not met here.

Prediabetes (Option B): FPG 100-125 mg/dL, HbA1c 5.7-6.4%. This patient exceeds that range.

Impaired glucose tolerance (Option D): Defined by 2-hour OGTT 140-199 mg/dL, not fasting glucose.

Key Takeaway

ADA 2024 criteria: Diabetes = FPG ≥126, HbA1c ≥6.5% (NGSP standardized), OGTT ≥200, or random ≥200 with symptoms. Prediabetes = intermediate ranges (FPG 100-125, HbA1c 5.7-6.4, OGTT 140-199).

questions.text: After CABG, a 50-year-old man is shifted to ICU. After 2 days of admission in ICU, he appears to be agitated, disoriented, facing sleeping problems. He speaks to someone in the ICU in the absence of others. He asks his wife to keep eyes at the main door as someone can enter there and harm him. Family members are reporting that suddenly he started having these symptoms. Which of the following does not suggest that he is suffering from schizophrenia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Disorientation and mental confusion is seen in acute delirium, not schizophrenia.

Diagnostic criteria of schizophrenia:

  • Presence of two or more of the following symptoms for a significant portion of time during a 1-month period (or less if successfully treated).
  • At least one symptom must be from items 1, 2, or 3:
    • Delusions (Option C)
    • Hallucinations (Option A & B)
    • Disorganized speech (e.g., frequent derailment or incoherence)
  • Additional possible symptoms:
    • Severely disorganized or catatonic behavior
    • Negative symptoms, such as reduced emotional expression or lack of motivation (avolition)

questions.text: Identify the site that is responsible for relieving pain when pressure is applied to the painful area
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The structure labeled A is the periaqueductal gray matter (PAG), which plays a central role in relieving pain. When pressure is applied to a painful area, the PAG activates descending pain inhibitory pathways. These pathways project to the raphe nuclei in the ventromedial medulla, where endogenous opioids such as endorphins are released. These opioids then inhibit pain transmission in the spinal cord, effectively reducing the perception of pain. Therefore, the PAG is the primary site responsible for pain relief in this context.

Explanation for Incorrect Options:

Corticospinal Tract (Option B): This structure carries voluntary motor commands from the brain to the spinal cord. It is not involved in pain modulation,

Medial Lemniscus (Option C): The medial lemniscus is part of the ascending sensory pathway that transmits fine touch, vibration, and proprioception. It does not play a role in pain inhibition.

Medial Longitudinal Fasciculus (MLF) (Option D): The MLF coordinates eye and head movements by connecting various cranial nerve nuclei. It is unrelated to pain perception or modulation.

choices.text: Absence of new Q waves on ECG
Lack of elevation in cardiac biomarkers
Duration of chest pain lasting more than 20 minutes

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with hypertension and diabetes presents with substernal chest pain lasting 30 minutes, brought on by exertion and relieved partially with rest. ECG shows ST-segment depression in the anterior leads. Serum troponin I levels are measured twice, 6 hours apart, and remain within normal limits. Which of the following best distinguishes this patient's condition from an NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of unstable angina, and among the given options, the lack of elevation in cardiac biomarkers can be used to distinguish it from NSTEMI.

Acute Coronary Syndromes (ACS) includes:

  • STEMI: With ST-elevation and necrosis.
  • NSTE-ACS (non-ST-segment elevation acute coronary Syndrome)

NSTE-ACS encompasses NSTEMI (with necrosis) and unstable angina (ischemia without necrosis).

Pathophysiology of NSTE-ACS

  • Caused by an imbalance between myocardial oxygen demand and supply, typically from coronary thrombosis.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Plaque rupture with inflammation (T-cell-mediated immune activity).
    • Plaque rupture without inflammation.
    • Plaque erosion with platelet-rich thrombus.
    • Vasospasm or increased oxygen demand without thrombosis.

Clinical Presentation of NSTE-ACS

  • Chest pain is prolonged (>10 minutes), severe, and may occur at rest or with minimal exertion.
  • Pain radiates to the arm, neck, jaw, or shoulder. Equivalents include dyspnea, nausea, or weakness (more common in women, the elderly, and diabetics).
  • Other findings may include diaphoresis, tachycardia, hypotension, pulmonary rales, gallop sounds, or cardiogenic shock in severe disease.

Diagnosis

  • Unstable angina: Ischemic symptoms ± ECG changes, but normal troponins (no necrosis).
  • NSTEMI: Similar symptoms and ECG findings, but troponin elevation confirms necrosis.
  • ECG changes in NSTE-ACS may include ST-segment depression or T-wave inversion. In NSTEMI, changes may persist for several days.

The following image shows an ECG in a case of NSTEMI.

Risk Stratification

Treatment

  • Treatment of NSTE-ACS begins with anti-ischemic therapy (nitrates, beta-blockers, calcium channel blockers, and opioids for refractory pain) and dual antiplatelet therapy in the absence of high-risk of bleeding, along with anticoagulants.
  • Risk-based invasive strategies are used, with immediate angiography for very high risk, early angiography within 24 hours for high risk, and delayed or conservative management for lower-risk patients.
  • After 12 months, treatment should be continued with a single antiplatelet agent, unless the patient requires long-term full-dose anticoagulation, in which case anticoagulant therapy alone is recommended for ongoing management.

Explanations of other options:

Absence of new Q waves on ECG (Option A): Q waves on ECG are typically seen in STEMI and not commonly in NSTEMI and unstable angina, and hence, will not help as a distinguishing feature.

Presence of ST-segment depression (Option C): ST-segment depression on ECG can be present in both unstable angina and NSTEMI.

Duration of chest pain lasting more than 20 minutes (Option D): This clinical feature can be seen in both conditions.

questions.text: During autopsy, a Forensic pathologist examines the wound of entry caused by a rifled firearm as shown in the image below. Based on the morphological features, what is the most likely range of firing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given image, there is a circular wound with Blackening and tattooing, without singeing and burning suggestive of wound caused by rifled firearm near shot.

A. Contact shot - here the muzzle end is in contact with body. It may be firm/hard/tight contact or loose contact or angled contact.

B. Close shot - here the victim is within the distance travelled by flame.

C. Near shot - here the victim is within the range of soot and smoke but outside the range of flame.

D. Intermediate shot - here the victim is within the range of powder particles but outside the range of soot and smoke.

E. Distant shot - here the victim is beyond the range of all the products of firing except the bullet.

Appearance of wounds in various ranges in rifled firearms:

  • Contact shot:
    • Firm contact: Wound of entry + Muzzle impression. (In case of contact shots over bony areas like head and sternum, it appears as cruciate shaped wound)
    • Loose contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening (corona) + Burning & singeing (Muzzle impression is unlikely)
    • Angled contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Partial muzzle Impression + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.
  • Close shot (Option D): Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.
  • Near shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening + Tattooing.
  • Intermediate shot (Option B): Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Tattooing.
  • Distant shot (Option A); Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar.

Exception: Contact shot on bony areas (head, sternum) > Escape of gas between skin and bone> Formation of temporary bulge > Forcible escape of gas through the wound of entry > Splitting of skin > Cruciate / Stellate shape > Large irregular wound.

choices.text: Increase the dose of oral iron
Switch to a different oral iron preparation
Administer a single dose of intravenous ferric carboxymaltose

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 30 weeks gestation has Hb of 7.8 g/dL. She has been compliant with oral ferrous sulfate 200 mg TDS for 4 weeks, but her Hb has not improved. She reports worsening constipation. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has moderate anemia that is unresponsive to oral iron therapy after 4 weeks, likely due to poor absorption or intolerance (constipation). The response is assessd by hemoglobin levels and the reticulocyte counts. Response is assesed after 1 month and if the hemoglobin increase is < 1gm % it is inadequate response.
  • In the second trimester, the preferred next step is parenteral iron therapy.
  • Intravenous ferric carboxymaltose allows for the administration of a complete replacement dose (1000-1500 mg) in a single sitting, rapidly correcting anemia with better tolerability but is expensive.
  • Transfusion is reserved for severe, symptomatic anemia.(Option D ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

  • Increase the dose of oral iron and Switch to a different oral iron preparation (Option A and B) : Increasing dose or switching preparation is unlikely to help if she is unresponsive and intolerant.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man received an intravenous infusion of 1200 mL of 0.45% saline (half-normal saline). His body weight is 76 kg with a BMI of 24 kg/m². Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams best illustrates the post-infusion distribution of body fluids?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

When 0.45 % saline (half-normal saline) is infused, it behaves as a hypotonic solution relative to plasma.

Here's what happens:

Extracellular fluid (ECF): The immediate effect is a fall in osmolarity with a modest increase in volume, because the infused solution is less concentrated than plasma.

Intracellular fluid (ICF): Water then moves from the now-dilute ECF into the ICF until osmotic equilibrium is restored. This raises the ICF volume and lowers its osmolarity.

Overall: Both ECF and ICF volumes increase, and the osmolarity of both compartments decreases.

The Darrow-Yannet diagram that shows expansion of both compartments with a fall in osmolarity is the one labelled C, matching the physiological response to hypotonic fluid administration.

Explanation of other options:

A (Option A): Diagram A depicts an increase in ECF volume with no change in osmolarity and no change in ICF volume, which is the pattern you would expect after infusion of an isotonic fluid (e.g., 0.9% saline). Because 0.45% saline is hypotonic and will cause water to move into cells, A does not represent the current scenario.

B (Option B ): Diagram B shows an increase in ECF volume with a rise in osmolarity and a decrease in ICF volume, which corresponds to infusion of a hypertonic solution (or net water loss from the ICF into ECF). Since half-normal saline is hypotonic and produces the opposite osmotic effect (ECF osmolarity falls and ICF volume rises), B is not appropriate.

D(Option D): Diagram D illustrates a pure increase in ICF volume with no change in ECF volume, which would imply direct intracellular fluid loading without any ECF effect - a physiologically unlikely pattern following an intravenous infusion (IV fluid first distributes into ECF). Because IV 0.45% saline initially expands the ECF before equilibrating with the ICF, D is not the correct representation.

Key takeaway:

Body Fluid Compartments

questions.text: A 20-year-old male has presented to ENT OPD with chronic painless ear discharge from right ear. The otoscopic picture is shown in the given image. Which of the following is clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The multiple perforation of the tympanic membrane gives a clue to the diagnosis of tubercular otitis media.

  • In tubercular otitis media, there are 4 important facts to note:
  • Multiple perforations in the tympanic membrane
  • Painless refractory ear discharge
  • Pale granulations
  • Facial palsy is commonly associated

Clinical Presentation:

  • Classical features:
    • Painless otorrhoea
    • Multiple tympanic membrane perforations
    • Pale granulations
    • Early severe hearing loss
    • Bone necrosis
  • Otoscopy:
    • Tympanic membrane perforation with pale/denuded mucosa
    • Middle ear bone may be denuded of mucosa (30% cases).
  • Multiple perforations (once hallmark) are now rare; small perforations may coalesce into a large one.
  • Ng’s triad for tuberculous otitis media:
    • Regional lymphadenopathy without systemic TB signs.
    • Chronic otitis refractory to conventional antibiotics.
    • Early complications (facial palsy, sensorineural loss).
  • Hearing loss:
    • Usually conductive, but may be mixed (due to labyrinthitis).
    • Often disproportionate to otoscopic findings.
  • Absence of otalgia + early complications (e.g., facial nerve palsy in 10–20%) should raise suspicion.
  • Facial palsy without cholesteatoma is highly suggestive.

Tubo-tympanic CSOM (Option A) shows a single central perforation in the pars tensa with mucopurulent discharge, whereas here there are multiple painless perforations.

Serous otitis media (Option B) is not the case here because it presents with fluid behind an intact tympanic membrane and does not cause chronic ear discharge.

Attico-antral CSOM (Option C) is incorrect because it typically presents with an attic perforation and foul-smelling, blood-stained discharge due to cholesteatoma, which is not the case here.

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with multiple erythematous scaly lesions on the trunk and proximal limbs. There is no involvement of the palms or soles, and he reports no systemic symptoms. What is the typical scaling in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Multiple red scaly plaques along the lines of cleavage, as shown in the image, the characteristic Christmas-tree pattern, indicate pityriasis rosea. The typical initial lesion in this condition is the Herald patch, and scaling is characteristically peripheral collarette.

Pityriasis Rosea

  • Acute, self-limiting hypersensitivity skin disease
  • Mainly affects children and young adults.
  • Causative organisms: Likely viral, strongest evidence for HHV-6 and HHV-7

Clinical Presentation:

  • Herald patch:
    • First lesion, larger and more conspicuous than later lesions.
    • Usually on trunk
    • Sharp red round/oval plaque with fine scale.
    • Erythematous annular plaque with scaling only in the periphery (peripheral collarette scaling)
    • Hanging curtain sign is seen here.
  • Secondary eruption:
    • Appears 5-15 days after herald patch
    • New lesions develop in crops over 1-2 weeks; may continue for several weeks.
    • Classical lesions:
      • Oval, dull red annular plaques.
      • Peripheral collarette of scale.
    • Pattern: Long axes follow lines of cleavage (Christmas tree pattern) on upper chest/back.

    • Palms/soles rarely involved.
    • No constitutional symptoms.
  • Management:
    • Usually self-limiting.
    • Emollients and topical steroids may be used.

Explanation of other options:

Furfuraceous (Option B): Seen in pityriasis versicolor caused by Malassezia furfur. Multiple hypopigmented scaly macules on upper back/chest.

Micaceous (Option C): Silvery white scaling in psoriasis.

Sandpaper (Option D): In actinic keratosis, the firmly adherent, dry, rough and often yellow or brown colored scales have a gritty feel like sandpaper and the scales are better appreciated by skin palpation.

Key Takeaway:

  • The herald patch is the hallmark initial lesion of pityriasis rosea, preceding the secondary eruption.Typical scaling is peripheral collarette of scale.

questions.text: A patient is found to have a hematocrit of 45 % and a renal plasma flow (RPF) of 700 mL/min. Based on these values, calculate the renal blood flow (RBF).
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Renal blood flow is the total volume of blood (plasma plus red cells) reaching the kidneys each minute. It is derived from the plasma flow using the formula:

Renal blood flow (RBF) = Renal plasma flow/(1-Hematocrit)

RPF / (1-Hct) = 700 / (1-0.45) = 700 / 0.55 = 1270 mL/min

Given:

  • RPF = 700 mL/min
  • Hct = 45

RPF / (1-Hct) = 700 / (1-0.45) = 700 / 0.55 = 1270 mL/min

The renal blood flow is 1270 mL/min.

Key takeaway:

Cs - clearance rate of substances "s"

EPAH - PAH extraction ratio

ERPF - effective renal plasma flow

GFR - glomerular filtration rate

P - plasma concentration

PAH - para-aminohippuric acid

PPAH - renal arterial PAH concentration

RBF - renal blood flow

RPF - renal plasma flow

S - a substance

U - urine concentration

V - urine flow rate

VPAH - renal venous PAH concentration

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason correctly explains the Assertion
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason does not explain the Assertion
Assertion is true, but the Reason is false
Assertion is false, but the Reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML) commonly presents with massive splenomegaly.
Reason (R): The BCR-ABL fusion protein causes increased apoptosis of myeloid progenitors, leading to their accumulation in the spleen.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Assertion statement is true as-

  • CML is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the BCR-ABL fusion gene (Philadelphia chromosome, t(9;22)).
  • The disease shows marked leucocytosis with increased neutrophils, basophils, eosinophils, and their precursors.
  • Massive splenomegaly is common due to extramedullary haematopoiesis and sequestration of leukemic cells.
  • Clinical presentation often includes fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, and a dragging abdominal sensation from splenomegaly.

The Reason Statement is Wrong as-

  • BCR-ABL fusion protein is a constitutively active tyrosine kinase that promotes growth factor-independent proliferation and survival of myeloid progenitors.
  • It inhibits apoptosis (not increases it).
  • The splenomegaly is due to massive proliferation of leukemic myeloid cells and extramedullary haematopoiesis, not apoptosis.

choices.text: Eyelid muscles → Neck & Lower jaw → Upper limbs → Abdomen →Lower limbs → Fingers & toes
Eyelid muscles → Neck & Lower jaw → Muscles of face →Muscles of chest → Upper limbs → Abdomen →Lower limbs → Fingers & toes
Fingers and toes → Lower limbs → Abdomen →Upper limbs → Muscles of chest → Muscles of face → Neck & Lower jaw → Eyelid muscles
Neck & Lower jaw → Eyelid muscles → Upper limbs → Abdomen → Lower limbs → Lower jaw → Fingers and toes →Muscles of chest → Muscles of face

questions.text: During the postmortem examination, in what specific sequence does rigor mortis appear according to Nysten's Law?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rigor mortis follows a predictable sequence in appearance as per Nysten's Law/Rule.

The Order of Appearance of Rigor: All muscles of the body, both voluntary and involuntary are affected. It does not start in all muscles simultaneously. It first appears in involuntary muscles; the myocardium becomes rigid in an hour. It begins in the eyelids, neck and lower jaw and passes upwards to the muscles of the face, and downwards to the muscles of the chest, upper limbs, abdomen and lower limbs and lastly in the fingers and toes.

Nysten's Law Sequence:

Appearance: Proximo-distal progression

Myocardium → Eyelid muscles → Neck & Lower jaw → Muscles of face → Muscles of chest → Upper limbs → Abdomen → Lower limbs → Fingers and toes

In individual limbs, it usually progresses from above downwards. Such a sequence is not constant, symmetrical or regular.

In individual limbs, it disappears in the same order in which it has appeared.

Rigor mortis always sets in, increases and decreases gradually.

Rigor mortis, or cadaveric rigidity, is the postmortem stiffening of muscles resulting from ATP depletion, leading to permanent actin-myosin cross-bridging.

Rigor mortis starts, when the ATP becomes 85% of normal (15% depletion), and it reaches its peak when ATP becomes 15% of normal (85% depletion)

  • Shapiro's Rule: All muscles enter rigor mortis simultaneously, but timing of visibility depends on muscle bulk.
  • Rule of 12: On an average, rigor mortis takes about 12 hours to establish, once established, it persists for another 12 hours and disappears in another 12 hours

questions.text: Precontrast renal function tests are not needed before administration of which contrast?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sonovue, an ultrasound contrast agent is safe and do not require precontrast renal function testing.

  • Sonovue is an ultrasound contrast agent composed of gas-filled microbubbles (commonly sulfur hexafluoride, SF6).
  • These microbubbles enhance the ultrasound image by behaving like red blood cells, crossing all capillary beds.
  • This makes contrast-enhanced ultrasonography (CEU) a valuable technique for studying vasculature and tissue blood flow.
  • CEU has been widely applied in cardiology and shows potential in evaluating renal vasculature and hemodynamics in a noninvasive and safe
  • Importantly, unlike iodinated or gadolinium-based contrasts, ultrasound contrast agents do not affect kidney function. Therefore, renal function tests are not needed prior to administration, making Sonovue especially useful in CKD patients.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Iohexol (Option A): An iodinated contrast agent, known to cause contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). Precontrast RFTs are required.

Gadolinium (Option B): An MRI contrast agent, associated with nephrogenic systemic fibrosis (NSF) in patients with poor renal function (low eGFR). Hence, RFTs are needed.

Gastrografin (Option D): A high-osmolar ionic iodinated contrast agent. Its high osmolarity gives it a higher risk of nephrotoxicity, so RFTs are essential before use.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2610015/

choices.text: Lithium-induced hyperthyroidism and transient renal dysfunction
Lithium-induced hypothyroidism, nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, and hyperparathyroidism
Lithium-induced acute interstitial nephritis and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)
Lithium overdose causing CNS toxicity and permanent renal failure

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with bipolar disorder has been on lithium therapy for 8 years. She presents to the outpatient clinic complaining of persistent coarse tremors, polyuria, and recent weight gain.
Her labs reveal:
1. Serum lithium level: 1.1 mEq/L
2. eGFR: 55 mL/min
3. Serum calcium: 11.2 mg/dL
4. TSH: 5.6 μIU/mL
Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the patient's clinical findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient presents with classic chronic lithium toxicity side effects despite therapeutic lithium levels:

  • Coarse tremors and weight gain → Common lithium side effects.
  • Polyuria and polydipsia → Due to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) from lithium blocking aquaporin-2 channels in distal tubules.
  • Mild hypothyroidism (elevated TSH) → Lithium impairs thyroid hormone synthesis; especially women.
  • Hypercalcemia (serum Ca²⁺ 11.2 mg/dL) → Lithium-induced hyperparathyroidism

Lithium has a narrow therapeutic index (0.6-1.5 mEq/L) and chronic use, especially in patients with declining eGFR, predisposes to these complications.

Therapeutic Index:

  • Therapeutic range: 6-1.5 mEq/L
  • Toxicity generally occurs >1.5 mEq/L, but chronic complications can arise even within therapeutic levels.

Side Effects of Lithium:

Monitoring Recommendations:

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Lithium-induced hyperthyroidism and transient renal dysfunction (Option A):
Incorrect - Hypothyroidism, not hyperthyroidism, is a common lithium side effect.

Lithium-induced acute interstitial nephritis and syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) (Option C):
Incorrect - Lithium does not cause SIADH; instead, it causes nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Interstitial nephritis is rare.

Lithium overdose causing CNS toxicity and permanent renal failure (Option D):
Incorrect - This is not a case of acute lithium overdose (toxicity typically >1.5 mEq/L); symptoms are related to chronic use.

choices.text: RR = 0.5; Smoking halves the risk of lung cancer.
RR = 1.5; Smokers have a 1.5 times higher risk of lung cancer.
) RR = 7.0; Smokers have a 7 times higher risk of lung cancer.
RR = 10.5; Smokers have a 10.5 times higher risk of lung cancer.

questions.text:
A prospective cohort study was conducted to investigate the association between smoking and the incidence of lung cancer. The results of the 10-year study are summarized in the table below:

What is the Relative Risk (RR) of developing lung cancer for smokers compared to non-smokers, and how would you interpret this value?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Evaluation of the given Cohort Study:

  • a = Number of exposed individuals (smokers) who develop the disease (lung cancer) = 140
  • b = Number of exposed individuals (smokers) who do not develop the disease = 3860
  • c = Number of non-exposed individuals (non-smokers) who develop the disease = 20
  • d = Number of non-exposed individuals (non-smokers) who do not develop the disease = 5980

Calculation of Incidence Rates:
The key to a cohort study is calculating and comparing the incidence of disease in the exposed vs. non-exposed groups.

  • Incidence in Exposed group (Ie) (Smokers) = a / (a+b)

= 140 / (140 + 3860) = 140 / 4000 = 0.035 (or 35 per 1000)

  • Incidence in Non-exposed group(Ine) (Non-smokers) = c / (c+d)

= 20 / (20 + 5980) = 20 / 6000 ≈ 0.00333 (or 3.33 per 1000)

Calculation of the Relative Risk (RR):

  • Relative Risk (RR) = Incidence in Exposed (Ie) / Incidence in Non-exposed (Ine)
  • RR = 0.035 / 0.00333 ≈ 10.5

Interpretation of RR Value:

  • A Relative Risk of 1.0 indicates no association.
  • A Relative Risk greater than 1.0 indicates a positive association or increased risk.
  • RR = 10.5 means that smokers have 10.5 times the risk (or a 950% increased risk) of developing lung cancer compared to non-smokers over the 10-year study period.
  • This indicates a very strong association between the exposure (smoking) and the outcome (lung cancer).

Explanation for Incorrect options:

RR = 0.5 (Option A): This would imply that smoking is protective, which is contradicted by the data

RR = 1.5 (Option B): This value suggests a weak association, which is a severe underestimate given the calculated data.

RR = 7.0 (Option C): This is an incorrect calculation. It likely results from a wrong formula (e.g., (a/b)/(c/d) or (a/c)/(b/d)).

choices.text: Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are correct, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is correct, but R is incorrect.
A is incorrect, but R is correct.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Amitriptyline overdose can lead to hyperthermia, mydriasis, urinary retention, tachycardia, and confusion.

Reason (R): Amitriptyline blocks muscarinic receptors, inhibits reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, antagonizes alpha-adrenergic and histamine receptors, and blocks sodium channels.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amitriptyline overdose can lead to hyperthermia, mydriasis, urinary retention, tachycardia, and confusion.

Amitriptyline acts by blocking muscarinic receptors, inhibiting reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine, antagonizing alpha-adrenergic and histamine receptors, and blocking sodium channels.

  • Mechanism of Action (MOA):
    • TCAs inhibit reuptake of serotonin and norepinephrine at presynaptic nerve terminals, increasing neurotransmitter concentration in the synaptic cleft.
    • Antagonize histamine receptors → Sedation and weight gain.
    • Alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonism → Orthostatic hypotension and tachycardia.
    • Muscarinic acetylcholine receptor antagonism → Anticholinergic effects such as dry mouth, mydriasis, urinary retention, constipation.
    • Sodium channel blockade → QRS widening & ventricular arrhythmias; QT prolongation is mainly from K⁺ (IKr) blockade.

Key Takeaway:

Tricyclic Antidepressants

  • Inhibits reuptake of serotonin & norepinephrine → ↑ neurotransmitter levels in the synaptic cleft
  • Antagonizes histamine receptors → sedation, weight gain
  • Blocks muscarinic receptors → classic anticholinergic toxidrome
  • Alpha-1 receptor antagonism → postural hypotension, tachycardia
  • Sodium channel blockade → dangerous in overdose → arrhythmias

References:

  • https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557791/

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presented with oral ulcers and extensive skin lesion as shown. He has recently been started on allopurinol. What scoring system is specifically used to predict mortality in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of allopurinol use and the development of skin lesions point to a drug eruption. The drug intake followed by extensive skin detachment (>30% of body surface area), as shown in the image with oral ulcers, points towards the diagnosis of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN). The scoring system used to predict mortality in this condition is the SCORTEN score.

  • TEN is a severe mucocutaneous drug eruption.

SCORTEN (SCORe of Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis)

  • A validated prognostic scoring system for SJS (Stevens-Johnson Syndrome) and TEN (Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis).
  • Predicts the chances of mortality.
  • One point is attributed to each parameter.
  • Higher scores predict higher mortality.
  • Should be calculated on admission and reassessed within the first 5 days (on day 3) of hospitalisation.
  • 7 Parameters to calculate SCORTEN:
    1. Age > 40 years
    2. Presence of malignancy
    3. Heart rate > 120/min
    4. Epidermal detachment > 10% BSA at admission
    5. Serum urea > 10 mmol/L
    6. Serum glucose > 14 mmol/L
    7. Serum bicarbonate < 20 mmol/L
  • In 2022, Re-SCORTEN was proposed, which incorporated the RDW/Hb ratio as an additional prognostic criterion, assigning 2 points when present.
  • Re-SCORTEN Predicted Mortality

Explanation of other options:

PASI score (Option A): Used for assessing severity of psoriasis, not for mortality prediction in TEN.

Breslow thickness (Option B): Refers to the depth of melanoma invasion (0.75 mm is good prognosis while > 0.75mm is bad prognosis), unrelated to TEN prognosis.

Glasgow Coma Scale (Option D): Evaluates level of consciousness in neurological injury, not dermatological conditions.

Key Takeaway:

  • SCORTEN score is the validated tool used to predict mortality in patients with SJS/TEN.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC11767146/

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with resistant hypertension not controlled by three antihypertensive drugs. On examination, BP is 168/104 mmHg in both arms. Abdominal examination reveals a bruit in the right flank. CT angiography of renal vessels reveals a "string-of-beads" appearance of the renal artery. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the finding of "string-of-beads" appearance of renal artery on CT angiography, with a background of resistant hypertension is fibromuscular dysplasia.

  • Fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is a hyperplastic vascular disorder that most often affects medium- and small-sized arteries, though larger vessels can also be involved.
  • Histologically, it is marked by deposition of collagen within the arterial media, producing alternating fibromuscular ridges and thinned segments.
  • The condition is more common in females and typically involves the renal and carotid or vertebral arteries.
  • Clinically, FMD can lead to stenosis, dissection, aneurysm, or thrombosis. It is a cause of secondary hypertension leading to resistant depression.
  • When limb vessels are involved, symptoms resemble those of atherosclerosis, including claudication and rest pain. Angiographically, FMD is classified into two patterns:
    • Multifocal type, which shows the characteristic "string-of-beads" appearance caused by alternating thickened ridges and thinner arterial wall regions. This is shown below
    • Focal type, which presents as either a unifocal stenosis (<1 cm) or a tubular stenosis (≥1 cm).
  • Management includes aspirin to lower the risk of thrombosis, while percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) or surgical reconstruction is reserved for patients with severe, disabling symptoms or threatened limb viability.

Resistant and secondary hypertension

  • Resistant hypertension is defined as the inability to lower systolic or diastolic blood pressure below 130/80 mmHg despite the use of three antihypertensive drugs (ideally including a diuretic), or the requirement of four or more medications to achieve a blood pressure under 130/80 mmHg, which is termed apparent resistant hypertension.
  • Secondary hypertension refers to elevated blood pressure caused by an identifiable anatomical or biochemical abnormality.
  • It represents a minority of hypertension cases but should be considered in patients with new-onset disease or in those with long-standing hypertension showing certain warning features.
  • These include treatment-resistant hypertension, sudden worsening of previously stable blood pressure, target organ damage that appears excessive for the degree of hypertension, or laboratory findings such as unexplained hypokalemia, proteinuria, or left ventricular hypertrophy.

Explanation of other options:

Takayasu arteritis (Option A): Takayasu arteritis is a large-vessel inflammatory disorder that predominantly involves the aortic arch and its major branches. It often leads to absent pulses in the affected arteries, most notably the subclavian artery. Though it can affect renal arteries and lead to hypertension, it is not associated with a string of beads appearance on CT angiography.

Polymyalgia rheumatica (Option B): Polymyalgia rheumatica is marked by pain, stiffness, and aching in the muscles of the neck, shoulders, lower back, hips, and thighs. It usually occurs on its own but can also be associated with giant cell arteritis.

Fibromyalgia (Option D): Fibromyalgia (FM) is a condition marked by persistent, widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. In addition to being primarily a pain disorder, it is frequently accompanied by neuropsychological symptoms such as fatigue, non-restorative sleep, cognitive difficulties, anxiety, and depression.

choices.text: Intravenous thrombolysis with tenecteplase may be used as an alternative to rtPA in eligible patients
Mechanical thrombectomy can be performed up to 24 hours in selected patients with large vessel occlusion
Blood pressure should generally not be lowered acutely unless it exceeds 220/120 mmHg, or >185/110 mmHg if thrombolysis is planned
Long-term dual antiplatelet therapy is recommended for all ischemic stroke patients

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with a sudden onset of right-sided weakness and slurred speech for 6 hours. Non-contrast CT of the brain is shown below. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this patient is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical features and NCCT showing hyperdense MCA sign is suggestive of ischemic stroke, and the false statement regarding the management is long-term dual antiplatelet therapy is recommended for all ischemic stroke patients.

  • Ischemic stroke occurs when there is sudden occlusion of an intracranial artery, resulting in reduced blood flow to the brain tissue it supplies.
  • The extent of injury depends on collateral circulation, vascular anatomy, site of blockage, and systemic blood pressure.
  • Neurons and supporting glial cells can die within minutes if blood flow drops below critical thresholds.
  • A transient ischemic attack (TIA) arises if perfusion is restored before permanent injury occurs.
  • A key concept is the ischemic penumbra, which refers to brain tissue that is functionally impaired but still salvageable if blood flow is rapidly reestablished.
  • Without reperfusion, the penumbra progresses to infarction.

questions.text: Match the congenital heart lesions (Column A) with their characteristic findings (Column B):
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Large VSD (1 → b): Large defects have equalized pressures across ventricles, producing a soft pansystolic murmur even though the lesion is hemodynamically severe.
  • Small VSD (2 → c): A small defect creates a very high pressure gradient, giving a very loud pansystolic murmur, often with a palpable thrill.
  • TOF (3 → d): Hallmark is cyanotic (tet) spells, relieved by squatting which raises systemic vascular resistance and reduces right-to-left shunt.
  • PDA (4 → a): Classically produces a continuous "machinery" murmur with bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure due to runoff into the pulmonary circulation.

Key Takeaway

Murmur loudness does not equal severity - small VSD = very loud murmur, large VSD = softer murmur. PDA gives a continuous machinery murmur with bounding pulses, and TOF is recognized by cyanotic spells relieved by squatting.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a 1-year history of a firm, nontender 6-cm poorly-defined right breast lump without skin changes or lymphadenopathy. Histopathology image of the excised mass is attached. Initial excision leads to recurrence after 1 year, but a second wide excision prevents further recurrence. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The image shows leaf-shaped stromal overgrowth, pointing to the diagnosis of phyllodes tumour.

choices.text: Smoking is a strong risk factor for hypersensitivity pneumonitis
A high CD4/CD8 ratio on BAL strongly suggests hypersensitivity pneumonitis
The mainstay of treatment is lifelong corticosteroid therapy
Histology typically shows loosely formed noncaseating granulomas with interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates

questions.text: A 38-year-old bird breeder presents with progressive breathlessness and a dry cough for 3 months. He reports worsening symptoms after cleaning bird cages. On examination, inspiratory crackles are heard bilaterally. High-resolution CT shows ground-glass opacities with areas of mosaic attenuation and centrilobular nodules. Which of the following statements regarding this patient's condition is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette is hypersensitivity pneumonitis and the true statement regarding it is, histology typically shows loosely formed noncaseating granulomas with interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates

  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP), also known as extrinsic allergic alveolitis, is an inflammatory lung disease caused by repeated inhalation of environmental antigens that trigger an immune-mediated reaction in the alveoli and small airways.
  • Interestingly, smokers appear to have a lower risk of developing HP. (Option A ruled out)

Causative Antigens

  • HP may be triggered by a wide variety of inhaled agents from microbial, animal, plant, and chemical sources.
  • Examples include mouldy hay (farmer's lung), avian droppings and feathers (bird fancier's lung), chemical agents (such as isocyanates in industrial settings), and mycobacterial antigens from contaminated water or metalworking fluids.

Clinical Presentation

HP can manifest as acute, subacute, or chronic forms:

  • Acute HP develops suddenly after antigen exposure, with symptoms such as fever, chills, cough, and dyspnea, which may resolve within days if exposure stops.
  • Subacute HP has a slower onset with recurrent episodes of cough, dyspnea, and systemic malaise, often linked to intermittent exposures.
  • Chronic HP presents with progressive dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss, resembling fibrotic lung disease. Prolonged or unrecognized exposure can lead to irreversible fibrosis.

Diagnosis

Diagnosis requires a combination of exposure history, clinical features, and supportive tests:

  • Imaging: Chest X-ray is often nonspecific, while high-resolution CT may show ground-glass opacities, centrilobular nodules, and signs of air trapping. In fibrotic HP, honeycombing and traction bronchiectasis may develop.
  • Pulmonary Function Tests: May show restrictive, obstructive, or mixed changes. Diffusion impairment is common, especially in advanced disease.
  • Bronchoalveolar Lavage: Lymphocytosis is characteristic, often with a reduced CD4/CD8 ratio but is not characteristic. (Option B ruled out)
  • Histopathology: Lung biopsy may reveal poorly formed noncaseating granulomas and interstitial lymphocytic infiltrates.
  • Serum Testing: IgG antibodies to specific antigens can support the diagnosis but are not fully diagnostic on their own.

Treatment

  • The cornerstone of management is antigen avoidance by identifying and eliminating the source (e.g., removing birds, avoiding mold exposure, improving ventilation). (Option C ruled out)
  • Glucocorticoids may be used in acute or severe cases, typically as prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg/day with gradual taper.
  • In chronic fibrotic HP, corticosteroids may offer limited benefit as structural lung damage may be irreversible.
  • In advanced disease, lung transplantation may be considered.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has fluctuating levels of attention and alertness, recurrent visual hallucinations and Parkinson's features. Many times he claims that his wife is s not the real one as she is replaced by a similar looking lady. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation of the patient is a delusion of misidentification, which is seen in Lewy body dementia.

  • Delusional misidentification syndromes (DMS) are reported in 6% of patients with DLB, indicating a notable prevalence.
  • Patients with DLB may experience Capgras-like delusions, such as believing familiar people have been replaced by impostors.
  • Misidentification in DLB often co-occurs with visual hallucinations and cognitive fluctuations, core features of the disease.
  • These delusions in DLB contribute to behavioural disturbances and potential aggression, highlighting their clinical significance.

Delusional Misidentification Syndromes (DMSs)

  • Definition: DMSs are psychiatric phenomena where a person consistently misidentifies people, places, objects, or events.
  • Association with mental disorders: Often seen in psychotic states such as schizophrenia, but also occur in dementia.
  • Anatomical basis: Frequently linked to organic brain disease, especially lesions in the right frontal lobe and nearby areas.
  • Prevalence in dementia: DMSs are common in dementia
  • Behavioral implications: Patients may display violence or dangerous behavior, which has forensic significance.
  • Capgras syndrome, Fregoli syndrome, and reduplicative paramnesia show similar delusional behaviour.
  • Clinical considerations: Management strategies focus on understanding pathogenesis and reducing risks associated with misidentification behaviors.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC10852797/

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding multiple myeloma are correct?

1. Renal dysfunction in multiple myeloma is commonly precipitated by factors such as dehydration, infection, hypercalcemia, or nephrotoxic drugs in addition to light chain deposition.
2. The most common immunoglobulin subtype produced in multiple myeloma is IgM.
3. Bone marrow biopsy typically shows clonal plasma cell infiltration ≥10%.
4. Novel agents like bortezomib (a proteasome inhibitor), lenalidomide, and dexamethasone form the backbone of therapy.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct regarding multiple myeloma.

  • Multiple myeloma (MM) is a malignant proliferation of plasma cells from a single clone.
  • The disease causes bone pain or fractures, renal failure, anaemia, infections, hypercalcemia, and hyperviscosity-related symptoms.
  • The exact cause is unknown, but risk factors include radiation exposure, farming, and contact with petroleum products.
  • Genetic abnormalities are common: half show hyperdiploidy, while others have translocations involving chromosome 14q32 (e.g., t(11;14), t(4;14), t(14;16)).
  • Patients with active disease often have elevated IL-6 levels, which are linked to a worse prognosis.
  • Incidence rises with age, with a median diagnosis at ~69 years, and is rare under 40.
  • Men are more often affected, and Black populations have about twice the incidence of Whites.

Clinical Features

  • Bone involvement: Lytic lesions that lead to fractures, spinal cord compression, and hypercalcemia.
  • Infections: Hypogammaglobulinemia and immune dysfunction cause recurrent bacterial infections, often pneumonia and pyelonephritis.
  • Renal impairment: Due to light chain nephropathy, hypercalcemia, amyloid, recurrent infections, or drug toxicity.
  • Hematologic issues: Normocytic anemia is common; clotting abnormalities may occur.
  • Other manifestations: Amyloidosis, neuropathy (especially IgM-associated), and systemic complications.

Diagnosis and Investigations

  • In nearly all patients (about 99%), laboratory tests show elevated immunoglobulins in the blood and/or light chains (Bence Jones proteins) in the urine.
  • These monoclonal immunoglobulins are typically identified first as abnormal protein "spikes" on serum or urine electrophoresis.
  • Most cases present with serum Ig levels above 3 g/dL and/or urine Bence Jones protein exceeding 6 mg/dL.
  • IgG is the most frequent monoclonal protein, followed by IgA (Options A, B, and D ruled out)
  • Bone marrow: ≥10% clonal plasma cells.
  • Imaging: Radiography, MRI, PET/CT to detect bone lesions.
  • Other tests: Serum β₂-microglobulin and albumin are used in staging; LDH and cytogenetics provide prognostic information.

Treatment

  • Initial therapy:
    • Immunomodulatory drugs such as lenalidomide, thalidomide, and pomalidomide
    • Proteasome inhibitors such as bortezomib, and carfilzomib)
    • Anti-CD38 antibodies (daratumumab)
  • Transplant candidates: Induction therapy followed by autologous stem cell transplantation, then maintenance (often lenalidomide)
  • Non-transplant candidates: Combination regimens tailored to age/comorbidities.

questions.text: Which anatomic variant is seen in the given CT.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CT scan shows a vessel arising from the arch of aorta and passing posterior to the esophagus, causing a posterior indentation of the esophagus, which is characteristic of an aberrant right subclavian artery.

Anatomical Variant:

  • The right subclavian artery arises aberrantly from the distal aortic arch, usually after the left subclavian artery.
  • It passes posterior to the esophagus, potentially compressing it.

Clinical Significance:

  • Compression of the esophagus may cause dysphagia, termed dysphagia lusoria.
  • Most cases are asymptomatic, but symptomatic patients may require treatment.

Imaging Features:

  • CT Scan: Shows the artery arising from the aortic arch and coursing posterior to the esophagus.
  • Barium Swallow: Shows a deep oblique extrinsic impression on the posterior upper esophagus often superior to the normal left main bronchus impression.

Management:

  • Usually non-operative, using proton pump inhibitors unless symptoms are severe.

Explanation of other options:

Tracheal Diverticulum (Option A): This is an outpouching from the tracheal wall and does not course behind the esophagus; it cannot cause the vascular posterior esophageal indentation seen on the image.

Duplication of Esophagus (Option B): A congenital esophageal duplication appears as a cystic mass adjacent to the esophagus and is not a vascular structure; it does not explain the smooth posterior indentation caused by a vessel.

Right Aortic Arch (Option D): In a right aortic arch, the aortic arch is located on the right side of the thorax, but it does not produce a posterior esophageal indentation by a vessel; this finding is specific to an aberrant right subclavian artery.
