questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents to the OPD with a fever of 38.4 °C. He is an intravenous drug user. Examination shows a new pansystolic murmur at the tricuspid area. Echocardiography reveals a vegetation on the tricuspid valve. Blood cultures grow Staphylococcus aureus in two separate sets. He also has Janeway lesions on his palms. Based on Duke's criteria, which of the following best describes the number of criteria fulfilled in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The number of criteria fulfilled in this patient according to the Modified Duke Criteria for the clinical diagnosis of infective endocarditis is 2 major (positive blood culture with typical organism, and vegetation on ECHO) and 3 minor criteria (IV drug use/predisposing condition, fever > 38 °C and Janeway lesions).

  • Infective endocarditis is characterised by vegetations, which are masses of platelets, fibrin, microorganisms, and inflammatory cells.
  • Bacteria typically attach to damaged endothelium or prosthetic material, where turbulent flow causes injury.
  • Vegetations protect microbes from host defences and antibiotics, leading to persistent infection.

Clinical Features

  • Constitutional symptoms: Fever, chills, weight loss, malaise, and myalgias are common.
  • Cardiac findings: New or changing murmurs, heart failure from valvular damage, perivalvular abscesses, and conduction abnormalities.
  • Vascular manifestations: Arterial emboli, Janeway lesions (shown below), mycotic aneurysms, conjunctival hemorrhages.
  • Immunologic manifestations: Osler's nodes (shown below), Roth spots, glomerulonephritis, positive rheumatoid factor.
  • Neurologic complications: Stroke, brain abscess, hemorrhage, seizures, and meningitis.
  • Renal involvement: Glomerulonephritis and infarctions may cause hematuria and renal dysfunction.

The modified Duke criteria is used for the diagnosis, and the salient features are mentioned below.

questions.text: A research subject is given a glucose load after a period of prolonged starvation. Shortly afterwards, he develops lactic acidosis due to impaired pyruvate oxidation. Supplementation with which vitamin would prevent this complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient develops lactic acidosis after glucose because pyruvate cannot enter the TCA cycle through pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH). PDH requires thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP, from vitamin B1) as a cofactor.

  • Without thiamine, pyruvate is shunted to lactate → lactic acidosis.
  • This is why thiamine must be given before glucose in malnourished/alcoholic patients.

Thiamine functions as TPP in:

  • Pyruvate dehydrogenase (linking glycolysis to TCA cycle)
  • α-Ketoglutarate dehydrogenase (TCA cycle)
  • Branched-chain α-ketoacid dehydrogenase (maple syrup urine disease; thiamine-responsive variant)
  • Transketolase (HMP shunt; most sensitive to deficiency)

Clinical correlations:

  • Dry beriberi: Muscle weakness, peripheral neuropathy.
  • Wet beriberi: Dilated cardiomyopathy → heart failure, pulmonary edema.
  • Mixed beriberi: Combination of neurologic and cardiac features.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy: Confusion, ophthalmoplegia, ataxia; due to thiamine deficiency, especially in alcoholics.
  • Korsakoff psychosis: Untreated Wernicke can progress to irreversible memory loss and confabulation.
  • Always give thiamine before dextrose, otherwise Wernicke's can be precipitated.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Required as FAD in dehydrogenases (eg, succinate dehydrogenase), but PDH specifically requires thiamine as TPP.

Vitamin B3 (Niacin): Provides NAD⁺/NADP⁺ for dehydrogenases; deficiency causes pellagra, but not the block described here.

Vitamin B5 (Pantothenic acid): Part of coenzyme A (CoA); essential for acetyl-CoA formation, but the specific glucose-precipitated lactic acidosis is due to lack of thiamine.

Key Takeaway

Thiamine deficiency blocks PDH → pyruvate accumulates → lactate builds up after glucose. Thiamine must always be given before glucose in malnourished or alcoholic patients.

choices.text: High-dose oral levothyroxine should be started immediately as the treatment of choice
50 mg of parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered every 6 hours
Intravenous liothyronine (T3) is always preferred over thyroxine (T4) due to faster onset of action
Active external rewarming with heating blankets is the cornerstone of therapy for hypothermia in myxedema coma

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department in winter with confusion, hypothermia (34°C), and bradycardia (heart rate 42/min). She has a history of hypothyroidism but discontinued her medication several months ago. On examination, she is drowsy, has periorbital puffiness, dry coarse skin, and delayed relaxation of deep tendon reflexes. Blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg. Laboratory tests show Na⁺ 124 mmol/L, glucose 55 mg/dL, TSH markedly elevated, and free T4 undetectable. Which of the following statements regarding the management of this patient is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the correct statement regarding the management of myxedema coma is 50 mg of parenteral hydrocortisone should be administered every 6 hours

  • Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening manifestation of hypothyroidism, carrying a high mortality rate despite intensive therapy.
  • Mortality is not directly linked to TSH or T₄ levels.
  • It presents with altered mental status, sometimes seizures, alongside typical hypothyroid features.
  • It usually occurs in elderly patients with known or undiagnosed hypothyroidism, often triggered by respiratory-depressing drugs (sedatives, anesthetics, antidepressants), pneumonia, myocardial infarction, stroke, gastrointestinal bleeding, or sepsis.
  • Cold exposure, hypoventilation (causing hypoxia and hypercapnia), hypoglycemia, and dilutional hyponatremia also contribute.

Clinical Features:

  • Hypothermia (as low as 23°C)
  • Reduced consciousness
  • Signs of severe hypothyroidism
  • Metabolic disturbances like hyponatremia and hypoglycemia

Treatment:

  • Thyroid Hormone Replacement:
    • IV levothyroxine (LT4) (200-400 µg as a loading dose, followed by 1.6 µg/kg/day orally or 25% less if IV). (Option A ruled out)
    • If IV levothyroxine is unavailable, the same loading dose can be administered through a nasogastric tube, though absorption may be reduced in myxedema.
    • Since the conversion of T₄ to T₃ is impaired in myxedema coma, adding liothyronine (T₃) either intravenously or via nasogastric tube to LT₄ therapy is considered. However, excessive T₃ carries a risk of inducing arrhythmias. (Option C ruled out)
  • Supportive Therapy:
    • External warming only if <30°C (to avoid cardiovascular collapse), with space blankets to prevent further heat loss. (Option D ruled out)
    • IV hydrocortisone (50 mg every 6h) is to be administered. It is suggested that levothyroxine can enhance cortisol breakdown, and hypothyroidism may conceal an existing adrenal insufficiency.
    • Treat precipitating factors, often with broad-spectrum antibiotics until infection is excluded.
    • Ventilatory support and regular arterial blood gas monitoring in the first 48h.
    • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose for severe hyponatremia/hypoglycemia (hypotonic fluids avoided).

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK545193/

questions.text: A 45-year-old returns from the USA after a prolonged flight and develops acute shortness of breath with low oxygen saturation. She has a previous history of deep-vein thrombosis. A CT pulmonary angiogram reveals a large saddle-shaped thrombus in the main pulmonary artery. What is the expected ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) ratio in the affected lung region?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Acute pulmonary embolism occludes perfusion (↓Q) to the involved acini while ventilation (V) to those units is preserved → physiologic dead space; mathematically V/Q → ∞.
  • Resultant hypoxemia stems from increased overall V/Q heterogeneity and shunt-like perfusion to non-occluded regions; patients hyperventilate, so PaCO₂ often falls (respiratory alkalosis: pH 7.47, PaCO₂ 32).
  • Classic triad in PE physiology at the bedside: tachypnea, respiratory alkalosis, elevated A-a gradient (consistent with PaO₂ 62 on room air).

Explanations of the Other Options:

V/Q = 1 (Option A): This indicates normal ventilation and perfusion.

V/Q = 0.3 (Option B): This suggests low V/Q (ventilation is reduced relative to perfusion, as in airway obstruction or asthma).

V/Q → 0 (Option C): Describes shunt (ventilatory failure with intact perfusion), e.g., lobar pneumonia/atelectasis-not the occlusive vascular pattern of PE.

Key takeaways:

  • PE → dead-space effect (V/Q → ∞) in affected units, overall hypoxemia with low/normal PaCO₂ from hyperventilation.
  • Shunt (V/Q → 0) is the opposite pattern (alveolar filling/collapse), not primary in PE.

choices.text: Aphonia; vocal cord in cadaveric position
Weak voice and mild aspiration; bowing of affected vocal cord
Severe aspiration without voice change; fully mobile vocal cords
Asymptomatic; posterior commissure deviation to normal side

questions.text: The most likely symptom and laryngeal examination finding in a case of unilateral superior laryngeal nerve palsy are given as follows. Which is the correct combination?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The superior laryngeal nerve is closely located to the superior pole of the thyroid. Hence, it can be damaged during thyroid surgery.

  • Branches of SLN:
    • External laryngeal nerve: Supplies the cricothyroid muscle, the main tensor of the vocal cords. Any damage leads to bowed-down (lax) vocal cords and a weak voice.
    • Internal laryngeal nerve: Supplies the supraglottis and prevents aspiration.

Injury to the External Branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve (EBSLN):

  • Intraoperative identification:
    • Up to 20% of EBSLN may not be visually identifiable, making injury a risk during thyroid or neck surgery.
    • Intraoperative nerve monitoring (IONM) is very helpful for locating and protecting the nerve.
    • Careful superior pole dissection and ligating vessels on the gland itself reduces the risk of nerve injury.
    • Knowing the anatomical variations of the EBSLN is critical for safe surgical dissection.
  • Postoperative assessment:
    • Surgeons should ask about voice strength, pitch, and fatigue after surgery.
    • Any changes may indicate EBSLN injury.
    • Suspected cases require formal voice evaluation using videostroboscopy and possibly speech therapy.

Aphonia; vocal cord in cadaveric position (Option A): This is seen in bilateral adductor palsy of vocal cord.

Severe aspiration without voice change; fully mobile vocal cords (Option C): This is incorrect since severe aspiration won't be seen in this case, as one side is normal.

Asymptomatic; posterior commissure deviation to normal side (Option D): This is not a possibility since the patient won't be asymptomatic but will have a weak voice. Also, in unilateral SLN palsy, the anterior commissure of the vocal cord is deviated to the normal side.

questions.text: A 51-year-old woman tests positive for hepatitis A antibody. Her initial serum AST is 275 U/L, and ALT is 310 U/L. One month later, her liver enzymes have normalized. Which phase of the cell cycle best describes the hepatocytes at this point?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hepatocytes are quiescent (stable) cells that normally reside in G0, a metabolically active but non-dividing phase.
  • During acute hepatitis, hepatocyte injury and necrosis occur, causing elevations in AST and ALT.
  • Surviving hepatocytes may re-enter the cell cycle (G1 → S → G2 → M) to proliferate and restore liver mass.
  • After regeneration is complete and normal liver architecture is restored, hepatocytes return to G0, resuming a quiescent state.

Cell Cycle Phases

  • G0: Resting/quiescent phase; metabolically active but non-dividing.
  • G1: Cell growth, preparation for DNA synthesis. (Option B ruled out)
  • S: DNA replication phase. (Option C ruled out)
  • G2: Preparation for mitosis.
  • M: Mitosis (cell division). (Option D ruled out)

Key Regulators of the Cell Cycle:

p53 (Guardian of the Genome):

  • Located on chromosome 17p13, 53 kDa protein.
  • Controls G1 → S and G2 → M
  • DNA damage → p53 activation →
    • Upregulates p21 → inhibits CDKs → cell cycle arrest
    • Upregulates GADD45 → DNA repair
    • If repair fails → BAX activation → apoptosis
  • Mutated p53 → common in sporadic cancers, therapy-resistant, poor prognosis.
  • Associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • MDM2 negatively regulates p53.

Retinoblastoma (Rb) Gene (Governor of the Cell Cycle):

  • Located on chromosome 13q14.
  • Rb binds E2F transcription factor, keeping the cell inactive.
  • Cyclin D/CDK4 phosphorylates Rb → releases E2F → G1 → S progression.
  • Dephosphorylated Rb → cell cycle stop.
  • Cyclin D/CDK4 initiates phosphorylation; Cyclin E/CDK2 continues G1 → S progression.

Cyclins and CDKs:

  • Cyclin D/CDK4: G1-S initiation
  • Cyclin E/CDK2: Late G1 → S
  • Cyclin A/CDK2: S → G2
  • Cyclin B/CDK1: G2 → M

CDK Inhibitors:

  • Cip/Kip family (CDKN1): p21, p27, p57 → inhibit CDK activity
  • INK4/ARF family (CDKN2): p14, p15, p16, p17, p18
    • p14 → stabilizes p53 by inhibiting MDM2
    • p16 → inhibits Cyclin D/CDK4, surrogate marker for HPV infection

Key Takeaway:

  • Radiation targets M phase, mostly affecting mitotically active cells.
  • G1-S checkpoint: Mainly regulated by p53.
  • G2-M checkpoint: Controlled by p53, BRCA, ATM.
  • Rb gene: Master switch for cell cycle; phosphorylation state dictates activity.

Hepatocytes and other stable cells are normally in G0, but can reenter the cycle after injury.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with recurrent painless rectal bleeding. Colonoscopic biopsy reveals mucosa with markedly dilated glands and an inflammatory stroma. His father has a history of pulmonary arteriovenous malformations. This overlap of gastrointestinal pathology with vascular malformations is most likely due to mutation in which gene?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child’s presentation with recurrent painless rectal bleeding and histopathology showing cystically dilated glands with inflamed stroma is characteristic of Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (JPS). The overlap of gastrointestinal pathology with vascular malformations is due to mutations in SMAD4 or BMPR1A.

  • Juvenile Polyposis Syndrome (JPS):
    • Seen in children (<5 years) with painless rectal bleeding, anemia, diarrhea, digital clubbing.
    • Histology: Cystically dilated glands with boot-shaped crypts, inflammatory stroma.
    • Genetics: Mutations in SMAD4 or BMPR1A.
  • Importantly, SMAD4 mutations can cause the JPS-HHT overlap syndrome, where patients have:
    • Juvenile GI polyps (bleeding, anemia).
    • Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT): pulmonary/hepatic/cerebral AV malformations.
  • In this case: Child with juvenile polyps + family history of pulmonary AVMs → SMAD4 mutation.

Explanation of Other Options:

ENG (Option A):

  • ENG (Endoglin) mutations cause Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT) type 1.
  • Presents with recurrent epistaxis, mucocutaneous telangiectasia, visceral AVMs (lung, liver, brain).
  • Does not cause hamartomatous GI polyps with dilated glands.

ACVRL1 (Option B):

  • ACVRL1 (ALK1) mutations cause HHT type 2.
  • Clinical picture similar to ENG mutations, without association with juvenile polyps.

BMPR2 (Option D):

  • Mutation in BMPR2 is the most common cause of familial pulmonary arterial hypertension (FPAH).

Not associated with colonic hamartomatous polyps.

questions.text:
During a routine physical exam, a physician asks the patient to fold his arms across the chest and bend forward. This maneuver increases the size of the triangle of auscultation, allowing clearer auscultation of posterior lung sounds.
Which muscle forms the medial boundary of this triangle?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The triangle of auscultation enlarges when the scapula is protracted (arms crossed + bending forward).
  • Its medial boundary is the trapezius, a superficial back muscle extending from the occiput and nuchal ligament to the scapular spine.
  • This is the landmark that forms the medial margin of the auscultatory window.

Triangle of Auscultation

  • Anatomical Boundaries:
    • Inferior: Superior border of latissimus dorsi (Option A)
    • Medial: Lateral edge of trapezius (Option B)
    • Lateral: Medial border of scapula
    • Floor: Ribs, intercostal muscles, and sometimes the rhomboid major (forms the floor, not the border) (Option D)
  • Lies at the inferior angle of the scapula
  • Thinness of structures in the triangle allows better assessment of underlying thoracic structures and facilitates surgical procedures
  • Clinical Applications:
    • Scapular tumor excision
    • Thoracotomy
    • Pleurectomy
    • Rhomboid intercostal nerve block

Explanation to the other option:

Serratus anterior (Option C): Not related to this triangle.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539834/#

choices.text: Day 2-5 FSH, LH, and estradiol to assess ovarian reserve
A hysterosalpingography (HSG) to assess tubal patency
A semen analysis for the male partner
Mid-luteal phase serum progesterone to confirm ovulation

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with primary infertility for 2 years. She has regular 28-day cycles and no history of dysmenorrhea. Her husband's history is unremarkable. On examination, the woman's BMI is 32 kg/m². Which of the following is the single most appropriate initial investigation in the evaluation of this couple?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The male factor contributes to 40-50% of infertility cases, making semen analysis the first and most essential test in infertility evaluation, as it is non-invasive, inexpensive, and provides crucial information before proceeding to female investigations.
  • Basic investigation for infertility:
    • Semen analysis
    • Test for ovulation: S.progesterone levels on day 22 of the cycle
    • Test for tubal patency by hysterosalpingography done between day 7 and day 10.
  • Semen Analysis - Sample Collection:
    • Collected after 2-7 days of abstinence (optimum ~3 days).
    • Samples should reach the laboratory within 1 hour of collection.
  • Analysis is performed on liquefied semen, with a normal liquefaction time of 20-30 minutes.
  • The most important parameter: morphology of sperm>motility>concentration.

Explanation of other options:

Day 2-5 FSH, LH, and estradiol to assess ovarian reserve (Option A): Part of the ovarian reserve testing in the female workup, but not the first step.

A hysterosalpingography (HSG) to assess tubal patency (OptionB): Used to assess tubal patency between day 7 and day 10, indicated later in the workup.

Mid-luteal phase serum progesterone to confirm ovulation (Option D): Serum Progesterone levels on day 22 of the cycle used to confirm ovulation, but a history of regular cycles is a good clinical indicator of ovulation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Semen analysis is the first and most important test in an infertility workup.
  • Always rule out male factor early due to its high prevalence.

choices.text: Early diastolic "rapid-inflow" phase with the third heart sound

questions.text: A 59-year-old man with a prior myocardial infarction undergoes left-heart catheterisation during a pre-transplant evaluation. When assessing left-ventricular pressure across the cardiac cycle, during which phase would you expect the maximum left-ventricular pressure to be recorded?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During ventricular ejection, the left ventricle has already generated enough pressure to open the aortic valve. Continued contraction raises ventricular pressure to its absolute peak, slightly higher than aortic pressure, ensuring forward flow into the systemic circulation. Wiggers diagrams consistently show this as the highest point of the left-ventricular pressure curve.

Explanation for other options:

Late atrial systole (Option A): In this phase, the atria contract at the very end of diastole to deliver a final "boost" of blood into the ventricle. Although this slightly elevates ventricular end-diastolic pressure, it remains far below systolic peak-typically around 10 mm Hg versus more than 120 mm Hg in a normal left ventricle.

Early diastolic rapid-inflow phase (with S3) (Option B): Right after the mitral valve opens, blood passively rushes from the atrium to the ventricle, sometimes creating a third heart sound. Ventricular pressure at this point is low and still falling or just beginning to rise slightly as the ventricle fills, so it cannot represent the maximal systolic pressure.

Isovolumetric contraction( Option C): This is the brief period after the mitral valve closes but before the aortic valve opens. The ventricle builds pressure rapidly but has not yet reached the peak because ejection has not begun.

Key Takeaway:

Phases of the Cardiac Cycle

Diastole

  • Protodiastole: Just before the semilunar valves close, the ventricles have already begun to relax. Blood continues to move into the aorta and pulmonary artery for a short time, carried forward by its own momentum even though the ventricular muscle is no longer contracting.
  • Isovolumetric Relaxation: After the semilunar valves shut, both the atrioventricular (AV) and semilunar valves remain closed. The ventricular walls keep relaxing, but the volume of the chambers stays constant until ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure.
  • Ventricular Filling: Once ventricular pressure drops beneath atrial pressure, the AV valves open and blood flows passively into the ventricles.
  • Atrial Systole: Near the end of diastole, the atria contract and push an extra volume of blood into the ventricles. This contraction produces the 'a wave in the jugular venous pulse.

Systole

  • Isovolumetric Contraction: Ventricular muscle begins to contract while both sets of valves are closed. Pressure rises sharply without a change in ventricular volume, corresponding to the 'c' wave of the jugular venous pulse.
  • Ventricular Ejection: When ventricular pressure exceeds the pressure in the aorta and pulmonary artery, the semilunar valves open and blood is expelled. Peak pressures typically reach about 120 mm Hg in the left ventricle and 25 mm Hg in the right ventricle.

questions.text: A patient presents to her GP with recurrent nosebleeds and also complains of facial fullness and facial pain. Over the past 2 months she has developed progressive shortness of breath and on one occasion she coughed up some blood. On looking through the patient notes, the GP notices that the patient was recently admitted to hospital with hematuria and proteinuria. What would be the most appropriate test to perform?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The case described here (ENT symptoms, pulmonary involvement, and renal disease) fits best with Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's granulomatosis). The most appropriate test is therefore ANCA (usually C-ANCA/PR3).

  • The most common manifestation of Wegener's granulomatosis is sinusitis, which is indicated by facial swelling and pain in the given scenario.
  • It can be associated with septal perforation leading to saddle-nose deformity.

Wegener's granulomatosis

  • Definition: Systemic necrotizing vasculitis with granulomatous inflammation affecting small-medium vessels.
  • Triad: Classically involves upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys.
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation of the respiratory tract + necrotizing vasculitis + focal/proliferative glomerulonephritis.
  • Diagnosis: Strong association with C-ANCA (anti-PR3); P-ANCA (anti-MPO) may also be seen in some cases.
  • Clinical course: Can present with chronic sinusitis, nasal crusting, septal perforation, hematuria/proteinuria, pulmonary nodules, or alveolar hemorrhage.

General approach to suspected vasculitis:

  • Diagnosis requires integration of clinical, laboratory, and biopsy information.
  • ANCA (Antineutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibodies) testing plays a key role in identifying ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV).
  • Detected by indirect immunofluorescence (IIF) on human neutrophils.

Types of ANCA patterns

  • C-ANCA (Cytoplasmic ANCA)
    • Fluorescence pattern: Cytoplasmic staining.
    • Target antigen: Proteinase-3 (PR3).
    • Associated with:
      • Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA, formerly Wegener's).
  • P-ANCA (Perinuclear ANCA)
    • Fluorescence pattern: Perinuclear staining.
    • Target antigen: Myeloperoxidase (MPO).
    • Associated with:
      • Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA).
      • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.
      • Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA, Churg-Strauss).
  • Atypical ANCA patterns
    • Usually due to other antigens.
    • Rarely associated with systemic vasculitis.

Explanation of other options

ACE levels (Option A): Elevated in sarcoidosis, not in a case with renal, pulmonary, and ENT involvement → not appropriate here.

Anti-GBM antibodies (Option B): Useful for diagnosing Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary hemorrhage + glomerulonephritis), but ENT involvement is absent in Goodpasture's → less likely here.

Factor VIII levels (Option D): Measured in hemophilia and bleeding disorders, not related to systemic vasculitis → not relevant.

choices.text: No prophylaxis needed at this stage
Start trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole prophylaxis against toxoplasma gondii

questions.text: A 34-year-old man with HIV presents for routine follow-up. His most recent CD4 count is 90 cells/µL, and his HIV RNA viral load is detectable. He has no prior opportunistic infections. He is on antiretroviral therapy but has not yet achieved immune reconstitution. According to current guidelines, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the most appropriate next step in the management of this retropositive patient with CD4 count of 90 cells/µL and detectable viral load is to start trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole prophylaxis against PCP.

Patients with HIV are at risk of acquiring various opportunistic infections. Few of them along with the corresponding CD4 counts when the risk of acquiring them are highest are given below.

PCP Prophylaxis in HIV patients

Indications

  • CD4 count <100-200/µL with detectable HIV RNA (Option C ruled out)
  • CD4 count <100/µL regardless of viral load
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • History of prior PCP
  • Prophylaxis may be discontinued if CD4 count rises to >200/µL for at least 3 months

Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (TMP-SMX) is the first choice. Alternative drugs that can be used include dapsone, atovaquone, and aerolised pentamidine.

Explanations of other options:

Begin azithromycin prophylaxis against MAC (Option A): Prophylaxis against Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is recommended in patients with HIV whose CD4+ T cell count falls below 50/µL, unless antiretroviral therapy (ART) is started immediately and expected to achieve viral suppression. It is also indicated in individuals with a history of disseminated MAC infection. Prophylaxis can be discontinued once fully suppressive ART is in place.


Start trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole prophylaxis against toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Prophylaxis against Toxoplasma gondii is indicated in HIV patients who are IgG positive for T. gondii and have a CD4+ T cell count below 100/µL, or in those with a prior episode of toxoplasmic encephalitis and a CD4+ T cell count below 200/µL.

Reference:

https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/rr5804a1.htm

questions.text: During an experiment on brain function, a neuroscientist created a bilateral lesion in a specific region of the brain. After the procedure, the animal became strikingly apathetic and refused both food and water, eventually showing signs of starvation. Damage to which structure best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The lateral hypothalamus plays a crucial role in initiating feeding and drinking behaviours and in maintaining overall arousal and activity. When this region is destroyed on both sides, animals lose their drive to eat and drink and often become profoundly passive, sometimes starving despite the availability of food. This classic effect is summarised by the phrase "lateral lesion leads to loss of appetite."

Explanation of other options:

Ventromedial hypothalamus (Option A): This nucleus serves as a satiety centre, signalling fullness and helping to inhibit feeding. A lesion here causes hyperphagia and obesity, the opposite of the lack of eating seen in this experiment.

Anterior hypothalamus (Option B): The anterior hypothalamus primarily regulates body temperature through heat dissipation and also participates in parasympathetic control. Damage here causes problems with thermoregulation, not a refusal to eat or drink.

Olfactory cortex (Option D): Located in the temporal lobe, this region is central to the perception of smell. Lesions may impair olfaction but do not directly alter hunger or thirst drives.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents with chronic fatigue and delayed puberty. Examination shows poor secondary sexual characteristics and hepatosplenomegaly. CBC: Hb 9.1 g/dL, Hct 26.7%, MCV 66 μm³, thrombocytopenia, leukopenia. Peripheral smear is given below. Labs: glucose 144 mg/dL, TSH 6.2 mU/mL, ferritin 679 ng/mL. A mutation in which gene is most likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this clinical scenario, the CBC finding of MCV 66 μm³ with Hb 9.1 g/dL → suggests thalassemia or iron-deficiency (Microcytic Anaemia).

Elevated Ferritin (679 ng/mL)- indicates Iron overload and ineffective erythropoiesis. On Peripheral smear, it shows target cells (central dark spot surrounded by a pale ring and then outer rim of Hb), Aniso-poikilocytosis (variation in size and shape), hypochromia (central pallor), and nucleated red cells (due to extramedullary haematopoiesis) → classic for thalassemia major/intermedia


Systemic features of Hepatosplenomegaly: from extramedullary haematopoiesis and splenic sequestration and Delayed puberty / endocrine dysfunction: due to iron overload → damage to pituitary, gonads, thyroid, pancreas (diabetes) also suggest of Thalassemia.

Pathogenesis

  • β-Thalassemia results from mutations in the β-globin gene (HBB) on chromosome 11.
  • Defect: decreased or absent β-globin synthesis → unpaired α-globin chains accumulate → damage erythroid precursors → ineffective erythropoiesis and peripheral haemolysis.
  • Compensatory increase: HbA2(α2δ2) and HbF (α2γ2).
  • Iron overload: due to ↑ intestinal absorption (low hepcidin) + repeated transfusions → secondary hemochromatosis → endocrine failure, diabetes, hypothyroidism, hypogonadism, cardiomyopathy.

Explanation Of Other Options:

choices.text: Active redistribution of blood due to residual myocardial contractility
Gravitational settling of blood in dependent capillaries and venules after cessation of circulation
Chemical transformation of subcutaneous fat into a waxy substance under moist conditions
Haemoglobin breakdown by putrefactive bacterial enzymes forming coloured pigments and gases

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examines a dead body with purplish-red patches over the dependent parts. These patches do not blanch on pressure and are consistent with an early postmortem change. What is the primary mechanism responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Livor mortis (Postmortem hypostasis) is the purplish-red discoloration that appears in the dependent areas of the body after death.
  • Mechanism: Once circulation ceases, gravity pulls blood into dependent venous channels and capillaries, leading to discoloration which is visible through the skin.
  • Importantly, it is a passive process (no cardiac activity involved), distinguishing it from other early postmortem changes.

Livor mortis (also called postmortem staining, subcutaneous hypostasis, cadaveric lividity, suggillation, cogitation, vibices, or darkening of death) refers to the bluish or purplish-red discoloration of the skin caused by gravitational settling of blood in the toneless capillaries and venules of the dependent regions of the body after death.

  • Location: Superficial layers of the dermis
  • Mechanism: Blood in capillaries and venules stagnates and sinks in dependent parts due to gravity, causing bluish-purple discoloration from deoxyhaemoglobin.
  • Onset: It is absent in the first 30 minutes. In 30 minutes to 2 hours, mottled patches appear. The patches coalesce each other in 2 to 4 hours and well developed in about 4 hours. The hypostasis gets fixed in 6 to 12 hours.
    • Test by applying thumb pressure → Blanching indicates livor mortis is not fixed
  • Primary vs. Secondary Lividity:
    • Primary lividity occurs when livor mortis reaches maximum intensity (6–12 hours after death)
    • Secondary lividity occurs if the position of the body is changed before fixation.
  • Persistence: Staining remains until putrefaction begins
  • Distribution Patterns:
    • Supine → Back of neck, back, flanks (except areas under pressure)
    • Prone → Anterior body parts
    • Side → Dependent side
    • Head Down → Blackened face and neck
    • Vertical Suspension → Legs and hands (glove and stocking appearance), genitalia
    • Drowning → Face, upper chest, hands, lower arms, feet, and calves
  • Absent In: Bodies in running water, excessive blood loss, severe anaemia.
  • Medicolegal Significance:
    • Estimation of time of death
    • Position of the body at the time of death
    • Indicates if the body was moved after death
    • Color changes and distribution pattern may suggest cause of death

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Active redistribution of blood due to residual myocardial contractility (Option A): Incorrect. Residual heart contractions end within minutes of death; lividity is purely passive gravitational pooling, not active redistribution.

Chemical transformation of subcutaneous fat (Option C): Incorrect. This describes adipocere formation, a late postmortem change occurring in moist environments, not an early external change like lividity.

Hemoglobin breakdown by bacterial enzymes (Option D): Incorrect. This is the mechanism of putrefaction/marbling, which occurs later, not the mechanism of livor mortis.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK539741/

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of dilated cardiomyopathy presents for follow-up. He is comfortable at rest and can perform routine daily activities such as dressing and eating without difficulty. However, he notices mild shortness of breath and fatigue when climbing stairs, walking briskly, or carrying groceries. According to the NYHA classification, which class best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

NYHA class II best fits this patients symptoms.

  • Heart failure (HF) represents the final pathway of many cardiovascular disorders, including hypertension, coronary artery disease, and valvular disease.
  • It is defined as a clinical syndrome resulting from structural or functional cardiac abnormalities that impair ventricular filling or ejection.
  • Key symptoms include breathlessness, fatigue, and ankle swelling, while signs may include elevated jugular venous pressure, pulmonary rales, and peripheral edema.

Terminology

  • Congestive heart failure refers broadly to symptomatic HF with fluid overload.
  • Chronic heart failure describes long-standing disease, often treated with medications and devices, and prone to worsening episodes.
  • Acute heart failure indicates rapid onset or deterioration of symptoms, either as a worsening of chronic HF or as new-onset disease (e.g., acute coronary syndrome, valve dysfunction, hypertensive emergency).
  • Acute pulmonary edema is a severe presentation with sudden pulmonary congestion and elevated left heart filling pressures.

Phenotypes Based on Ejection Fraction

  • HFrEF (Heart failure with reduced EF): Reduced EF (≤40%).
  • HFpEF (Heart failure with preserved EF): Preserved EF (≥50%).
  • HFmrEF (Heart failure with mildly reduced EF): Mildly reduced EF (41-49%).

Pathophysiology

Heart failure is progressive, often beginning with an initial insult (e.g., myocardial infarction, pressure overload, or genetic disease) that leads to structural and functional remodelling.

  • Ventricular remodelling:
    • Concentric hypertrophy occurs with pressure overload (e.g., hypertension, aortic stenosis).
    • Eccentric hypertrophy results from volume overload (e.g., valvular regurgitation).
    • Remodelling is driven by myocyte hypertrophy, interstitial fibrosis, changes in calcium handling, cytoskeletal protein abnormalities, re-expression of fetal genes, and cell death (apoptosis/necrosis).
  • HFpEF is less understood, traditionally attributed to diastolic dysfunction but now recognized to involve vascular stiffness, renal dysfunction, inflammation, and metabolic changes.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male comes to your clinic with complains of frequent checking of doors even when they are locked. He is distressed about this fact. Consider the following statements regarding his case:

1. His condition is considered as ego dystonic
2. SSRI is very useful
3. Risperidone may be used in SSRI resistant cases to augment the response
4.Systemic desensitisation is the best behaviour therapy.

Which of the above are correct statements?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Systemic desensitisation is not used for the management of OCD, instead, exposure and response prevention therapy is used.

Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)

  • Core features: Intrusive thoughts (obsessions) and repetitive behaviors or mental acts (compulsions).
  • Symptoms: May include rituals, preoccupations, or both.
  • Distress and interference: Symptoms cause significant distress and interfere with:
    • Daily routine
    • Work or occupational functioning
    • Social activities and relationships
  • Definition of obsession: A recurrent and intrusive thought, feeling, or impulse that the person finds distressing.
  • Obsessions and compulsions in OCD are ego-dystonic, meaning the patient recognizes them as unwanted and distressing (e.g., distress about repeated door checking). (Statement 1)

Management of OCD

  1. Pharmacotherapy
    • First-line drugs: SSRIs (fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline, citalopram) and clomipramine.
    • Onset of effect: 4-6 weeks; maximal benefit usually 8-16 weeks.
    • Combination therapy: Best outcomes when SSRIs or clomipramine are combined with behavioral therapy.
    • Risperidone, an atypical antipsychotic, is used to augment SSRI therapy in treatment-resistant OCD, helping reduce persistent obsessive-compulsive symptoms.
    • Alternative/adjunctive drugs: Valproate, lithium, carbamazepine, venlafaxine, MAOIs, buspirone, clonazepam, atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone) for refractory cases.
  2. Behavioral Therapy
    • Most effective approach: Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP).
    • Other techniques: Desensitization, thought stopping, flooding, implosion therapy, aversive conditioning.
    • Can be done outpatient or inpatient; effects often longer-lasting than drugs alone.
  3. Psychotherapy / Insight-oriented therapy
    • Limited evidence but may help patients understand psychological triggers and improve treatment compliance.
    • Useful for obsessive-compulsive personality traits.
  4. Supportive Measures
    • Hospitalization in severe cases to reduce stress and manage symptoms.
    • Family involvement: emotional support, guidance on handling symptoms, reassurance.

choices.text: They provide superior mucosal immunity in the gut, preventing reinfection.
They have no risk of causing vaccine-associated disease, making them safer for immunocompromised hosts.
They typically provide lifelong immunity after a single dose.
They are more effective at inducing a cytotoxic T-cell response compared to live attenuated vaccines.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to a PHC for vaccination. The child is immunocompromised due to a congenital condition. The MO decides to administer the Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) instead of the Oral Polio Vaccine (OPV). Which of the following is the most accurate advantage of using killed (inactivated) vaccines like IPV in such a scenario?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • In this case Inactivated Polio Vaccine (IPV) is chosen for administration due to its safety in Immunocompromised Individuals
  • Because the pathogen cannot replicate, it cannot revert to a virulent form and cannot cause the disease it is meant to prevent.
  • This makes killed vaccines like IPV, Inactivated Influenza vaccine, and Hepatitis A vaccine the safest choice for individuals with compromised immune systems (eg., congenital immunodeficiency, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy patients), for whom live vaccines are often contraindicated.

Fundamental Property of Killed Vaccines:

  • Killed vaccines are manufactured by inactivating the pathogen (virus or bacterium) using methods like heat, chemicals (e.g., formaldehyde), or radiation.
  • This process destroys the replicative ability of the pathogen while preserving its immunogenicity (the ability to stimulate an immune response).

Explanation for Incorrect options:

They provide superior mucosal immunity in the gut, preventing reinfection (Option A):

  • This is a key advantage of live attenuated vaccines (like OPV).
  • They mimic natural infection by replicating at the portal of entry (e.g., the gut for OPV), producing strong secretory IgA immunity.
  • Killed vaccines are generally poor inducers of mucosal immunity and primarily produce a systemic IgG response.

They typically provide lifelong immunity after a single dose (Option C):

  • This statement is false.
  • Killed vaccines often produce a weaker immune response that is primarily humoral (antibody-mediated) and may not generate long-lasting memory.
  • They typically require multiple doses (primary series and boosters) to achieve and maintain protective immunity.
  • Live vaccines often provide longer-lasting immunity.

They are more effective at inducing a cytotoxic T-cell response compared to live attenuated vaccines (Option D):

  • Cytotoxic T-cell (CD8+) responses are best induced by antigens synthesized within host cells, as occurs with live attenuated vaccines or viral vector vaccines.
  • Killed vaccines are processed externally and presented on MHC Class II molecules, primarily stimulating helper T-cells (CD4+) and antibody production, not a strong CD8+ response.
    • </

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Digitalis can lead to bradycardia by reducing AV nodal conduction.

Reason (R): Digitalis activates muscarinic M₂ receptors, leading to decreased cyclic AMP and reduced Ca²⁺ influx.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Assertion (A) is TRUE: Digitalis does decrease AV nodal conduction velocity, which can result in bradycardia (slowing of heart rate), particularly beneficial in atrial fibrillation/flutter by reducing the number of impulses reaching the ventricles.

Reason (R) is FALSE:The mechanism of Digitalis is not through muscarinic M₂ receptors. That is the mechanism of vagal (parasympathetic) stimulation, not Digitalis.

Digitalis inhibits the Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase, which indirectly leads to increased intracellular Ca²⁺ by altering Na⁺/Ca²⁺ exchange. This increases contractility and slows AV conduction-but not through G-protein-coupled M₂ receptor activation or decreased cAMP.

Key takeaway:

Digitalis-induced bradycardia is due to its direct inhibition of the Na⁺/K⁺ -ATPase pump, which enhances vagal tone and slows AV nodal conduction - not by activating muscarinic M₂ receptors or reducing cAMP.

  • Digitalis inhibits Na⁺/K⁺-ATPase
  • This leads to increased intracellular Na⁺ and there will be decreased Na⁺/Ca²⁺ exchange which will increase intracellular Ca²⁺ and thereby increasing contractility (positive inotropy)
  • They Also enhances vagal (parasympathetic) tone thereby decreasing AV nodal conduction which leads to bradycardia

The direct M₂ receptor action mechanism is for acetylcholine,which is not present for digitalis.

choices.text: Oral rehydration solution, 50-100 mL after each loose stool, at home with continued feeding
Oral rehydration solution, 75 mL/kg over 4 hours under supervision at a health facility
Intravenous Ringer Lactate, 100 mL/kg over 6 hours in divided doses
Intravenous Normal Saline, 20 mL/kg bolus, repeated if shock persists

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant presents with watery diarrhoea for 2 days, passing 8-10 stools/day. On examination, the child has sunken eyes, is thirsty and drinks eagerly, and the skin pinch goes back slowly. The infant is alert and active. Weight is 7.5 kg. According to IMNCI guidelines, what is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This child has some dehydration based on IMNCI criteria:

  • General condition: alert, active
  • Eyes: sunken
  • Thirst: drinks eagerly
  • Skin pinch: goes back slowly

This fits the yellow category (some dehydration).

  • Management: Plan B → ORS 75 mL/kg over 4 hours under supervision at a health facility. For a 7.5 kg child, this equals ~560 mL in 4 hours. Feeding should be continued alongside rehydration.

IMNCI guideline summary:

  • No dehydration (green): Plan A → ORS/home fluids after each loose stool (50-100 mL <2 years, 100-200 mL age 2-10 years).
  • Some dehydration (yellow): Plan B → ORS 75 mL/kg over 4 hours at a facility.
  • Severe dehydration (pink): Plan C → IV fluids (Ringer Lactate preferred). 100 mL/kg total: <12 months = 30 mL/kg in 1 hr then 70 mL/kg in 5 hr; ≥12 months = 30 mL/kg in 30 min then 70 mL/kg in 2.5 hr.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Oral rehydration solution, 50-100 mL after each loose stool, at home (option A): This is for no dehydration (green category), not some dehydration.

Intravenous Ringer Lactate, 100 mL/kg over 6 hours (option C): Used in severe dehydration (pink category) with lethargy/unable to drink. This child is alert and drinking.

Intravenous Normal Saline, 20 mL/kg bolus (option D): Reserved for shock (circulatory collapse). Not indicated here.

Key Takeaway

IMNCI dehydration classification is clinical. Some dehydration (yellow) requires ORS 75 mL/kg over 4 hours under supervision (Plan B). Severe dehydration (pink) requires IV fluids (Plan C). No dehydration (green) → Plan A with ORS at home.

questions.text: Identify the MRI sequence
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The key features of the MRI image indicate that it is a FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) sequence:

  • CSF signal is suppressed (dark/black): Unlike T2-weighted images where CSF is bright, FLAIR suppresses the CSF signal, making fluid appear black.
  • Gray matter is bright (whitish), while white matter is dark: This is characteristic of FLAIR images, which are T2-weighted with CSF suppression.
  • Bone appears black and fat (surface fat) appears bright, consistent with FLAIR imaging.
  • Clinical relevance: FLAIR is particularly useful for detecting lesions near CSF spaces, such as periventricular plaques in multiple sclerosis, because it clearly shows lesions while suppressing CSF signal.

FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery:

  • The main purpose of a FLAIR (Fluid-Attenuated Inversion Recovery) MRI sequence is to enhance image contrast in situations where high resolution is not the primary concern.
  • It is technically defined as a heavily T2-weighted spin-echo sequence that utilizes a long inversion time.
  • Its key function is to nullify, or suppress, the signal from cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), making it appear black in the resulting images.
  • A major benefit of this CSF suppression is the reduction of motion artifacts caused by CSF flow, which is particularly useful in spinal imaging.
  • In terms of pathology, most lesions appear bright with high signal intensity on FLAIR. In contrast, fluid-filled structures like cysts and cystic lesions appear dark, known as signal voids.

Other types of MRI sequences:

  • T2-Weighted MRI:
    • On T2-weighted MRI, gray matter appears bright/whitish, white matter appears darker, and CSF (fluid) appears bright/white.
    • This sequence is useful for highlighting fluid-filled spaces, edema, and lesions with high water content.
  • Susceptibility weighted (Option B):
    • Susceptibility Weighted Imaging (SWI) shows dark "blooming" artifacts around areas of calcification, haemosiderin, or microhemorrhages.
    • Blood vessels appear jet black due to deoxyhemoglobin.
    • SWI is particularly useful for detecting microbleeds, small hemorrhages, and calcifications that may be missed on other MRI sequences.
  • T1W (T1Weighted) (Option C):
    • If the MRI shows CSF as dark, gray matter as gray, and white matter as white, it matches T1-weighted imaging.
    • Fat appears bright, making it easy to identify surface fat. Bone appears black due to low signal.
  • DWI (Diffusion weighted tensor imaging) (Option D):
    • Diffusion Tensor Imaging (DTI), also called Tractography, visualizes white matter tracts in the brain.
    • On DTI, the tracts appear in colorful patterns, representing the direction of fiber bundles.
    • It is primarily used to evaluate white matter integrity and connectivity in neurological conditions or surgical planning.

choices.text: Drainage through the portal venous system
Transformation of epithelial to mesothelial cells

questions.text: A histological section of an abdominal organ shows pale-staining clusters of cells scattered among darker-staining parenchymal tissue. These clusters, which are supplied by a rich fenestrated capillary network and lie within the lobules , modulate the activity of the surrounding cells . Which mechanism is primary responsible for this modulation.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image represents a cluster of endocrine cells (islet-like architecture) within an exocrine gland.
  • These endocrine cells (e.g., in the pancreas, Islets of Langerhans) exert local effects on surrounding acinar cells by releasing hormones and mediators that act nearby.
  • This paracrine communication regulates exocrine secretion and modulates neighbouring cell activity without requiring systemic circulation or nerve conduction.

Paracrine Effects:

  • Within and around the islets, hormone-secreting cells- β-cells (insulin), α-cells (glucagon), δ-cells (somatostatin), PP cells, and ε cells- communicate with each other and with nearby exocrine cells.
  • This communication occurs locally via cell contact, short-range signaling molecules, and local blood flow.
  • Such paracrine regulation modulates the release of insulin, glucagon, and somatostatin, thereby maintaining glucose homeostasis and overall pancreatic function.
  • Paracrine interactions are also essential for the survival, proliferation, and proper functioning of β-cells. Disruption of this signalling network contributes to pathologies like diabetes mellitus.

Explanation of Other Options:

Drainage through the portal venous system (Option A):

  • True for systemic endocrine delivery (e.g., insulin to the liver via portal vein).
  • But the primary local influence on neighbouring cells is not via the portal system.

Direct nerve-mediated impulses (Option B):

  • Autonomic innervation modulates both endocrine and exocrine pancreas.
  • However, local influence of these cell clusters on adjacent cells is not primarily neural.

Transformation of epithelial to mesothelial cells (Option C):

  • Irrelevant to the physiological regulation of exocrine/endocrine pancreas.
  • This is a distractor and not a mechanism of local signalling.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC4686426/

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with hypokalemia and ketonuria
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with hypoglycemia
Metabolic alkalosis with hyperkalemia and hyponatremia
Normal acid-base status with isolated mild hyponatremia

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida at 7 weeks of gestation presents with severe, persistent vomiting for the past two weeks. She has lost 4 kg during this period and appears dehydrated on examination. Her pulse is 110/min with postural hypotension. Laboratory evaluation shows mild transaminitis (AST/ALT ~70 IU/L) and a serum bilirubin of 1.8 mg/dL. Arterial blood gas is obtained. Which of the following laboratory patterns is most consistent with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hyperemesis gravidarum

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum is persistent vomiting associated with weight loss of ≥ 5% of pre-pregnancy weight and presence of ketonuria due breakdown of fat and dehydration.
  • Persistent vomiting causes loss of gastric acid (H+ and Cl- ions), leading to metabolic alkalosis. Subsequent renal compensation involves excretion of potassium (K+) to conserve H+, resulting in hypokalemia. This electrolyte imbalance is a hallmark of the condition, differentiating it from simple dehydration from other causes.
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum interferes with the patient's quality of life and is associated with elevated hCG levels as seen in:
    • Multiple gestations (twins/triplets)
    • Molar pregnancies (most dramatic hCG elevation and carries the highest risk)
    • Ovarian theca lutein cysts (due to high hCG).
  • Complications of Hyperemesis Gravidarum:
    • Dehydration and ketonuria
    • Electrolyte imbalance
    • Mallory-Weiss tear
    • Vitamin deficiency (vitamin k and thiamine): Thiamine deficiency → Wernicke' encephalopathy
  • Management involves:
    • Hospitalization
    • IV fluid rehydration
    • Electrolyte correction: potassium replacement
    • Thiamine supplementation: Depleted glycogen stores and carbohydrate load from dextrose can precipitate Wernicke's encephalopathy (characterized by confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia) in thiamine-deficient states caused by prolonged vomiting.
    • Antiemetics (ondansetron, promethazine, metoclopramide).

Key Takeaways:

  • Hyperemesis gravidarum (HG): Severe vomiting in early pregnancy → weight loss >5%, dehydration, ketonuria, mild hepatic dysfunction.
  • Pathophysiology:
  • Gastric H+ and Cl- loss → metabolic alkalosis.
  • Renal K+ wasting → hypokalemia.
  • Breakdown of fat due to starvation → ketonuria.
  • LFT derangements (AST/ALT, bilirubin) are commonly seen and can mimic hepatitis.
  • Thiamine should always be given before dextrose infusion in malnourished or severely vomiting patients to prevent Wernicke's encephalopathy.

Explanation for other options:

High anion gap metabolic acidosis with hypoglycemia (Option B): Seen in diabetic/starvation ketoacidosis; not typical in HG where alkalosis predominates.

Metabolic alkalosis with hyperkalemia and hyponatremia (Option C): Hyperkalemia does not occur; potassium is lost in urine.

Normal acid-base status with isolated mild hyponatremia (Option D): Hyponatremia may accompany vomiting/dehydration, but the hallmark is alkalosis + hypokalemia.

choices.text: Systolic blood pressure < 90 mmHg or diastolic ≤ 60 mmHg

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with fever, cough, and shortness of breath. You decide to assess his pneumonia severity using the CURB-65 score. Which of the following is not a parameter of CURB-65?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The CURB-65 score uses the parameter respiratory rate ≥ 30/min.

The CURB-65 score is a severity-of-illness tool used to assess patients with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). It evaluates five parameters:

  • C: Confusion
  • U: Urea >7 mmol/L
  • R: Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • B: Blood pressure (systolic <90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg)
  • 65: Age ≥65 years
  • A score of 0 indicates patients can usually be managed as outpatients.
  • A score of 1-2 suggests hospital admission may be appropriate, especially if age ≥65 contributes to the score.
  • Patients with scores ≥3 have higher mortality and often require ICU admission.
  • Community-acquired pneumonia can result from a wide range of pathogens, including bacteria, viruses, fungi, and protozoa.
  • Typical bacteria: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and in some cases Staphylococcus aureus, Klebsiella pneumoniae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
  • Atypical bacteria: Mycoplasma pneumoniae, Chlamydia pneumoniae, and Legionella
  • Respiratory viruses such as influenza, RSV, adenovirus, parainfluenza, and metapneumovirus also play an important role.
  • Determining the appropriate care setting for CAP can be challenging. Some individuals can be safely managed at home, while others require hospitalization.
  • To reduce unnecessary admissions and better predict outcomes such as severe disease or death, objective scoring systems are used.
  • The two most common are the Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI), which estimates mortality risk, and the CURB-65 score, which grades illness severity.
  • The PSI assigns points for 20 factors, including age, comorbidities, and abnormal clinical or laboratory findings, and then classifies patients into one of five classes with corresponding mortality risks.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child is brought to the clinic for evaluation of frequent episodes characterized by brief staring spells lasting a few seconds, with no loss of postural tone. The child appears unresponsive during these episodes and exhibits subtle lip-smacking movements. An EEG shows a characteristic generalized pattern.
Which of the following drugs is most appropriate as initial therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The child's clinical features are typical of absence seizures (petit mal epilepsy): sudden staring, unresponsiveness, automatisms, preserved posture, and characteristic 3 Hz spike-and-wave EEG.
  • Ethosuximide is the drug of choice (DOC) for absence seizures in children because it specifically inhibits T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which mediate the abnormal oscillations.

Childhood Absence Seizures

  1. Clinical Profile
    • Age of onset: typically 4-10 years.
    • Episodes: brief, sudden staring with unresponsiveness lasting a few seconds.
    • Motor features: subtle automatisms such as eyelid flutter or lip-smacking.
    • Posture: maintained throughout the episode.
    • Aftermath: no postictal confusion; child resumes normal activity.
    • Frequency: can occur many times per day, often mistaken for "daydreaming."
  2. EEG Findings
    • Diagnostic hallmark: generalized 3 Hz spike-and-wave discharges.
    • Helps differentiate absence seizures from focal impaired-awareness seizures (which show focal activity).
  3. Pathophysiology
    • Origin: abnormal oscillations within thalamocortical circuits.
    • Mechanism: mediated by T-type calcium channels in thalamic neurons.
    • Result: transient lapses in awareness without motor convulsions.
  4. Treatment Rationale
    • First-line:
      • Ethosuximide → specifically blocks T-type calcium channels → directly addresses pathogenesis.
      • Excellent efficacy and tolerability in pure absence seizures.
    • Alternative:
      • Sodium valproate → broad-spectrum AED. (Option C ruled out)
        • Used if absence seizures coexist with other generalized seizure types.
        • More systemic side effects (weight gain, tremor, hepatotoxicity, cognitive impact).
    • Avoid:
      • Phenytoin → may worsen absence seizures. (Option A ruled out)
      • Carbamazepine → may aggravate absence seizures. (Option D ruled out)
  5. Evidence & Guidelines
    • Randomized controlled trials: ethosuximide superior to valproate in cognitive outcomes and tolerability.
    • International neurology guidelines: recommend ethosuximide as first-line for childhood absence epilepsy.

questions.text: A 30-year-old multigravida at 32 weeks gestation presents with sudden, painless vaginal bleeding. She is hemodynamically stable, uterus is relaxed, and fetal heart sounds are normal. On transabdominal ultrasound, the placental edge is seen implanted in the lower uterine segment, lying exactly at the level of the internal os. According to standard classification, this corresponds to which type of placenta previa?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ultrasound shows the placental edge exactly at the level of the internal os → that is Type II (Marginal) placenta previa.
  • Antepartum hemorrhage (APH) is defined as any bleeding from or into the genital tract occurring beyond the period of viability (≥28 weeks of gestation). Placenta previa is the second most common cause of APH.
  • In this condition, the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment. As the uterus contracts or the cervix dilates, the inelastic placental attachment shears, opening venous sinuses in the decidua basalis (intervillous space) and causing painless bleeding. Unlike placental abruption, the placenta does not separate, and no thromboplastin is released.
  • The classic presentation is painless bleeding in late pregnancy. A PV exam is contraindicated until previa is ruled out by USG to prevent catastrophic hemorrhage.

choices.text: Hepatic duct of segment IV (left medial lobe)

questions.text:
A 50-year-old woman undergoes laparoscopic cholecystectomy. During dissection in the cystohepatic triangle, excessive bile leakage is noticed. On review, it is found that an accessory bile duct running through the triangle was inadvertently clipped and divided.
This structure is most likely:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The cystohepatic triangle may contain not only the cystic artery and lymphatics but also accessory bile ducts, the most important being the duct of Luschka.
  • These small ducts usually drain directly from the right lobe of the liver into the gallbladder or cystic duct.
  • Injury or failure to recognize them can lead to bile leakage post-cholecystectomy, a known surgical complication.

Cystohepatic (Hepatobiliary) Triangle


  • Boundaries (modern definition):
    • Inferior: Cystic duct
    • Medial: Common hepatic duct
    • Superior: Inferior surface of the liver
  • Common Misconception: It is often incorrectly referred to as Calot's triangle, which was originally described as an isosceles triangle bounded by the cystic duct, common hepatic duct, and cystic artery.
  • Modern distinction: The cystohepatic triangle differs from Calot's original definition by excluding the cystic artery as a boundary.
  • Anatomical Features:
    • Bridged by a double layer of peritoneum (short mesentery of the cystic duct).
    • Contains adipose and connective tissue, lymphatics, autonomic nerves.
    • Houses the cystic artery (usually from the right hepatic artery) and the cystic lymph node (Node of Lund).
    • May occasionally contain an accessory cystic duct or the duct of Luschka.
  • Clinical Importance:
    • Safe identification of structures in this triangle is essential during cholecystectomy to avoid injury to:
      • Common hepatic duct
      • Common bile duct
      • Right hepatic artery

Explanation of other options:

Accessory pancreatic duct (Option B): Related to pancreatic drainage, not gallbladder surgery.

Hepatic duct of segment IV (Option C): Drains the left medial lobe, not part of the triangle.

Cystic duct remnant (Option D): A normal remnant after cholecystectomy, but not an accessory structure traversing the triangle.

choices.text: Long-term PPI use causes hypochlorhydria, leading to compensatory hypergastrinemia and impaired release of vitamin B12 from food proteins.
PPIs increase gastric acidity, which suppresses gastrin release and promotes intrinsic factor secretion.
Chronic PPI use directly stimulates parietal cell proliferation and increases intrinsic factor levels.
PPI therapy prevents the development of fundic gland polyps by promoting gastric mucosal health.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a long history of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) has been taking esomeprazole 40 mg daily for over 5 years. She now presents with vague epigastric discomfort and fatigue. Laboratory tests reveal low serum vitamin B12 levels. Upper GI endoscopy shows mild gastric mucosal atrophy and fundic gland polyps. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Chronic PPI use suppresses gastric acid secretion → hypochlorhydria → compensatory hypergastrinemia as a feedback mechanism.
  • Hypergastrinemia promotes ECL cell hyperplasia and is associated with fundic gland polyps (generally benign).
  • Hypochlorhydria impairs vitamin B12 absorption by interfering with the release of vitamin B12 from dietary proteins (intrinsic factor production is not the limiting step here).
  • Over time, gastric mucosal atrophy may develop; risk is influenced by factors such as pylori infection (test and eradicate if long-term PPI is required).
  • Regular monitoring of vitamin B12 levels is reasonable in long-term PPI therapy.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

PPIs increase gastric acidity, which suppresses gastrin release and promotes intrinsic factor secretion (Option B): PPIs suppress acid production, leading to hypochlorhydria, not increased acidity.

Chronic PPI use directly stimulates parietal cell proliferation and increases intrinsic factor levels (Option C): PPIs inhibit parietal cell H⁺/K⁺ ATPase; they do not directly stimulate parietal cell proliferation or increase intrinsic factor.

PPI therapy prevents the development of fundic gland polyps by promoting gastric mucosal health (Option D): Fundic gland polyps are more common with long-term PPI use due to trophic effects of hypergastrinemia.

Key takeaway:

Adverse effects of PPI:

(Mnemonic for adverse effects of PPI: MICAH)

M: Microscopic colitis, malabsorption of calcium, vitamin B12, iron and magnesium

I: Intestinal infections and IBD

C: Colonization of multi-drug resistant bacteria

A: Atrophic gastritis

H: Hypergastrinemia

questions.text: A 32-year-old gravida 4 para 2 woman with a history of two prior lower-segment cesarean sections and one prior myomectomy presents at 33 weeks of gestation for routine antenatal care. Ultrasonography shows an anterior low-lying placenta with multiple irregular vascular lacunae and turbulent flow on color Doppler. MRI reveals loss of the normal retroplacental hypoechoic zone with placental tissue extending to the uterine serosa but without bladder involvement. Which of the following best describes the FIGO classification of her condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Placenta accreta spectrum (PAS) refers to a group of disorders where placental villi abnormally adhere to or invade the myometrium due to defective decidua.
  • According to FIGO classification:
    • Grade 1 : Placenta accreta: Villi attach directly to the myometrium without invasion.
    • Grade 2: Placenta increta: Villi invade into the myometrium.
    • Grade 3: Placenta percreta: Villi penetrate through the myometrium, sometimes reaching the
      • Grade 3A: Serosa
      • Grade 3B: Bladder
      • Grade 3C: Any other adjacent pelvic structure
  • Placenta accreta results from defective decidualization with absence of the decidua basalis and loss of Nitabuch's layer, the normal fibrinoid barrier between trophoblast and decidua. This defect allows excessive invasion of the cytotrophoblast into the myometrium, leading to abnormal placental adherence.
  • Risk factors:
    • The single greatest risk factor for placenta accreta spectrum is the combination of placenta previa (anterior) in present pregnancy and a history of prior cesarean sections.
    • The risk increases with the number of prior scars from :
      • Previous c-sections
      • Myomectomy
      • Curettage
      • Endometrial ablation
    • Previous history of PAS
  • It can be diagnosed by Ultrasonography with color doppler or an MRI.
  • Management:
    • Antenatal diagnosis: Plan an elective cesarean section at 34-35+6 weeks, immediately followed by hysterectomy with the placenta left in situ.
    • Postnatal diagnosis: If the patient presents with uncontrollable postpartum hemorrhage, an emergency hysterectomy is required.

Explanation of other options:

Placenta increta (Grade 2) (Option A): Incorrect - invasion is confined to the myometrium only; in this case, MRI confirms extension up to serosa.

Placenta accreta (Grade 1) (Option C): Incorrect - only villous adherence to myometrium without invasion, which does not explain imaging findings.

Placenta percreta Grade 3B (Option D): Incorrect - requires placental villi invading into the bladder wall; imaging explicitly rules this out.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with well-demarcated, scaly plaques on the extensor surfaces of his elbows and knees. A test was done by gently scraping the scales, as shown below. What is this clinical sign called?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of characteristic lesions bilaterally over the extensor regions points to the diagnosis of psoriasis. Pinpoint bleeding after gentle scraping of psoriatic scales indicates the Auspitz sign, characteristic of psoriasis.

Psoriasis - Clinical Presentation

  • Lesion Appearance:
    • Scaly plaques with sharply demarcated edges.
    • May have a hypopigmented halo around healing psoriatic lesions (Woronoff ring).
    • Single or multiple lesions; when multiple, usually monomorphic and
    • Distribution: Symmetrical, Scalp, trunk, extensor surfaces of limbs.
    • New lesions in a linear pattern at trauma sites → Koebner (isomorphic) phenomenon. (Option A ruled out)
  • Scaling:
    • Silvery white scales
    • Minimal scaling in flexural areas.
  • Auspitz Sign: (Option D)
    • Gentle removal of scales reveals a glistening erythematous surface with pinpoint bleeding (due to thin suprapapillary epidermis).
    • This test is called the Grattage test.

Explanation of other options:

Nikolsky sign (Option B): Gentle lateral pressure on the skin causes the epidermis to shear off, seen in pemphigus vulgaris; unlike the Auspitz sign, it does not produce pinpoint bleeding.

Wickham striae (Option C): Fine white lines on lichen planus lesions, unrelated to scraping or bleeding.

Key Takeaway:

  • In psoriasis, gentle removal of scales exposes tiny bleeding points from superficial dermal capillaries, known as the Auspitz sign.

questions.text:
Regarding lupus nephritis, which of the following combinations of statements is correct?

1. Class IV (Diffuse proliferative) lupus nephritis is the most severe and carries the worst prognosis if left untreated.
2. Class V (Membranous) lupus nephritis typically shows subendothelial immune deposits and is best managed with steroids alone.
3. Belimumab and voclosporin are newer agents approved for use in active lupus nephritis.
4. Class VI (Advanced sclerosing) lupus nephritis represents end-stage disease with >90% glomerular sclerosis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct regarding lupus nephritis.

  • Lupus nephritis is a frequent and serious manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), occurring in up to half of patients.
  • It results from immune complex deposition that activate complement pathways, leukocyte infiltration, and cytokine release, ultimately injuring renal tissue.
  • These immune deposits are seen in mesangial, subendothelial, or subepithelial sites.

Clinical Features

  • Kidney involvement in SLE manifests with proteinuria (most common), hematuria, hypertension, variable renal dysfunction, and urinary RBC casts.
  • Hypocomplementemia (low C3/C4) is seen in most acute cases, and anti-dsDNA levels correlate with disease activity.
  • Renal biopsy is essential for classification, guiding therapy, and monitoring disease course.

Classification

  1. Class I (Minimal Mesangial): Rare, immune deposits in mesangium, normal light microscopy; excellent prognosis.
  2. Class II (Mesangial Proliferative): Mesangial hypercellularity and immune deposits; generally mild disease.
  3. Class III (Focal Proliferative): <50% glomeruli involved, with endothelial and mesangial proliferation, necrosis, and crescents; hematuria, proteinuria, hypertension.
  4. Class IV (Diffuse Proliferative): >50% glomeruli involved, most severe and common form; subendothelial deposits produce wire-loop lesions as shown below.
  5. Class V (Membranous): Subepithelial deposits causing capillary wall thickening, often nephrotic syndrome; can occur with proliferative lesions (mixed pattern). (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  6. Class VI (Advanced Sclerosing): >90% glomeruli sclerosed; represents end-stage disease.

Prognosis

  • Class IV has the worst prognosis without therapy. Aggressive immunosuppression is needed.
  • Class V patients often present with nephrotic syndrome, are prone to thrombotic complications, and may require combination therapy.
  • Class VI patients almost invariably progress to end-stage kidney disease, requiring dialysis or transplantation.

Treatment

  • Induction therapy: High-dose corticosteroids plus either cyclophosphamide or mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) for 2-6 months.
  • Maintenance: Lower-dose steroids with MMF or azathioprine. Calcineurin inhibitors (e.g., tacrolimus, cyclosporine) may also be used.
  • Biologics: Belimumab and voclosporin have recently been approved for active lupus nephritis, often in combination with standard therapy.
  • Adjuncts: ACE inhibitors/ARBs and SGLT2 inhibitors for proteinuria reduction. Anticoagulation if antiphospholipid antibodies are present.
  • Kidney transplantation is an option for patients progressing to end-stage disease, with outcomes comparable to other transplant populations if lupus is quiescent.

choices.text: Obidoxime is the preferred confirmatory test and reverses the neuromuscular block seen in myasthenia gravis.
Donepezil provides the most rapid diagnostic confirmation and distinguishes myasthenic from cholinergic crisis.
Edrophonium transiently improves muscle strength by inhibiting acetylcholinesterase and helps differentiate myasthenic crises from cholinergic crises.
Lidocaine and magnesium do not interfere with neuromuscular transmission and therefore cannot worsen myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman with fluctuating ptosis, diplopia, and fatigable limb weakness worsening in the evening has been on pyridostigmine for 6 months. Recently, her weakness worsened after a dental procedure with local lidocaine. On examination, she shows marked extraocular fatigability. A diagnostic test is performed with an initial 2 mg IV injection of a short-acting agent; after 30 seconds, her muscle strength improves, so no further dose is given. Which one of the following statements regarding this scenario is MOST accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation

The patient has myasthenia gravis (MG), an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction.

  • Pathophysiology: Antibodies block AChRs, activate complement, and reduce receptor number, producing fatigable muscle weakness (worsens later in the day, improves with rest).
  • Clinical features: Ptosis, diplopia, bulbar and limb weakness without sensory involvement.

Diagnostic test:

  • Edrophonium (Tensilon) test is the classic bedside diagnostic procedure.

Mechanism: A short-acting anticholinesterase that increases acetylcholine levels at the NMJ, temporarily improving strength.

Procedure: Inject 2 mg IV → observe 30-60 s → if no adverse effects, give remaining 8 mg.

Interpretation:

  • Myasthenic crisis: Brief improvement in strength.
  • Cholinergic crisis: No improvement or worsening.

Safety: IV atropine must be ready to treat bradycardia.

Drugs aggravating MG:

  • Local anaesthetics (e.g., lidocaine) - interfere with neuromuscular transmission and worsen weakness.
  • Magnesium, aminoglycosides, quinolones, macrolides, beta-blockers, botulinum toxin, penicillamine, quinine derivatives, and non-depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMRs) are all implicated.
  • Antacids containing magnesium or aluminium (e.g., Digene) reduce absorption of pyridostigmine, decreasing its efficacy and increasing weakness.

Management overview:

  • Long-term therapy: Pyridostigmine (drug of choice) or neostigmine (oral/IV).
  • Alternative diagnostic agent: IV neostigmine (1.5 mg) can be used if edrophonium is unavailable, with atropine pre-treatment.
  • Provocative test: d-Tubocurarine (0.5 mg IV) produces marked weakness in MG but is hazardous and rarely used.

Differential diagnoses (for fatigable weakness):

  • Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome: Antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, strength improves with activity.
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome: Acute ascending polyneuropathy, not fatigable.
  • Huntington's chorea / ALS / external ophthalmoplegia: No transient improvement with anticholinesterases.

Key pharmacological pearls:

  • Lidocaine may worsen MG by impairing neuromuscular conduction.
  • Magnesium competes with calcium at presynaptic terminals, decreasing ACh release.
  • Pyridostigmine absorption is reduced by magnesium/aluminium antacids.

Explanation of Other Options

Obidoxime (Option A): Cholinesterase reactivator used in organophosphate poisoning; not a diagnostic test for MG and does not reverse autoimmune AChR blockade.

Donepezil (Option B): Centrally acting anticholinesterase for Alzheimer's disease, not for MG diagnosis or crisis differentiation.

Lidocaine and magnesium do not interfere with neuromuscular transmission and therefore cannot worsen myasthenia gravis (Option D): Incorrect; both can exacerbate MG by reducing acetylcholine release or receptor function, leading to increased weakness and fatigue.

Key Takeaways

  • Edrophonium test remains the classic (though less commonly used) diagnostic tool for MG and for distinguishing myasthenic crisis (improves) from cholinergic crisis (no improvement/worsening).
  • Many drugs worsen MG, notably local anaesthetics and magnesium salts, as well as several antibiotics and cardiovascular agents.
  • Always keep atropine ready to counteract bradycardia during testing.

choices.text: 25; It is the best single indicator of the nutritional status and health care of children in a community.
40; It is the best single indicator of the nutritional status and health care of children in a community.
25; It is the best single indicator of the socioeconomic development and overall health status of a community.
40; It is the best single indicator of the socioeconomic development and overall health status of a community.

questions.text: In a community with a population of 50,000, the number of live births in a year was 1,200. The number of deaths among children under 5 years of age in the same year was 48. What is the Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR) per 1000 live births for this community, and what is its primary significance as a health indicator?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Calculation of Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR):
