The Under-5 Mortality Rate (U5MR) is a vital statistic that measures the probability of a child dying between birth and exactly 5 years of age, expressed per 1000 live births.

The formula is:
U5MR = (Number of deaths of children under 5 years of age in a year / Number of live births in the same year) × 1000

Given:

  • Number of deaths (<5 years) = 48
  • Number of live births = 1200

Calculation:
U5MR = (48 / 1200) × 1000
U5MR = (0.04) × 1000
U5MR = 40 per 1000 live births

Therefore, the rate is 40 (Option A, C ruled out).

Significance of Under-5 Mortality Rate:

The U5MR is a critical index for assessing child health for several reasons, as described in Park's textbook:

  • It reflects the nutritional status of children, as malnutrition is a major underlying cause of death in this age group (Option D ruled out).
  • It indicates the adequacy of health care available to children, including immunization coverage, availability of Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORT) for diarrhea, and case management of pneumonia and other common childhood illnesses.
  • It is a more comprehensive measure than the Infant Mortality Rate (IMR) because it covers the vulnerable period from birth to 5 years, capturing deaths from a wider range of causes that affect toddlers and preschoolers.

questions.text: To check the higher mental function of the patient, the examiner says some numbers and the patient is asked to repeat them. The examiner starts with a single number and gradually increases to two number sequence, three number sequence and so on and so forth, till patient fails to repeat. This test can be applied for all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The digit span test cannot be used to analyse abstract thinking.

  • The described test is the digit span test, where the patient repeats sequences of numbers read aloud.
  • It evaluates the patient's ability to hold and manipulate information over a short period.
  • Key cognitive functions tested include:
    • Attention (Option A): The patient must focus on the numbers being read.
    • Concentration (Option B): Sustained mental effort is required to retain and repeat increasing sequences.
    • Immediate memory (Option D): Also called working memory, it involves recalling the numbers immediately after hearing them.

Abstract thinking:

  • Abstract thinking involves the ability to:
  • Grasp the essentials of a whole and discern common properties.
  • Think hypothetically or symbolically.
  • Apply logical deductions beyond concrete experiences.
  • The digit span test does not require hypothetical reasoning or symbolic thought. It only tests short-term retention and attention, not higher-order conceptual processing.

questions.text: Which of the labelled regions in the diagram represents the characteristic laboratory pattern expected in a patient with polycythemia rubra vera?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Polycythaemia rubra vera (PRV) is a chronic myeloproliferative neoplasm driven by mutations in JAK2 tyrosine kinase (most often V617F mutation). It is characterized by increased proliferation of erythroid, granulocytic, and megakaryocytic precursors, with erythroid predominance.

Key laboratory hallmark:

  • Increased red cell mass (polycythaemia) → haematocrit often >60%.
  • Suppressed serum erythropoietin (EPO) → because red cell expansion is autonomous (not EPO-driven).
  • Leukocyte alkaline phosphatase (LAP) activity is elevated, in contrast to the case with chronic myeloid leukemia, where it is reduced

On the diagram:

  • X-axis: Red cell mass
  • Y-axis: Serum erythropoietin

Thus. PRV falls into Box C → Increased red cell mass with decreased serum erythropoietin.

Other Findings-

  • The liver and spleen are typically moderately enlarged and may show extramedullary haematopoiesis.
  • Thrombotic complications are an important cause of morbidity and mortality, and major and minor haemorrhagic complications are also frequent.
  • Pruritus and peptic ulceration are common, possibly in relation to increased histamine release from basophils.

Complications-

  • Thrombosis (Budd-Chiari syndrome, DVT, stroke, MI).
  • Haemorrhage (due to abnormal platelet function).
  • Progression to myelofibrosis or acute leukaemia in some cases.

Differential Diagnosis of Polycythaemia

Explanation Of Other Options:

Box A (Option A) (↑ EPO, ↓ red cell mass): Typical of secondary polycythaemia due to hypoxia (e.g., COPD, cyanotic heart disease, high altitude).

Box B (Option B) (↑ EPO, ↑ red cell mass): Seen in secondary polycythaemia due to ectopic EPO production (renal cell carcinoma, hepatocellular carcinoma, uterine fibroids).

Box D (Option D) (↓ EPO, ↓ red cell mass): Characteristic of aplastic anaemia / marrow failure syndromes where marrow doesn't respond, leading to anaemia with low EPO.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Naegele's rule becomes increasingly unreliable for estimating the expected date of delivery in women who have irregular menstrual cycles and significant variability in follicular phase duration, especially when cycle length deviates from 28 days.
Reason (R): Naegele's rule assumes that ovulation consistently occurs exactly at the midpoint of every menstrual cycle, regardless of cycle length, and that the luteal phase duration may fluctuate between women.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Assertion (A) is true:

  • Naegele's rule indeed becomes increasingly unreliable for estimating the expected date of delivery (EDD) in women with irregular menstrual cycles and significant variability in follicular phase duration, especially when the cycle length deviates from 28 days. This is widely supported by clinical research and reviews.

Reason (R) is false:

  • Naegele's rule assumes a 28-day menstrual cycle with ovulation occurring on day 14. This assumption makes it increasingly unreliable for women who have irregular menstrual cycles or significant variability in the follicular phase duration, causing inaccuracy in estimating the expected date of delivery (EDD).

Naegele's rule:

  • The Naegele's formula is used to calculate the estimated day of delivery (EDD).
  • The formula is given by: 1st day of LMP + 7 days and 9 months = EDD.
  • Naegele's rule assumes the menstrual cycles:
    • Regular cycle
    • Cycle length: 28 days
    • Day 14 of cycle: day of ovulation and day of fertilization
  • In women with irregular cycles or extremes of cycle length, this assumption fails, so EDD cannot be accurately predicted.
  • Naegele's formula is not applicable in the following conditions:
    • Pregnancy due to OCP failure
    • Lactational amenorrhea
    • Irregular cycles
    • Unsure about LMP
  • Methods of Gestational Age Determination:
    • First Trimester:
      • Crown-Rump Length (CRL): Most accurate method for dating.
    • Second Trimester:
      • Biparietal Diameter (BPD)
      • Femur Length (FL): More reliable than CRL in this period.
    • After 20 Weeks: Fundal Height Measurement: Correlates reasonably with gestational age (in cm ≈ weeks).

Key Takeaway:

  • Naegele's rule is limited in irregular cycles, ART pregnancies, lactational amenorrhea, and poor recall of LMP.

questions.text: Match the following disorders with their typical lab parameters:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option A correctly matches the disorders in column A with their typical lab parameters.

The various disorders are summarised below.

Diabetes insipidus

  • Diabetes insipidus is characterized by excessive urine output of dilute urine, leading to intense thirst (polydipsia).
  • It results from either a deficiency of arginine vasopressin (AVP) secretion (central DI) or renal resistance to AVP (nephrogenic DI).
  • Central DI may occur due to injury, inflammation, tumours, infections, or idiopathic destruction of hypothalamic AVP-secreting neurons.
  • Nephrogenic DI can arise from genetic mutations, drugs like lithium, electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypercalcemia), or chronic kidney conditions.
  • Pathophysiologically, the lack of AVP effect prevents adequate water reabsorption, so urine remains maximally dilute (<250 mOsm/kg).
  • Serum sodium (serum osmolality) can remain normal, or there can be hypernatremia.
  • Diagnosis relies on measuring urine output, osmolality, plasma AVP/copeptin levels, and sometimes a water deprivation test with desmopressin administration.
  • Treatment is based on cause: central DI responds well to desmopressin (DDAVP), a synthetic AVP analogue given via injection, nasal spray, or orally.
  • Nephrogenic DI is harder to manage and may be improved with thiazides, amiloride, NSAIDs, or by stopping offending drugs such as lithium.

Primary Polydipsia

  • Primary polydipsia is defined by excessive fluid intake leading to polyuria with dilute urine.
  • It is commonly associated with psychiatric disorders, neurological disease, or seen as a behavioural habit.
  • The increased intake reduces plasma osmolality, suppresses AVP secretion, and produces compensatory water diuresis.
  • Clinically, patients excrete large amounts of very dilute urine but usually maintain normal sodium levels unless intake is extreme, in which case hyponatremia may occur.
  • Unlike DI, the plasma AVP response is intact and urine can concentrate normally if water is restricted.
  • Treatment focuses on gradual reduction of water intake, supportive strategies to reduce thirst, and addressing underlying psychiatric or behavioral causes.

SIADH

  • SIADH occurs when antidiuretic hormone (AVP) is secreted inappropriately, despite normal osmotic suppression.
  • This leads to water retention, low plasma osmolality, and hyponatremia.
  • Urine osmolality: usually >100-200 mosm/L (not maximally dilute, unlike primary polydipsia)
  • Urine sodium: inappropriately high (>30 mmol/L) despite low plasma sodium, reflecting ongoing sodium loss
  • Volume status: patients are typically euvolemic, without clinical oedema
  • Failure to suppress AVP during water excess prevents normal water diuresis. This causes mild extracellular fluid expansion, but without significant oedema.
  • Instead, the main effect is an increase in intracellular volume, particularly in the brain, leading to pressure changes and neurological symptoms.

choices.text: Collapse of the carpal arch due to delayed union
Ischemic necrosis of the proximal fragment
Malunion secondary to altered ligamentous pull
Secondary osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint

questions.text: A 19-year-old male presents with persistent wrist pain after falling on his outstretched hand. A fracture through the waist of a carpal bone is strongly suspected. Which of the following complications is most likely to occur if this injury is missed?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The scaphoid is the most commonly fractured carpal bone.
  • Its blood supply comes primarily from branches of the radial artery that enter distally and then travel retrograde to the proximal pole.
  • When a fracture occurs through the waist, the proximal fragment is at risk of being cut off from its blood supply.
  • The most feared complication is avascular necrosis (ischemic necrosis) of the proximal fragment.

Anatomy of Scaphoid

  • Located in proximal carpal row, boat-shaped
  • Divided into distal pole/tubercle, waist, proximal pole
  • Articulates with radius (proximal), trapezium (distal), lunate and capitate (medial)
  • Acts as a bridge between proximal and distal carpal rows, transmits forces during FOOSH

Blood Supply

  • Supplied mainly by branches of the radial artery
  • Dorsal branches enter along dorsal ridge; volar branches enter distally
  • Proximal pole receives blood retrogradely → vulnerable if waist/proximal fractures occur

Anatomical Snuffbox

  • Bounded laterally by abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis, medially by extensor pollicis longus
  • Floor formed by scaphoid and trapezium; radial artery passes through
  • Tenderness in this area after FOOSH is a sensitive clinical sign of scaphoid fracture

Complications of Missed Fracture

  • Avascular necrosis of proximal fragment (most likely)
  • Nonunion leading to carpal collapse (SNAC wrist)
  • Secondary osteoarthritis of wrist joints
  • Carpal instability and loss of wrist function

Explanation of other options:

Collapse of the carpal arch due to nonunion (Option A): Nonunion is possible if the fracture is missed, but the most specific and likely complication is ischemic necrosis, not arch collapse.

Malunion secondary to altered ligamentous pull (Option C): Malunion may occur, but again it is less characteristic than AVN.

Secondary osteoarthritis of the radiocarpal joint (Option D): This can develop late due to chronic nonunion or AVN, but it is a downstream complication, not the primary one most likely to occur.

Key Takeaway:

  • Snuffbox tenderness with scaphoid fracture carries a high risk of proximal pole avascular necrosis due to retrograde blood supply, making it the most significant complication.

Reference:

  1. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK536907/
  2. https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24720299/

questions.text:
Choose the CORRECT option regarding nephron development and function
1. Metanephric blastema gives rise to ureter
2. Ureteric bud derivatives are lined by transitional epithelium
3. 75% of filtrate is reabsorbed mainly in the distal convoluted tubule
4. Aldosterone acts on distal nephron to increase NaCl and water reabsorption
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  1. Metanephric blastema gives rise to the ureter: Incorrect. The metanephric blastema forms the nephrons (glomerulus, Bowman's capsule, proximal convoluted tubule, loop of Henle, distal convoluted tubule). The ureteric bud, which arises from the mesonephric duct, gives rise to the ureter, renal pelvis, major and minor calyces, and collecting ducts.
  2. Ureteric bud derivatives are lined by transitional epithelium: Correct. The ureteric bud forms the collecting system of the kidney, including the ureter, renal pelvis, calyces, and collecting ducts. These structures are indeed lined by transitional epithelium, which is specialized to allow for stretching as urine volume changes.
  3. 75% of filtrate is reabsorbed mainly in the distal convoluted tubule: Incorrect. Approximately 65-70% of the filtrate is reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule, not the distal convoluted tubule. The distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts are responsible for fine-tuning reabsorption under hormonal control.
  4. Aldosterone acts on the distal nephron to increase NaCl and water reabsorption: Correct. Aldosterone primarily acts on the principal cells in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting ducts (parts of the "distal nephron") to increase the reabsorption of sodium ions (NaCl) and, consequently, water. This helps regulate blood pressure and fluid balance.

Thus, statements 2 and 4 are correct.

Key Takeaway:

  • Nephron Development: Metanephric blastema forms nephrons; Ureteric bud forms the collecting system.
  • Epithelium: Ureteric bud derivatives (collecting system) are lined by transitional epithelium.
  • Filtrate Reabsorption: Bulk reabsorption occurs in the proximal convoluted tubule.
  • Hormonal Control: Aldosterone's primary action is on the distal nephron to increase Na+ and water reabsorption.

choices.text: ATP activates phosphofructokinase-1 by providing energy
Citrate stimulates phosphofructokinase-1 to enhance glycolysis

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the major allosteric regulator that activates the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis in the liver?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1) is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis. It is most strongly activated by fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which integrates hormonal signals from insulin and glucagon to regulate glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

A review of glycolysis:

  • Glucose gets converted into pyruvate through glycolysis while ADP gets converted into ATP in the process.
  • The pyruvate gets converted to acetyl-CoA by the Krebs cycle.
  • In negative feedback mechanism, if the products of a reaction increase, the reaction is stopped by those products.
  • The rate limiting enzyme of glycolysis is PFK-1.
  • ATP, pyruvate, acetyl-CoA, and other products of these reactions have a negative feedback on the enzyme phosphofructokinase-1 (PFK-1).
  • An increased amount of glucose or ADP, however, will give a positive feedback to the enzyme PFK-1.

Pathophysiology

  • PFK-1
    • Activated by AMP and F-2,6-BP
    • Inhibited by ATP and citrate
  • Hormonal regulation
    • Insulin → dephosphorylates PFK-2/FBPase-2 → ↑ F-2,6-BP → glycolysis ↑
    • Glucagon → phosphorylates PFK-2/FBPase-2 → ↓ F-2,6-BP → glycolysis ↓, gluconeogenesis ↑

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Glucagon activates PFK-2, increasing fructose-2,6-bisphosphate (Option B): Glucagon activates PKA, which phosphorylates the bifunctional enzyme, favouring FBPase-2. This decreases F-2,6-BP, suppressing glycolysis. The PFK-2 is not the rate-limiting enzyme. Fructose-2,6 biphosphate inhibits its own enzyme, PFK-2 but favours the enzyme PFK-1.

ATP activates phosphofructokinase-1 by providing energy (Option C): ATP actually inhibits PFK-1 by signaling high-energy status, thereby slowing glycolysis.

Citrate stimulates phosphofructokinase-1 to enhance glycolysis (Option D): Citrate is a negative regulator of PFK-1, reflecting TCA cycle sufficiency; it inhibits glycolysis, not stimulates it.

Key Takeaway:

The most potent activator of PFK-1 is fructose-2,6-bisphosphate, which is increased by insulin and suppressed by glucagon, ensuring glycolysis is tightly linked to nutritional status.

questions.text:
A woman experiences vomiting every time she consumes spicy food. Vomiting is a coordinated reflex involving several gastrointestinal and respiratory actions.

Arrange the following physiological events in the correct sequence during vomiting:

1. The lower esophageal sphincter (LES) is open while the upper esophageal sphincter (UES) remains closed.
2. Strong contractions occur in the stomach.
3. Deep inspiration is taken against a closed glottis.
4. Pyloric sphincter relaxes.
5. Both LES and UES open.
6. Reverse peristalsis begins in the small intestine.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Step 6 - Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine:
    Vomiting is usually preceded by reverse peristalsis, starting from the lower ileum, pushing contents back toward the stomach. This helps load the stomach with intestinal contents before expulsion.
  • Step 4 - Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter:
    To allow intestinal contents to flow backward into the stomach, the pyloric sphincter (between stomach and duodenum) must relax. This facilitates retrograde movement.
  • Step 2 - Strong contractions in the stomach:
    Once the stomach is filled by reverse peristalsis, forceful contractions of the stomach occur, increasing intragastric pressure, prepping for expulsion.
  • Step 3 - Inspiration against a closed glottis:
    The vomiting center in the brainstem activates respiratory muscles, leading to a deep inspiration against a closed glottis. This increases intra-abdominal and thoracic pressure and protects the airway.
  • Step 1 - LES is open and UES is still closed:
    At this point, the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) opens to let gastric contents move upward into the esophagus, while the UES stays closed temporarily to prevent premature ejection into the mouth or aspiration.
  • Step 5 - Both LES and UES open:
    Finally, both sphincters open completely, allowing the vomitus to be expelled through the mouth.

Key takeaway:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with intensely pruritic vesicles and excoriations on the elbows, knees, and buttocks. He also reports occasional bloating and diarrhoea. Which systemic condition is most likely associated with this dermatosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's intensely pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, and buttocks) are characteristic of dermatitis herpetiformis (a type of subepidermal group of disorders).

Bloating and diarrhoea point towards malabsorption and, this condition is closely associated with celiac disease, linking the skin findings to an underlying gluten-sensitive enteropathy.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis (DH)

  • Chronic autoimmune blistering disease
  • Intensely pruritic.
  • Affects extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, buttocks, scalp).
  • Associated with gluten-sensitive enteropathy (GSE).
  • IgA autoantibodies against transglutaminases deposited in superficial papillary dermis.
  • Genetics:
    • Strong HLA association: HLA-DQ2 (major), HLA-DQ8 (minor).
    • The target antigen is Transglutaminase 3.
  • Clinical Features
    • History: Severe itch; possible gastrointestinal symptoms from GSE
    • Presentation:
      • Grouped red papulovesicles over extensor surfaces.
      • Papulo-vesicular lesions, often excoriated due to pruritus.
      • Bilaterally Symmetrical distribution.
      • Mucosal changes rare
  • Investigation:
    • Anti-TTG antibody test
    • Histopathology: Subepidermal cleft, papillary tip neutrophilic abscesses.
    • Direct immunoflourescence: Granular deposition of IgA at the basement membrane zone.
  • Management:
    • First-line: strict gluten-free diet
    • Drug: dapsone or sulfonamides.
  • Systemic association:
    • Gluten-sensitive enteropathy/ coeliac disease.

Explanation of other options:

Hepatitis C (Option B): More commonly associated with lichen planus rather than dermatitis herpetiformis.

HIV infection (Option C): Can cause various skin manifestations but grouped extensor vesicles with severe pruritus are not typical.

Systemic lupus erythematosus (Option D): Usually presents with malar rash, discoid lesions, painless oral ulcers, lupus hair or photosensitive rashes, not symmetrical pruritic vesicles on extensor surfaces.

Key Takeaway:

  • Dermatitis herpetiformis presents as intensely itchy, symmetrical vesicles on extensor surfaces and is strongly associated with celiac disease.

questions.text: All of the following gases are implicated in DCS except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

DCS or decompression sickness (Caisson's disease) is not associated with carbon dioxide.

  • Decompression sickness (DCS) is a condition that can be life-threatening.
  • It occurs when dissolved gases, most often nitrogen, form bubbles within the blood and tissues.
  • The disorder mainly affects people exposed to sudden changes in surrounding pressure.
  • Commonly affected groups include scuba divers, high-altitude aviators, and those working in pressurized environments.

Mechanism:

  • Decompression sickness (DCS) results from a rapid decrease in ambient pressure.
  • This pressure drop causes gases dissolved in body tissues to come out of solution and form bubbles in the bloodstream.
  • Nitrogen is the main gas involved, as it is the most abundant component of the atmosphere and is commonly present in divers’ breathing mixtures.
  • Although normally inert, nitrogen can trigger vascular blockage and inflammatory reactions when it accumulates excessively in blood vessels.

Important terms:

  • Bends: Nitrogen affecting the joints.
  • Prickles: Nitrogen affecting the nerve endings in the skin.

Management:

  • Oxygen supplementation.
  • Recompression chamber.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537264/

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman with known systemic sclerosis presents to the emergency department with acute shortness of breath and blurred vision. Blood pressure was measured to be 210/120 mm Hg, Laboratory investigations reveal creatinine of 3.8 mg/dL (baseline 0.9). Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical features of acute shortness of breath and blurred vision, along with rapidly declining kidney function and hypertension in a patient with systemic sclerosis, suggest a diagnosis of scleroderma renal crisis for which the most appropriate first-line treatment is Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors.

  • Scleroderma renal crisis is a severe complication of systemic sclerosis (SSc), and presents as abrupt hypertension and progressive renal failure.
  • The condition is driven by obliterative vasculopathy of renal arteries and arterioles, leading to vasospasm, reduced renal blood flow, and juxtaglomerular renin release.
  • ACE inhibitors (short-acting, titrated) are the cornerstone of therapy and have transformed survival. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • Additional agents (angiotensin II receptor blockers, calcium channel blockers, endothelin-1 blockers, prostacyclins, direct renin inhibitors) may be needed for resistant hypertension.

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a rare disease with an unknown cause, progressive course, and significant disability and mortality. Patients are classified broadly into:

  • Diffuse cutaneous SSc: Widespread skin thickening beginning distally and moving proximally, often associated with early visceral involvement (lung, kidney).
  • Limited cutaneous SSc: Skin involvement limited to fingers, distal limbs, and face, with later visceral manifestations. A subset with calcinosis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia is known as CREST syndrome.

Pathology: The hallmark is widespread obliterative microangiopathy and fibrosis.

Initial presentation in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis: Puffy fingers, pruritus, oedema → progresses to induration and fibrosis with contractures, pigmentation changes, arthralgias, and muscle weakness.

Initial presentation in limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis: More indolent. Raynaud's phenomenon precedes skin or organ disease by years. Late features include GERD, digital ulcers, PAH, and biliary cirrhosis.

Other clinical features

  • Raynaud's Phenomenon: Most common early sign, caused by episodic vasospasm. Can progress to digital ulcers or gangrene.
  • Skin: Symmetrical thickening from distal to proximal. "Salt-and-pepper" pigmentation, telangiectasia, calcinosis, microstomia, mask-like facies.
  • Pulmonary: Includes interstitial lung disease (ILD) and pulmonary vascular disease.
  • Gastrointestinal: Features include dysphagia, reflux, gastroparesis, bacterial overgrowth, malabsorption, and GAVE ("watermelon stomach").
  • Renal: Scleroderma renal crisis with accelerated hypertension and acute kidney injury
  • Cardiac: Includes pericarditis, myocardial fibrosis, conduction defects, arrhythmias, and heart failure.
  • Musculoskeletal: Carpal tunnel syndrome, arthralgia, contractures, tendon friction rubs, and myopathy.
  • Hematologic: Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia during renal crisis.

Autoantibodies seen in systemic sclerosis:

  • Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70): linked with ILD and poor outcomes.
  • Anti-centromere: linked with CREST syndrome and PAH
  • RNA polymerase III: linked with scleroderma renal crisis.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Choose the correct option

Assertion (A): Myasthenia gravis is characterised by impaired transmission at the neuromuscular junction and fatiguable weakness
Reason (R): In myasthenia gravis, autoantibodies most often target presynaptic receptors at the neuromuscular junction
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Myasthenia gravis is characterised by impaired transmission at the neuromuscular junction and fatigueable weakness, which arises due to autoantibodies that most often target acetylcholine receptors on the post-synaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction.

  • Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction disorder marked by weakness and easy fatigability of skeletal muscles.
  • The underlying defect is a reduction in functional acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) located on the post-synaptic membrane due to antibody-mediated autoimmune destruction.
  • This disrupts neuromuscular transmission, resulting in fewer activated muscle fibres with repeated activity, a phenomenon called myasthenic fatigue.
  • In some patients, antibodies target muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) or LRP4, affecting clustering of AChRs. T regulatory cell dysfunction also contributes to autoimmunity.

Clinical Features

  • MG affects all age groups, with peaks in women in early adulthood and men in later decades. Women are more commonly affected than men.
  • Symptoms include fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with activity and improves with rest.
  • Common early features are ptosis, diplopia, dysarthria, dysphagia, and difficulty chewing.
  • Bulbar, neck, limb, and respiratory muscles may be involved.
  • Weakness typically follows a pattern: ocular, facial, and proximal limb muscles are commonly affected, while deep tendon reflexes and sensory function remain intact.
  • Severe respiratory weakness may cause myasthenic crisis.

Diagnosis

Diagnosis relies on clinical suspicion supported by tests:

  • Autoantibody testing: Anti-AChR antibodies are positive in majority of generalised MG cases and ~50% of ocular MG; MuSK and LRP4 antibodies may be present in some seronegative cases.
  • Electrophysiology: Repetitive nerve stimulation shows a decremental response; single-fiber EMG is more sensitive.
  • Ice-pack test: Improvement in ptosis after cooling is supportive.
  • Imaging: Chest CT/MRI may detect thymoma or thymic hyperplasia
  • Differential diagnoses include Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome, botulism, thyroid disorders, mitochondrial myopathies, and congenital myasthenic syndromes.

Associated Disorders

  • About 75% of patients with AChR antibody-positive MG show thymic abnormalities, such as hyperplasia or thymoma.
  • MG is also associated with other autoimmune diseases such as thyroiditis, lupus, and rheumatoid arthritis.

Treatment

  • Anticholinesterase medications such as Pyridostigmine is first-line, improving neuromuscular transmission.
  • Glucocorticoids and immunosuppressants, thymectomy, and rapid immunotherapy through plasmapheresis and IV immunoglobulin (IVIg) are other treatment modalities.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with major depressive disorder plans to discontinue her antidepressant treatment in the near future due to personal reasons. She has been on long-term therapy and is concerned about potential discontinuation symptoms. Which of the following antidepressants is the most appropriate choice to minimize the risk of withdrawal effects during gradual tapering?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fluoxetine has a long half-life (1-2 weeks) and an active metabolite (norfluoxetine), which leads to the least withdrawal symptoms when discontinued.
  • Paroxetine, venlafaxine, and desvenlafaxine have shorter half-lives, lack active metabolites, and are more prone to causing intense discontinuation syndrome.

Note:

For SSRIs/SNRIs, the therapeutic index is wide and not tightly correlated with serum drug concentration. Dosage adjustments are driven primarily by clinical response and management of side effects.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Paroxetine (Option A): Paroxetine is highly associated with dry mouth, urinary retention, sedation, and increased sexual dysfunction in addition to severe withdrawal symptoms, due to lack of active metabolites and short half-life.

Venlafaxine (Option B): Causes increased anxiety, nausea, headache, and intense withdrawal due to short half-life and lack of active metabolites.

Desvenlafaxine (Option D):Similar to venlafaxine, causes nausea, dizziness, and nervousness, along with high discontinuation risk.

questions.text: Which laboratory finding is specific for vitamin B12 deficiency and not seen in folate deficiency?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is a coenzyme for methyl malonyl-CoA mutase (converts methyl malonyl-CoA → succinyl-CoA).

Deficiency blocks this step, causing methylmalonic acid accumulation, which damages myelin and explains the neurologic deficits seen in B12 deficiency (eg, subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord).

Folate deficiency does not affect MMA metabolism, making this the most specific discriminator.

  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum bound to intrinsic factor (IF, secreted by gastric parietal cells).
  • Contains cobalt in a corrin ring; also required as cofactor for methionine synthase (homocysteine → methionine).
  • Deficiency causes: megaloblastic anemia, peripheral neuropathy, hyperhomocysteinemia, and methylmalonic aciduria.
  • Causes: pernicious anemia (anti-IF antibodies), strict vegetarian diet, Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm), ileal resection/disease (eg, Crohn's).
  • Neurologic finding: Subacute combined degeneration (SACD): demyelination of dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts → sensory ataxia and UMN signs (spasticity, Babinski); loss of vibration/proprioception; paresthesias.
  • Schilling test (historical gold standard):
    • Low urinary excretion = B12 malabsorption.
    • Correction with IF = pernicious anemia.
    • Correction with pancreatic enzymes = pancreatic insufficiency.
    • Correction with antibiotics = bacterial overgrowth.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Elevated homocysteine (Option B): Elevated in both B12 and folate deficiency due to blocked methionine synthase. Not specific.

Hypersegmented neutrophils (Option C): Common to all megaloblastic anemias (B12, folate).

Megaloblastic anemia (Option D): Seen in both B12 (more classically) and folate deficiency due to impaired DNA synthesis.

Key Takeaway

Elevated MMA and neurologic deficits (SACD) are unique to vitamin B12 deficiency. Folate deficiency causes megaloblastic anemia and hyperhomocysteinemia but never methylmalonic aciduria or neurologic damage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient presented with symptoms suggestive of rhinosinusitis. Clinically, there are multiple nasal polyps are seen on the right side on anterior rhinoscopy. A CT scan is shown in the following image. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario of nasal polypi and the characteristic CT findings here points to the diagnosis of allergic fungal rhinosinusitis.

  • Fungal sinusitis is caused most commonly by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus, and it is a type I hypersensitivity reaction.
  • It is seen in immunocompetent patients.
  • The typical mucin in the nose of this patient will be very thick, recinous with a peanut butter appearance.
  • Microscopically, it has got eosinophilic Charcot-Leyden crystals and fungal hyphae.
  • The nasal polyps are very characteristic on a CT scan because these polyps have fungal debris, and in the given picture, there are typical heterogeneous opacities, unlike other polyps, like ethmoidal or antrochoanal that show homogenous opacities.
  • Double-density shadows or heterogeneous opacities on a CT scan are typical of allergic fungal sinusitis.
  • The Bent and Kuhn classification of EFRS:
    • Major Criteria
      • Type 1 Hypersensitivity
      • Nasal polyposis
      • Characteristic CT findings (serpiginous hyperdense material with a peripheral rim of hypodense mucosa, with or without expansion of the involved sinus wall).
      • Eosinophilic mucin without invasion
      • Positive fungal stain (fungal hyphae)
    • Minor Criteria
      • Asthma
      • Unilateral disease
      • Bone erosion
      • Fungal cultures
      • Charcot-Leyden crystals
      • Serum eosinophilia
    • According to the Bent and Kuhn classification, in the given scenario, there is hypersensitivity type I, polyposis, and characteristic CT findings.

Allergic rhinitis (Option A): Causes nasal obstruction, rhinorrhea, and sneezing but does not produce nasal polyps with allergic mucin or double density sign.

Antrochoanal polyp (Option B): Usually a single, unilateral nasal mass growing backwards with homogenous opacity in a CT scan. It usually arises from the maxillary sinus and extends into the choana, not multiple polyps.

Inverted papilloma of nose (Option C) or Ringertz tumour is a pinkish/ reddish firm nasal mass with epistaxis. Mostly seen in males aged 40-60 years. It is a benign but locally invasive tumor, usually unilateral.

choices.text: They act as abortifacients by disrupting an established implantation.
They inhibit ovulation by delaying follicular development and preventing luteinizing hormone (LH) surge.
They cause thickening of cervical mucus, preventing sperm ascent.
They induce endometrial shedding to prevent nidation.

questions.text: A medical student asks about the primary mechanism of action of emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs). Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding how ECPs like Levonorgestrel and Ulipristal prevent pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The primary and most evidence-based mechanism of action for ECPs (LNG and UPA) is inhibition or delay of ovulation.
  • UPA, a progesterone receptor modulator, directly inhibits follicular rupture even after the LH surge has begun. LNG likely works by delaying the LH surge. They are not abortifacients and are ineffective if implantation has already occurred (Option A and option D ruled out). Other mechanisms like endometrial changes are theorized but not primary.
  • While progestins can thicken cervical mucus, this is a mechanism of ongoing hormonal contraception, not the primary mechanism for emergency (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • ECPs work primarily by inhibiting or delaying ovulation.
  • They are not abortifacients and cannot terminate an established pregnancy.

questions.text: A 6-day-old neonate presents with jaundice involving palms and soles. The baby is irritable, feeding poorly, and has a high-pitched cry. The posture shown in the image is noted. Episodes of generalized rigidity are also seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The baby has severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (jaundice up to palms/soles) with neurologic manifestations - irritability, high-pitched cry, poor feeding, and opisthotonus/retrocollis (backward arching). These are classical of Stage II Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy (ABE).

Bilirubin-Induced Neurological Damage (BIND):

  • Pathophysiology: Unconjugated bilirubin crosses the immature blood-brain barrier → deposits in basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei → neurotoxicity.
  • Stages of Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy:
    • Stage I (Reversible): Lethargy, poor feeding, hypotonia, decreased sucking, bulging fontanelle.
    • Stage II (Intermediate): Irritability, high-pitched cry, opisthotonus, retrocollis, seizures, increased tone.
    • Stage III (Irreversible): Apnoea, persistent posturing, UMN signs, shrill cry, death.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Neonatal Tetanus (option B): Presents at 3-14 days with inability to suck, risus sardonicus, generalized spasms, and opisthotonus. Key difference: no jaundice, history of unsterile cord care/unvaccinated mother. In this case, jaundice is central, pointing to bilirubin encephalopathy.

Hypocalcaemia seizures (option C): Present with tremors, jitteriness, seizures; no jaundice or opisthotonus.

Congenital hypothyroidism (option D): May cause prolonged jaundice but associated with hypotonia, macroglossia, and umbilical hernia, not acute opisthotonic posturing with rigidity.

Key Takeaway

Opisthotonus and retrocollis in a jaundiced neonate = Stage II Acute Bilirubin Encephalopathy. Tetanus also causes opisthotonus but without jaundice, helping distinguish the two.

questions.text: An alcoholic person hears the noises of small insects. He knows it well that it is because of alcohol effect. As per history, he took his last peg of alcohol 18 hours before, as he promised his family that he won't be taking alcohol again. What is he experiencing?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient is aware that the perception is not real, which is the defining feature of a pseudohallucination.

  • Pseudohallucination refers to imaginal experiences, but its exact relationship to true hallucinations is unclear.
  • Hallucinations vs Pseudohallucinations: True hallucinations are perceived as real by the patient and can affect any of the five senses-most commonly auditory in psychiatric conditions like schizophrenia. Examples include voices commenting on behavior, multiple voices conversing, or visual and tactile experiences.

Criteria to diagnose hallucination:

  • It occurs in the absence of any stimulus
  • As vivid as real
  • Experienced in outer objective space
  • Involuntary

Alcohol withdrawal:

  • Timeline of symptoms:
    • 6-8 hrs → Tremor
    • >12 hrs → Psychotic/perceptual symptoms (hallucinations, delusions)
    • >24 hrs → Seizures
    • > 48 hrs, up to 72 hrs (sometimes within a week) → Delirium tremens (DTs)

Auditory hallucination (Option A): The person would perceive the sound as real without insight; not the case here.

Illusion (Option B): Illusions involve misperceiving a real external stimulus, but there are no actual stimulus present.

Delirium tremens (Option C): DTs involve confusion, severe autonomic hyperactivity, and disorientation, which the patient does not have. The most severe complication of withdrawal; considered a medical emergency with significant morbidity and mortality. Untreated DTs mortality is around 20%, often due to associated medical illnesses (pneumonia, liver/renal failure, or heart disease).

choices.text: Add inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) to his current regimen
Initiate dupilumab therapy due to evidence of type 2 inflammation
Start long-term oral glucocorticoid therapy for maintenance control

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with moderate-to-severe COPD (GOLD Group D) continues to have frequent exacerbations despite treatment with LABA + LAMA. His eosinophil count is 320 cells/µL. According to the GOLD 2025 report, what is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among the given options, the most appropriate next step is to add an inhaled corticosteroid (ICS) to his current regimen, as his eosinophil count is > 300 cells/µL.

  • COPD is a persistent condition marked by ongoing respiratory symptoms and fixed airflow obstruction.
  • It includes emphysema (destruction of alveoli with enlarged air spaces), chronic bronchitis (chronic cough with phlegm), and small airway disease (narrowing and reduction of small bronchioles).
  • The defining feature is airflow obstruction confirmed by spirometry.
  • The disorder commonly develops after long-term exposure to harmful environmental factors, especially cigarette smoking and biomass fuel use.

The management of COPD is summarised in the table below.

choices.text: ~19%; The reason is the low specificity of the test.
~19%; The reason is the low prevalence of the disease in the population.
~90%; The reason is the high sensitivity of the test.
~80%; The reason is the high specificity of the test.

questions.text: A new rapid diagnostic test (RDT) for visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) is evaluated in a endemic region with a prevalence of 5%. The test has a sensitivity of 90% and a specificity of 80%. If a person from this region tests positive with this RDT, what is the probability that they actually have the disease (Positive Predictive Value), and what is the primary reason for this value?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

Calculation of the Positive Predictive Value (PPV):
The best way to understand this is to assume a population and calculate the numbers.

Here, assume a population of 10,000 people.

  • Diseased individuals: Prevalence is 5%
    • Number of diseased = 5% of 10,000 = 500
  • Non-diseased individuals: 10,000 - 500 = 9,500
  • True Positives (TP): Sick people who test positive.
    • Sensitivity = 90% = TP / (All Diseased)
    • Therefore, TP = 90% of 500 = 450
  • False Negatives (FN): Sick people who test negative = 500 - 450 = 50
  • True Negatives (TN): Healthy people who test negative.
    • Specificity = 80% = TN / (All Non-Diseased)
    • Therefore, TN = 80% of 9,500 = 7,600
  • False Positives (FP): Healthy people who test positive = 9,500 - 7,600 = 1,900
  • Total Positive Tests = TP + FP = 450 + 1,900 = 2,350
  • Positive Predictive Value (PPV) = (True Positives / All Positive Tests) * 100
    • PPV = (450 / 2,350) * 100 ≈ 19.15%

Interpretation of the Reason for the Low PPV

  • The PPV is low (~19%) despite good sensitivity (90%). This suggests that out of all positive tests, over 80% are false positives.
  • This occurs primarily because of the low prevalence (5%) of the disease in the population.
  • When a disease is rare, even a test with good specificity will generate a large number of false positives because the number of healthy people (9,500) is vastly larger than the number of sick people (500).
  • The specificity (80%) is not ideal and contributes to the problem, but it is not the primary reason. In low-prevalence settings, PPV remains low unless specificity is very high; low prevalence is the primary driver here. The low prevalence is the fundamental driver.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

~19%; The reason is the low specificity (Option A): While low specificity is a contributing factor, it is not the primary reason. The major issue is the low prevalence.

~90%; The reason is the high sensitivity (Option C): This confuses PPV with sensitivity. Sensitivity is the probability the test is positive given the person is sick. PPV is the probability the person is sick given the test is positive. They are not the same.

~80%; The reason is the high specificity (Option D): This is incorrect. The PPV is not 80%, and high specificity would increase PPV, not explain a low value.

Key takeaway:

  • This question highlights a fundamental principle of screening: the Positive Predictive Value of a test is highly dependent on the prevalence of the disease in the population being tested.
  • A test performs poorly as a screening tool in low-prevalence populations due to a high nuber of false positives.

choices.text: Cytokine-mediated inflammatory response due to rapid spirochete lysis
Direct toxic effect of penicillin on tissues
Secondary bacterial infection causing systemic inflammatory response

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman with secondary syphilis is started on benzathine penicillin G. Four hours after the first dose, she develops chills, fever, headache, myalgias, and arthralgias. What is the pharmacological mechanism responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The symptoms represent the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction (JHR), an acute inflammatory response caused by the rapid killing of Treponema pallidum spirochetes by penicillin.

  • Penicillin causes rapid lysis of spirochetes, releasing lipoproteins and other antigenic components.
  • These microbial components trigger release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as TNF-α, IL-6, and IL-8.
  • The cytokine surge causes fever, chills, headache, myalgia, and arthralgia usually within hours of treatment initiation.
  • JHR is self-limiting and not a penicillin allergy or direct toxicity
  • The correct management is to continue penicillin therapy without interruption, as it does not indicate allergy or treatment failure.
    Symptomatic management with antipyretics (e.g., paracetamol) helps relieve chills, fever, myalgias, and arthralgias.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin (Option A): This is not possible, as it will be seen soon after the administration of the drug not after 4 hours.

Direct toxic effect of penicillin on tissues (Option C): Penicillin is a drug with least toxic effects on tissues and hence not the right answer in the scenario.

Secondary bacterial infection causing systemic inflammatory response (Option D): This is not the suitable option as well, since the symptoms of the patient are seen after the administration of penicillin.

Key Takeaways:

choices.text: Single oral cholecalciferol 600,000 IU (STOSS) plus calcium for 2 weeks, then stop
Cholecalciferol 3,000-6,000 IU daily for 12 weeks with oral calcium 30-75 mg/kg/day for ≥2 months, then maintenance 600 IU/day
Calcitriol 0.25-0.5 μg/day with oral phosphate supplementation; avoid calcium
Cholecalciferol 2,000 IU daily for 12 weeks without calcium; maintenance 400 IU/day thereafter

questions.text: A 14-month-old boy is noted to have bowing of the legs and widening of the wrists. Laboratory investigations show: Ca 8.1 mg/dL, PO₄ 2.7 mg/dL, ALP 1,600 IU/L, PTH 220 pg/mL. X-ray of the wrist reveals metaphyseal cupping and fraying. What is the most appropriate treatment regimen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child presents with clinical (bowing, wrist widening) and radiographic features (metaphyseal cupping/fraying) consistent with rickets.

The lab profile shows:

  • Low-normal calcium (8.1 mg/dL)
  • Low phosphate (2.7 mg/dL)
  • Very high ALP (1,600 IU/L)
  • Elevated PTH (220 pg/mL)

This pattern = nutritional vitamin D deficiency rickets (secondary hyperparathyroidism). The most appropriate treatment is:

  • Vitamin D3 (cholecalciferol) 3,000-6,000 IU daily for 12 weeks (>1 year child).
  • Oral calcium 30-75 mg/kg/day for at least 2 months.
  • Maintenance vitamin D: 600 IU/day after correction.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Single oral cholecalciferol 600,000 IU (STOSS) plus calcium for 2 weeks, then stop (option A): Old regimen, not preferred due to toxicity risk and less effective recovery.

Calcitriol 0.25-0.5 μg/day with oral phosphate supplementation; avoid calcium (option C): Used for familial hypophosphatemic rickets or renal tubular disorders, not nutritional deficiency.

Cholecalciferol 2,000 IU daily for 12 weeks without calcium; maintenance 400 IU/day (option D): Inadequate dose for >1 year; omission of calcium is incorrect.

Key Takeaway

Nutritional rickets presents with bowing, wrist widening, low PO₄, high ALP, and high PTH. The correct regimen is daily cholecalciferol (3,000-6,000 IU for >1 year) plus calcium supplementation, followed by maintenance dosing.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of positive eugenics?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Positive eugenics aims to improve the genetic composition of the population by encouraging individuals with desirable traits or genotypes to reproduce. Among the options, encouraging marriage among intelligent persons directly aligns with this goal, as it seeks to increase the frequency of socially valuable traits in the next generation.

Eugenics, a term proposed by Francis Galton, refers to the science of improving the genetic endowment of human populations. It has two broad types:

  • Negative eugenics - aims at reducing the frequency of hereditary diseases and disabilities by preventing reproduction among those with undesirable traits.
  • Examples: sterilization of unfit individuals, discouraging marriage among carriers of serious genetic disorders.
  • Positive eugenics- aims at increasing the frequency of desirable traits by encouraging reproduction among individuals with favorable characteristics.
    • Example: encouraging marriage and childbearing among intelligent or healthy persons.

Sterilization of unfit individuals (Option A) belongs to negative eugenics.

Segregation of criminals and birth control measures (Option C & D) do not directly target genetic improvement of the population and therefore are not examples of positive eugenics.

choices.text: Adenoid hypertrophy and otitis media with effusion
Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and Otitis media with effusion

questions.text: A 7-year-old child patient has mild hearing loss along with nasal obstruction, crowding of upper teeth and a dull voice. The otoscopy examination finding is given in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows air bubbles trapped in the glue behind the tympanic membrane, and the clinical scenario states nasal obstruction, crowding of upper teeth and dull voice, which point to the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy and otitis media with effusion.

Definition & Clinical Features

  • OME = accumulation of mucus in the middle ear ± mastoid air cell system.
  • Chronic OME = persistence of fluid for ≥3 months.
  • In children, it may present with:
    • Hearing loss
    • Delayed speech and language development
    • Poor social behavior
    • Balance difficulties (in younger children)
  • Often preceded by respiratory tract infection and otalgia with episodic history.

Histology:

  • Normal lining: Eustachian tube & anterior mesotympanum → ciliated, pseudostratified columnar respiratory epithelium with goblet cells & mucus-secreting glands.
  • Pathological changes in OME:
    • Inflammation of epithelium → serous or mucoid effusion.
    • Cuboidal middle ear mucosa replaced by thicker pseudostratified mucus-secreting epithelium.
    • Goblet cells frequently present; mucus-secreting glands may form.
    • Ciliary lining becomes less efficient at clearing secretions into nasopharynx.
  • Submucosa: oedematous, inflamed, dilated blood vessels, increased macrophages, plasma cells, and lymphocytes.

Characteristics of the Effusion in Otitis Media with Effusion (OME):

  • The effusion is predominantly composed of glycoprotein mucin.
  • Other components include:
    • Secretory immunoglobulin A (IgA)
    • Lysozyme
    • Interleukins and other inflammatory cytokines
  • Effusion shows:
    • Rheological adhesiveness (sticky, viscous nature)
    • Poor mucociliary transportability (difficult to clear)
  • These features contribute to persistence of the effusion and indicate the need for surgical drainage and middle ear ventilation.

Glue ear (Option A) and adenoid hypertrophy (Option C) are not complete diagnoses when mentioned alone. Hence, incorrect options.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and Otitis media with effusion (Option D): This is seen in adults rather than children. Here, the scenario clearly mentions features of adenoid hypertrophy, nasal obstruction, crowding of upper teeth and a dull voice pointing to the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with failure to thrive, developmental delay, seizures, and brittle hair. Labs show low serum copper and ceruloplasmin. Which enzyme is defective in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Menkes disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, leading to impaired intestinal copper absorption and systemic copper deficiency.
  • Menke disease is associated with ATP7A absence, leading to unabsorbed copper from the gut. This, in turn, reduces the formation of ceruloplasmin (thus the clinical presentation in the given scenario).
  • Copper is a required cofactor for lysyl oxidase, the enzyme responsible for covalent cross-linking of collagen fibrils.
  • Without functional lysyl oxidase, collagen has reduced tensile strength, producing connective tissue defects.
  • Clinical features: brittle "kinky" hair, hypotonia, seizures, developmental delay, failure to thrive.
  • Biochemical findings: low copper, low ceruloplasmin.
  • Contrast: Wilson disease (ATP7B mutation, copper accumulation in liver, brain, cornea).
  • Collagen synthesis step affected: extracellular cross-linking of fibrils.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Prolyl hydroxylase (Option A): Requires vitamin C, not copper; defective in scurvy.

Pyruvate dehydrogenase (Option C): Requires thiamine (B1), not copper; unrelated to collagen synthesis.

Transketolase (Option D): Requires thiamine pyrophosphate in the HMP shunt; unrelated to collagen.

Key Takeaway

Menkes disease = ATP7A mutation → copper deficiency → impaired lysyl oxidase → defective collagen cross-linking → kinky hair, seizures, developmental delay.

choices.text: All values are within ADA target goals
HbA1c, preprandial, and postprandial glucose are all above recommended targets
Only HbA1c is above target, while pre- and postprandial glucose are within range
Only preprandial glucose is above target, while HbA1c and postprandial glucose are controlled

questions.text:
A 52-year-old man with type 2 diabetes comes for follow-up. He has been on metformin and a GLP-1 receptor agonist. His recent lab values are:

1. HbA1c: 7.2%
2. Preprandial capillary glucose (average of 5 readings): 135 mg/dL
3. 2-hour postprandial glucose (average): 185 mg/dL

He has no major comorbidities and no history of hypoglycemia. According to the ADA 2025 guidelines which of the following statements is most appropriate regarding his current glycemic control?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this patient, HbA1c, preprandial and postprandial glucose are all above recommended targets in the majority of non-pregnant diabetic individuals according to ADA 2025 guidelines.

Notes:

  • Goals can be adjusted depending on patient factors such as age, comorbidities, cardiovascular risk, and risk of hypoglycemia.
  • Continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) can be used to better assess control.
  • Post-meal glucose should be checked 1-2 hours after the beginning of the meal, when glucose levels are expected to peak.

The primary aims of diabetes therapy are to:

  1. Relieve symptoms of high blood glucose.
  2. Prevent or lessen long-term complications affecting small and large blood vessels.
  3. Support patients in living as normal a life as possible.
    • To achieve these goals, clinicians and healthcare teams must set individualized glycemic targets, provide the necessary education and treatment to reach them, minimize hypoglycemia, and monitor for complications.
    • The American Diabetes Association (ADA) recommends using the Chronic Care Model, which stresses proactive, team-based care and health system designs that promote self-management, decision support, evidence-based guidelines, and community resources to encourage healthy lifestyles.

Reference:

https://diabetesjournals.org/care/article/48/Supplement_1/S128/157561/6-Glycemic-Goals-and-Hypoglycemia-Standards-of

choices.text: Soiled plastic catheters and IV tubes

questions.text: As per the Biomedical Waste Management rules (2016, amended 2018), which of the following wastes should be disposed in the red bag?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As per the Biomedical Waste Management rules (2016, amended 2018), soiled plastic catheters and IV tubes are disposed in the red bag.

Explanation of other options:

Human anatomical waste (Option A) is disposed of in a yellow bag, not red, as per biomedical waste rules.

Cytotoxic drugs (Option C) are disposed in yellow bags.

Metallic implants (Option D) are considered sharp or recyclable biomedical waste and are not disposed in red bags but in blue bags.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman suddenly lost consciousness. On awakening 1 hour later, she was unable to speak and could not move her right arm. Two months later, a head CT scan showed a large cystic area in the left parietal lobe. Which of the following pathologic processes most likely occurred in her brain?
questions.solution:
Explanation :
The clinical scenario describes a cerebral infarct (ischemic stroke) in the left parietal lobe, followed by a cystic cavity seen on CT after two months. In the central nervous system, ischemic injury results in liquefactive necrosis rather than coagulative necrosis, because of the high lipid content and hydrolytic enzyme activity.

Over time, macrophages clear necrotic tissue, leaving behind a fluid-filled cystic space.

Types of Necrosis:

Explanation of Other Options:

Karyolysis (Option C): This refers to nuclear fading (loss of basophilic staining due to DNAse activity) seen in necrotic cells. It is a microscopic nuclear change, not the gross morphologic pattern of necrosis, that explains the cystic lesion in this case.

questions.text: A recording of a simple muscle twitch from a frog's gastrocnemius muscle is shown along with a time trace created using a 100 Hz tuning fork. Based on this record, estimate the minimum tetanizing frequency for the muscle.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The tetanizing frequency of the muscle, based on the given diagram, is 20 Hz per second.

The minimum tetanizing frequency is the lowest stimulus rate that produces a sustained, fused contraction.

Tetanizing frequency = 1/contraction period

Here, the time trace was produced with a 100 Hz tuning fork, meaning it generated 100 oscillations each second.

Thus, each oscillation corresponds to a time span of 0.01 seconds.

On the recorded graph, the segment from point B (end of the latent phase) to point C (peak contraction) covers roughly five such oscillations.

Therefore, the contraction period is 5 × 0.01 = 0.05 seconds.

Applying the formula for tetanizing frequency (1 ÷ contraction period), we obtain 1 / 0.05 = 20 contractions per second.

Explanation of other options:

25/sec (Option A): Higher than necessary; tetanus would occur, but it is not the minimum rate.

18/sec (Option B): Below the calculated 20 Hz threshold, so individual twitches would still be visible.

12/sec (Option D): Far too low to achieve fusion; separate twitches remain clearly distinct.

Key takeaway:

Tetanization:

The characteristics of muscle contraction can be illustrated by observing single muscle twitches. When these individual twitches combine, the overall strength of contraction increases-a process known as summation. Summation can happen in two distinct manners:

  • Multiple fiber summation - achieved by recruiting more motor units to contract at the same time.
  • Frequency summation - produced by raising the rate of stimulation, which can ultimately result in tetanus.

If the stimulus frequency reaches a certain threshold, each successive contraction merges with the next, creating a smooth, continuous contraction of the entire muscle. This sustained response is called tetanization. Once this level is reached, further increases in stimulation frequency do not generate any additional rise in force.

There are two types of tetanus:

  • Complete tetanus - no relaxation occurs between individual stimuli, giving a steady contraction.
  • Incomplete tetanus - brief intervals of partial relaxation are present between the combined stimuli.

choices.text: Both A and R are correct, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are correct, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is correct, but R is incorrect.
A is incorrect, but R is correct.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old hypertensive male patient is currently prescribed Metoprolol for hypertension and post-myocardial infarction prophylaxis. The patient is admitted to the hospital with complaints of chest pain, and the attending physician also prescribes Verapamil for rate control.
Assertion (A):The combination of Metoprolol and Verapamil can lead to severe bradycardia and atrioventricular (AV) block.
Reason (R):Both Metoprolol and Verapamil reduce heart rate and AV conduction by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors and L-type calcium channels, respectively.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Metoprolol is a beta-1 selective blocker → reduces heart rate and AV conduction.
  • Verapamil is a calcium channel blocker (non-dihydropyridine type) → decreases AV nodal conduction and myocardial contractility.
  • Their combination can synergistically lead to excessive suppression of the heart rate and AV node conduction, causing bradycardia and AV block.
  • Metoprolol blocks beta-1 adrenergic receptors → decreased sympathetic stimulation → reduced chronotropy and dromotropy.
  • Verapamil inhibits L-type calcium channels in cardiac muscle and AV node → slows conduction velocity and prolongs refractory period.
  • Both mechanisms together severely depress cardiac conduction, increasing the risk of sinus bradycardia and AV block.

Classification of Beta-blockers:

Uses of Beta-blockers:

  • Essential tremors, Migraine prophylaxis, Post-MI, Stable angina, Arrhythmias, Heart failure, Hypertension.
  • Beta-blockers are contraindicated in asthma (Option A of previous MCQ).
  • Mask symptoms of hypoglycemia in diabetics.

Cardiac side effects

  • Precipitation of an acute MI.
  • Sinus bradycardia and heart block.
  • Heart failure may exacerbate symptoms in patients with decompensated heart failure or preexisting myocardial dysfunction

Extracardiac side effects

  • Increased airway resistance; hence, it is contraindicated in patients with asthma due to bronchospasm.
  • Exacerbation of peripheral artery disease and worsen claudication and precipitate Raynaud's disease.
  • In Hypoglycemia, Beta-blockers mask the signs seen in a hypoglycemic patient, such as tachycardia.
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Depression, fatigue, and sexual dysfunction such as erectile dysfunction.
  • Weight gain

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK499986/

questions.text: A 3-kg term neonate is born apnoeic and limp. After 30 seconds of effective positive pressure ventilation and 60 seconds of chest compressions with 100% oxygen, the heart rate remains at 40/min. Umbilical venous access has been secured. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In neonatal resuscitation, if the heart rate remains <60/min despite 30 seconds of effective ventilation and 60 seconds of coordinated chest compressions with 100% oxygen, the next step is administration of epinephrine.
  • The recommended dose is 0.01-0.03 mg/kg IV (1:10,000 dilution), preferably via an umbilical venous catheter.

If HR remains <60/min after adequate ventilation and chest compressions for >60 seconds, epinephrine must be administered immediately.

  • Preferred (fastest) route: Umbilical venous catheter.
  • Second fastest (if UVC unavailable): Intraosseous (IO), preferred site = tibia.
  • Least effective: Endotracheal (ET); requires higher dose.

Doses:

  • Venous/IO: 0.2 mL/kg of 1:10,000 dilution (0.02 mg/kg)
  • Endotracheal: 1 mL/kg of 1:10,000 dilution (0.1 mg/kg) (used only if vascular access not yet available).

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Epinephrine 0.1 mg/kg IV using 1:10,000 dilution (Option B): Too high a dose; may cause fatal arrhythmias.

Epinephrine 0.01-0.03 mg/kg IV using 1:1,000 dilution (Option C): Wrong concentration; risk of overdose.

Epinephrine 0.01-0.03 mg/kg endotracheal using 1:10,000 dilution (Option D): Acceptable only if IV access not available; here, umbilical access is already secured, so IV is preferred.

Key Takeaway

In neonatal resuscitation, the drug of choice when HR <60/min despite ventilation and chest compressions is epinephrine 0.01-0.03 mg/kg IV, 1:10,000 dilution, via umbilical vein.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with progressive weakness, difficulty in breathing, drooping eyelids, and slurred speech, starting a few hours after a snake bite. The relative reports the snake resembled a common krait. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neurotoxic snake venom, likely from a common cobra and common krait, leads to respiratory failure by blocking neuromuscular transmission and inhibiting acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. The patient presents with classic neuroparalytic symptoms such as ptosis, muscle weakness, and respiratory depression.

  • PASV, i.e., Polyvalent antisnake venom is effective against 1. Common cobra, 2. Common krait, 3. Russel's viper, and 4. Saw scaled viper
  • Fixation of toxins
    • Common cobra → Neurotoxins get fixed at post synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has a role. (Atropine is given to counteract the muscarinic effects of neostigmine).
    • Common krait → Neurotoxins get fixed at pre-synaptic region. Hence, neostigmine has no role.

Here, the snake has been identified as Common krait. Hence, only PASV is given.

Snakebite: (Land snakes)

  • Neurotoxic Snakes (Elapidae):
    • Example: Common cobra, Common Krait
    • Mechanism: Neurotoxins inhibit acetylcholine at neuromuscular junction
    • Clinical Features: Ptosis, descending paralysis, respiratory muscle weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria
    • Complications: Respiratory failure
  • Vasculotoxic Snakes (Viperidae):
    • Example: Russell's viper, Saw-scaled viper
    • Mechanism: Hemolysis, coagulopathy, tissue necrosis
    • Clinical Features: Bleeding, DIC, local swelling, early wet gangrene, circulatory failure

Sea snakes: Musculotoxic, leading to respiratory failure as a result of paralysis of the diaphragm.

Primary management (First aid) in a case of snake bite:

  • Best is immobilization → By application of splint
  • Assurance/Reassurance
  • Do not wash the area of the bite.
  • No tourniquet application.
  • Sutherland wrapping: Pressure application by crepe bandage if the victim is expected to reach the hospital in more than 30 minutes but less than 3 hours. The bandage is wrapped over the bitten area as well as the entire limb with the limb placed in a splint. It should be capable of admitting a finger beneath it.
  • Keep the affected area below heart level to reduce the flow of venom.
  • No incision & suction.
  • No ice application.
  • No electrotherapy.

Hospital treatment

  • Wait and watch for signs & symptoms.
  • If indicated → Begin PASV (Polyvalent anti snake venom) with 10 vials.
  • PASV is effective against 1. Common cobra, 2. Common krait, 3. Russel's viper, and 4. Saw scaled viper
  • PASV produced by Hoffkine biopharmaceutical company neutralises venom of pit viper due to para-specific activity.
  • In the common cobra, toxins are fixed at the post-synaptic region, so neostigmine has a role.
  • In the common krait, toxins are fixed at the pre-synaptic region, so neostigmine has no role.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Check the blood coagulation profile (Option A): Coagulation tests are useful in viper bites, where coagulopathy is expected. This patient shows neurotoxic symptoms with no signs of coagulopathy or bleeding, making this step inappropriate at this stage.

Administer PASV + Neostigmine + Atropine (Option C)

As this is a bite from common krait, there is no role of neostigmine and atropine along with PASV

Epinephrine injection + IV Hydrocortisone (Option D): Epinephrine is used primarily for anaphylaxis or allergic reactions, not for neurotoxic snake venom effects. This patient's symptoms reflect neuromuscular blockade, not allergic pathology. Hydrocortisone is used for severe inflammation or shock. No clinical signs suggest systemic inflammation or shock in this case; thus, hydrocortisone is not indicated.

References:

https://nhm.gov.in/images/pdf/guidelines/nrhm-guidelines/stg/Snakebite_QRG.pdf

http://repository-tnmgrmu.ac.in/18612/1/14110400021mohanraj.pdf

choices.text: Calcific narrowing of the aortic valve causing turbulent outflow during systole
Regurgitant flow across the mitral valve during systole
Incomplete closure of the aortic valve
Narrowing of the mitral valve orifice

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with a history of long-standing hypertension presents with progressive exertional dyspnea. On examination, he has a slow-rising carotid pulse and a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur best heard at the right second intercostal space. The murmur radiates to the carotid arteries. Which of the following best explains this clinical finding?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario of dyspnea and syncope, along with the description of the murmur, is consistent with a diagnosis of aortic stenosis which, commonly arises due to calcific narrowing of the aortic valve, causing turbulent outflow during systole.

Aortic stenosis

Etiology and Pathogenesis:

  • In adults, AS usually arises from calcification of valve cusps, often related to bicuspid valves, chronic degeneration, or prior rheumatic disease.
  • The process resembles atherosclerosis, involving inflammation, lipid deposition, and fibrotic changes leading to calcium hydroxyapatite deposits.
  • Risk factors include hypertension, diabetes, smoking, chronic kidney disease, and metabolic syndrome.
  • Rheumatic disease causes leaflet scarring and commissural fusion, while a bicuspid aortic valve (BAV) is a frequent congenital defect associated with aneurysms and sometimes coarctation.

Pathophysiology

  • The narrowed valve produces a systolic pressure gradient between the left ventricle and the aorta.
  • Initially, concentric hypertrophy maintains cardiac output, but over time, this leads to impaired relaxation, increased oxygen demand, and myocardial fibrosis.
  • Severe AS is defined by a mean gradient >40 mmHg or a valve area <1 cm².
  • Progression eventually causes reduced stroke volume, low-flow states, and ischemia.

Symptoms

  • AS often remains silent until the valve area is critically reduced. The classic triad of exertional dyspnea, angina, and syncope develops once obstruction worsens.
  • Dyspnea results from pulmonary venous hypertension, angina from an oxygen supply-demand mismatch, and syncope from reduced cerebral perfusion during exertion.

Physical Findings

  • The carotid pulse is delayed and reduced (pulsus parvus et tardus).
  • A systolic thrill may be felt, and a harsh, crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur is best heard at the base of the heart and radiates to the carotids.
  • The murmur intensity correlates with severity, though it may soften with very low cardiac output.
  • Additional findings can include a loud S4 and paradoxical splitting of S2.

Treatment

  • Treatment of aortic stenosis involves avoiding strenuous activity in severe cases, with careful use of medications like beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, and nitroglycerin for symptom relief.
  • Surgery is indicated in symptomatic severe cases, those with reduced LV function, or patients with associated aneurysms or coronary disease, with surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) being the standard.
  • Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI) is increasingly used in older patients or those at high surgical risk, while younger patients are generally treated with SAVR due to limited long-term data on TAVI.

Explanation of other options:

Regurgitant flow across the mitral valve during systole (Option B): Describes mitral regurgitation, and the hallmark auscultatory sign of chronic severe mitral regurgitation is a systolic murmur of grade III/VI or louder. It is typically holosystolic, but in acute severe MR, it may have a decrescendo quality and end in mid-to-late systole. In chronic MR, the murmur is usually best heard at the apex and often radiates toward the axilla.

Incomplete closure of the aortic valve (Option C): This description fits aortic regurgitation. In chronic aortic regurgitation, the murmur is classically a high-pitched, blowing, decrescendo sound during diastole, most clearly heard at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space.

Narrowing of the mitral valve orifice (Option D): This characterises mitral stenosis. A characteristic opening snap occurs shortly after A2, with a shorter A2-OS interval reflecting greater severity. This is followed by a low-pitched, rumbling diastolic murmur heard best at the apex in the left lateral position.

Key-takeaway:

Heart murmurs observed in various conditions are depicted below.

choices.text: Prepare for an emergency peripartum hysterectomy

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman undergoes a vaginal delivery complicated by heavy postpartum bleeding. Uterine massage is performed, but the uterus remains atonic. She has already received IV oxytocin infusion, IM methylergometrine, and IV tranexamic acid within 1 hour of delivery. Despite this, the uterus remains boggy and bleeding continues. Her pulse is 100/min, BP is 110/70 mmHg, and she appears stable after fluid resuscitation. On further review, she has a history of mild asthma since childhood. What is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This is a case of primary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) due to uterine atony.
  • First-line medical management of atonic PPH includes:
    • Aggressive fluid resuscitation to maintain blood volume.
    • Bimanual uterine massage.
    • Injection tranexamic acid: 1 g in 100 mL NS within the first 3 hours of delivery.
    • Uterotonic drugs: oxytocin, methylergometrine, syntometrine, misoprostol, carboprost.
  • In this patient, oxytocin, methylergometrine, and TXA have already been given but bleeding persists.
  • The patient has bronchial asthma, making carboprost contraindicated due to the risk of bronchospasm.

At this stage, the next step is a mechanical intervention before resorting to surgical procedures.

  • Uterine balloon tamponade (Bakri balloon, Sengstaken-Blakemore tube, EBB system):
    • Highly effective.
    • Minimally invasive.
    • Fertility-preserving.
    • Works by instilling warm saline into the balloon placed inside the uterus, which compresses venous sinuses and controls bleeding.

If balloon tamponade fails, escalation is:

  • Stepwise devascularization (uterine or ovarian artery ligation).
  • Uterine compression sutures (B-Lynch).
  • Emergency hysterectomy as a definitive, life-saving option.

Explanation for other options:

Carboprost (Option A): Incorrect. Effective in atonic PPH but contraindicated in asthma.

B-Lynch suture (Option C): Incorrect. Surgical option indicated only if balloon tamponade fails or if bleeding is uncontrolled in unstable cases.

Hysterectomy (Option D): Incorrect. Definitive treatment but reserved for refractory cases after conservative methods have failed.

Key Takeaway:

In atonic PPH refractory to first-line measures, the escalation is:

  • Medical therapy (uterotonics + TXA).
  • Balloon tamponade as the next conservative, fertility-preserving option.
  • If ineffective, stepwise devascularization or compression sutures.
  • Hysterectomy is reserved as the last resort.

Carboprost is contraindicated in asthma, making balloon tamponade the correct next step in this patient.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with stage 5 chronic kidney disease presents with generalised weakness, bone pain, and nausea. Which of the following combinations best describes the typical abnormalities seen in advanced chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option B best describes the typical abnormalities seen in advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD)

CKD includes a spectrum of abnormalities in kidney structure or function, usually progressing with time.

  • Its severity is closely tied to GFR decline and the degree of albuminuria.
  • Stage 5 CKD (previously called end-stage renal disease) is when the kidneys can no longer maintain the balance of toxins, electrolytes, and fluid, requiring dialysis or transplantation.

Pathophysiology

CKD develops through two main mechanisms:

  1. Primary causes (genetic abnormalities, immune-mediated injury, inflammation, metabolic or microvascular damage, toxins).
  2. Secondary maladaptive mechanisms involving hyperfiltration and hypertrophy of surviving nephrons. These short-term adaptations eventually become harmful, leading to glomerular sclerosis, podocyte dysfunction, and progressive nephron loss.
  3. Activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS) and impaired tubuloglomerular feedback accelerate progression.
