  4. This explains the slow but continuous decline in renal function once damage is established.

Clinical and Laboratory Manifestations of CKD

  1. Fluid, Electrolyte, and Acid-Base Disorders
    • Sodium & Water: Expansion of extracellular fluid is common, worsening hypertension and heart failure risk. Hyponatremia may appear with advanced disease.
    • Potassium: Declining GFR leads to impaired excretion. Hyperkalemia is aggravated by acidosis, tissue breakdown, or RAAS-inhibiting drugs. Hypokalemia is less common but may occur with tubular dysfunction.
    • Acid-Base: Metabolic acidosis develops because of reduced ammonium excretion. Early CKD often shows hyperchloremic acidosis; advanced disease shifts to a high anion-gap acidosis. Acidosis contributes to bone loss and muscle wasting. (Options A and C ruled out)
  2. Calcium and Phosphate Metabolism
    • Pathophysiology: CKD reduces phosphate clearance, leading to hyperphosphatemia, decreases calcitriol synthesis, and increases FGF-23. Together, these result in hypocalcemia and stimulation of PTH secretion, resulting in secondary hyperparathyroidism. (Option D ruled out)
    • Bone Disease in CKD
      • Osteitis fibrosa cystica: due to high PTH
      • Osteomalacia: due to vitamin D deficiency
      • Adynamic bone disease: low turnover, often from oversuppression of PTH.
    • Clinical Features: Bone pain, fractures, and vascular/soft tissue calcification.
    • Calciphylaxis: A severe complication presenting with painful skin necrosis from vascular calcification, most often in advanced CKD.
  3. Anemia
    • Normocytic, normochromic anemia begins by stage 3 and is nearly universal by stage 4.
    • Primarily due to reduced erythropoietin production, compounded by shortened RBC survival and other factors such as iron deficiency or chronic inflammation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) has been using latanoprost nightly with good adherence, but her intraocular pressure (IOP) remains above target. The ophthalmologist wants to add a medication that primarily increases trabecular (conventional) outflow and also lowers episcleral venous pressure, providing a mechanism complementary to latanoprost's uveoscleral effect. Which drug is the most appropriate add-on?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient is already on Latanoprost, which increases uveoscleral outflow, providing potent IOP reduction.
  • Since IOP remains uncontrolled, an agent that targets the trabecular outflow pathway (and lowers episcleral venous pressure) is indicated.
  • Netarsudil is a Rho-kinase inhibitor that relaxes the trabecular meshwork and Schlemm’s canal (→ ↑ trabecular outflow) and lowers episcleral venous pressure; it also has a modest effect to ↓ aqueous production via norepinephrine transporter (NET) inhibition- making it the most appropriate add-on here.
  • Rho-kinase inhibitor → relaxes trabecular meshwork/Schlemm's canal → ↑ trabecular outflow + ↓ episcleral venous pressure (± modest ↓ production via NET inhibition)

Treatment of glaucoma: There are 3 types of treatment modalities:

  • Surgery
  • Laser
  • Medical management
  1. Treatment Modalities for POAG
    • Medical therapy (first-line).
    • Laser therapy (e.g., ALT, SLT, MLT).
    • Surgery (e.g., trabeculectomy).
  2. Medical Management
    Two mechanisms: decrease aqueous production and increase outflow.
    Topical drugs (mainstay):
    • β-blockers (Timolol, Betaxolol) → ↓ aqueous; contraindicated/caution in asthma/COPD and heart block.
    • α-agonists (Brimonidine, Apraclonidine) → dual effect (↓ production + ↑ uveoscleral outflow); avoid in infants/lactation due to CNS depression; pregnancy data limited.
    • Miotics (Pilocarpine) → ↑ trabecular outflow; S/E: pseudomyopia, retinal detachment, iris cysts.
    • Topical CAIs (Dorzolamide, Brinzolamide) → ↓ production; avoid in sulfa allergy.
    • Prostaglandin analogues (Latanoprost, Travoprost, Bimatoprost) → ↑ uveoscleral outflow; Latanoprost → iris pigmentation changes (heterochromia); Bimatoprost → ↑ outflow + hypertrichosis; use caution in active uveitis.
    • Newer agents - Netarsudil → ↑ trabecular outflow and ↓ EVP; SE: conjunctival hyperemia, vortex keratopathy.
      Systemic drugs (used short-term or acute):
    • CAIs (Acetazolamide, Methazolamide) → tingling, renal stones, metallic taste.
    • Hyperosmotics (Mannitol IV, Glycerol PO) → draw fluid; avoid in CHF/DM.
  3. Laser Therapy
    • Argon laser trabeculoplasty (ALT).
    • Selective laser trabeculoplasty (SLT).
    • Micropulse diode (MLT).
  4. Surgery
    • Trabeculectomy = most common filtration surgery → creates new channel for outflow.

choices.text: Loss of sensation in the first dorsal web space
Weakness of external rotation due to teres minor involvement
Wasting of thenar muscles with loss of thumb opposition

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents after a fall on his outstretched hand. X-ray shows a fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus. On examination, he can initiate shoulder abduction but is unable to continue it beyond 15°. There is numbness over the lateral shoulder region. Which of the following additional findings is MOST likely if the nerve involved is injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has surgical neck of humerus fracture → classically injures the axillary nerve.
  • Axillary nerve supplies:
  • Deltoid → loss of abduction beyond 15°.
  • Teres minor → weakness of external rotation.
  • It also carries sensation from the regimental badge area (lateral shoulder).
  • Thus, in addition to abduction weakness and lateral shoulder numbness, weakness of external rotation is the most specific associated finding.

Axillary Nerve

  • Origin & Course:
    • Arises from posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5, C6).
    • Initially:
      • Lateral to radial nerve
      • Posterior to axillary artery
      • Anterior to subscapularis
    • At the lower border of subscapularis → curves posteriorly, inferior to humeroscapular articular capsule.
    • Passes through the quadrangular space with posterior circumflex humeral vessels.
  • Clinical Features of Axillary Nerve Lesion:
    • Muscles affected: Deltoid (main), Teres minor
    • Effects:
      • Reduced strength and stamina of abduction & forward flexion
      • Active movement restricted by pain and sling restraint
      • Loss of sensation: variable; may be partial or complete
    • Compensations:
      • If suprascapular nerve + rotator cuff intact → patient may still initiate abduction and elevate arm nearly fully
    • Deficits:
      • Forward flexion & abduction reduced to 10-30% of normal
      • Extension with shoulder abducted also weakened
    • Sensory changes:
      • Area of hypoaesthesia or anaesthesia over distal deltoid ("regimental badge patch")
      • Loss of function in upper lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm
      • Venous occlusive changes (swelling) may be present
  • Surgical Considerations:
    • Most commonly injured nerve in proximal humerus fractures: Axillary nerve
    • At risk during fracture of surgical neck and during surgical approaches to proximal humerus.

Explanation of other options:

Loss of sensation in the first dorsal web space (Option A): Incorrect. This is due to radial nerve injury, not axillary nerve.

Wasting of thenar muscles with loss of thumb opposition (Option C): Incorrect. This is seen in median nerve injury, typically in carpal tunnel syndrome or supracondylar fracture.

Clawing of medial two fingers (Option D): Incorrect. This occurs in ulnar nerve injury, classically with medial epicondyle fracture or Guyon's canal syndrome.

Key Takeaway:

  • Surgical neck humerus fracture → Axillary nerve injury → Deltoid paralysis (abduction beyond 15°) + Teres minor paralysis (external rotation weakness) + Sensory loss over regimental badge area.

Reference:

  1. https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3535990/#

choices.text: Serial ESR and CRP to monitor resolution of inflammation
Serial platelet counts to look for thrombocytosis in subacute phase
Serial echocardiography at diagnosis, 7-10 days, and 6-8 weeks
Serial chest X-rays to monitor cardiac size and myocarditis

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy presents with 7 days of fever unresponsive to antibiotics. He has red cracked lips, bilateral conjunctival congestion, diffuse rash, and swelling of hands and feet. A cervical lymph node >1.5 cm is noted. Labs show leukocytosis, anemia, and raised ESR. He is started on IVIg and high-dose aspirin. Which is the most appropriate investigation to monitor disease progression and complications in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The child fulfils criteria for Kawasaki disease: fever >5 days plus four of the five cardinal features (mucosal changes, conjunctival congestion, rash, extremity changes, lymphadenopathy).

The most feared complication is coronary artery aneurysm and other cardiac involvement. Therefore, the essential monitoring tool is echocardiography, done:

  • At diagnosis
  • At 7-10 days
  • At 6-8 weeks

This helps detect coronary artery dilatation, aneurysms, myocarditis, or pericardial effusion.

Explanation of Incorrect Options

Serial ESR and CRP to monitor resolution of inflammation (option A): Nonspecific; inflammation markers normalize after IVIg, but they don't monitor coronary aneurysm risk.

Serial platelet counts to look for thrombocytosis in subacute phase (option B): Thrombocytosis is common after the first week but not a reliable measure for cardiac complications.

Serial chest X-rays to monitor cardiac size and myocarditis (option D): May detect cardiomegaly but cannot evaluate coronary artery involvement, which is the main risk in Kawasaki disease.

Key Takeaway

Kawasaki disease is diagnosed clinically. The most important investigation to monitor disease progression and complications is echocardiography, performed at diagnosis, 7-10 days, and 6-8 weeks.

questions.text: What is the correct order for frozen section staining (rapid H&E)?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The correct order for frozen section staining (rapid H&E) is: Sectioning → Fixation → Hematoxylin → Eosin → Mounting

Frozen Section Staining:

  1. Tissue Freezing
    • Fresh specimen received intraoperatively.
    • Placed on metal chuck with OCT medium (Optimal Cutting Temperature).
    • Rapid freezing in cryostat at - 20°C to - 30°C → solidifies tissue for cutting.
  2. Sectioning
    • Cut thin sections (4-10 μm) using cryostat microtome blade.
    • Sections picked up on warm glass slide for adherence.
  3. Fixation
    • Immediate immersion in 95% ethanol/methanol (30-60 sec).
    • Stabilizes tissue & prepares for staining.
  4. Rinsing
    • Brief rinse in distilled water to remove excess fixative.
  5. Hematoxylin Staining
    • Immerse in hematoxylin (15-60 sec).
    • Stains nuclei blue-purple (basophilic structures).
  6. Bluing
    • Rinse in water → place in alkaline solution (e.g., Scott's tap water substitute / ammonia water).
    • Converts hematoxylin to sharp blue.
  7. (Optional) Differentiation
    • Quick dip in 5% acid alcohol → removes excess hematoxylin.
    • Sharpens nuclear detail (often skipped in rapid protocol).
  8. Eosin Staining
    • Immerse in eosin (15-30 sec).
    • Stains cytoplasm, collagen, RBCs pink-red (acidophilic structures).
  9. Dehydration
    • Sequential alcohol baths (ethanol):
    • 70% (optional), 95% (×2), 100% (×2).
    • Removes water, prepares tissue for clearing.
  10. Clearing
    • Immerse in xylene/xylene substitute × 2 → makes tissue transparent.
  11. Mounting
    • Drop of resin medium (e.g., DPX) + coverslip.
    • Seals tissue, prevents fading, permanent record.
  12. Microscopic Examination
    • Pathologist evaluates diagnosis intraoperatively (e.g., tumor margins, nature of lesion).

questions.text: A family is monitored over two generations. By age 18, four out of eight children develop high blood sugar and test positive for islet autoantibodies. They share similar MHC I and II loci, and insulin therapy effectively normalizes their HbA1c. Which of the following mechanisms most likely underlies their condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

The clinical presentation is type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM)-

  • Age of onset: childhood/adolescence.
  • Genetic link: strong association with MHC class II (HLA-DR3, HLA-DR4, DQ)
  • Pathogenesis: autoimmune destruction of pancreatic β-cells in the islets of Langerhans.
  • Autoantibodies: anti-insulin, anti-GAD (glutamic acid decarboxylase), anti-islet cell antibodies.
  • Mediated by T cells: autoreactive CD4+ and CD8+ T lymphocytes infiltrate islets (insulitis), leading to β-cell apoptosis.
  • Result: absolute insulin deficiency → patients require lifelong insulin therapy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chloride ion channel abnormality (Option A): Refers to CFTR mutations in cystic fibrosis, which can secondarily damage the pancreas (exocrine failure, sometimes late endocrine insufficiency). Not autoimmune, not MHC-linked, and not childhood-onset diabetes with autoantibodies.

Glucokinase gene mutation (Option B): Cause of MODY-2 (Maturity-Onset Diabetes of the Young) → autosomal dominant, presents with mild hyperglycaemia, NOT autoimmune, NOT MHC-linked.

Peripheral insulin resistance (Option C): Hallmark of type 2 diabetes mellitus, usually adult onset, strongly linked to obesity and metabolic syndrome. Insulin is often high or normal early, unlike T1DM where insulin is absent.

choices.text: It is an obligate extracellular parasite
NAAT is the most reliable diagnostic method
It is caused by serotypes D-K
Ampicillin is the antibiotic of choice

questions.text: A 5-year-old child from a rural area presents with a recurrent history of follicular conjunctivitis, photophobia, and corneal scarring. Which of the following statements about the causative organism is correct?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical history of recurrent follicular conjunctivitis, photophobia, and corneal scarring in a child from a rural area is highly suggestive of trachoma, which is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. For diagnosis, NAAT (nucleic acid amplification test) is the most sensitive and specific method, capable of detecting trachoma serotypes reliably.

  • Chlamydia are obligate intracellular parasites because they rely on the host cell for key amino acids and energy-generating metabolites like ATP. (Option A ruled out)

Serotypes:

  • Trachomais caused by serotypes A-C; it can lead to blindness. (Option C ruled out)
  • Serotypes D-Kcause urogenital infections and inclusion conjunctivitis.
  • Serotypes L1, L2, L3 → Causes Lymphogranuloma Venerum (LGV)

Diagnosis:

  • Nucleic acid amplification (NAA) tests are rapid, sensitive, and specific tests for chlamydial infections.
  • The most satisfactory method for the diagnosis of LGV is the isolation of an LGV strain of C trachomatis from tissue or lymph node aspirates.

Treatment:

  • Strains of C. trachomatis are susceptible to macrolides and doxycycline.
  • Azithromycin is the preferred therapy because it is given as a single oral dose for non-LGV C trachomatis infection.
  • Doxycycline is an alternative for C trachomatis and is the drug of choice for treating LGV.
  • For trachoma, a single dose of azithromycin is the treatment of choice. (Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Immediate administration of IV magnesium sulfate and calcium channel blocker
Hyperventilation with 100% oxygen and rapid cooling measures only
IV sodium bicarbonate 1-2 mEq/kg to correct metabolic acidosis
IV dantrolene 2.5 mg/kg bolus, repeated every 5-10 min to a maximum of 10 mg/kg

questions.text: A 24-year-old male undergoing emergency laparotomy develops a rapid rise in end-tidal CO2, tachycardia, generalized muscle rigidity, and a core temperature of 40 °C soon after induction with halothane and succinylcholine. Which of the following is the most appropriate definitive next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rapid IV dantrolene is the only specific therapy proven to reverse malignant hyperthermia (MH). Dantrolene directly inhibits RYR1-mediated calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in skeletal muscle, reversing the hypermetabolic crisis. Early administration halts the hypermetabolic crisis, lowers CO2 production, and reduces rigidity and hyperthermia.

  • Initial dose: 2.5 mg/kg IV, repeat every 5-10 min up to 10 mg/kg until symptoms subside.
  • Maintenance: 1 mg/kg IV every 4-6 h or 25 mg/kg/hr infusion for ≥24 h (longer if signs persist).
  • Supportive care includes discontinuing all volatile agents/succinylcholine, hyperventilation with 100% O2 ≥10 L/min, active cooling (stop at 38 °C), correction of metabolic acidosis with bicarbonate, treatment of hyperkalemia (glucose-insulin, bicarbonate, calcium if severe), and maintaining urine output >1-2 mL/kg/h with alkalinization to prevent myoglobinuric renal injury.
  • Complications of dantrolene: muscle weakness, phlebitis, GI upset, respiratory failure, hyperkalemia; administer through a large-bore IV line. Avoid calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem, nifedipine) with dantrolene because of risk of severe hyperkalemia and cardiovascular collapse.

Explanation of other options:

Magnesium sulfate and calcium channel blocker (Option A): Magnesium alone cannot terminate MH and calcium channel blockers given with dantrolene can precipitate fatal hyperkalemia.

Hyperventilation and cooling only (Option B): Supportive measures are essential but without dantrolene mortality remains high.

IV sodium bicarbonate (Option C): Corrects metabolic acidosis and hyperkalemia but is adjunctive, not definitive.

Key Takeaways:

  • MH is triggered by volatile anesthetics and succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals (commonly RYR1 mutation).
  • Hallmarks: sudden hypercarbia, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, rapidly rising temperature, metabolic/respiratory acidosis, ↑CK, myoglobinuria, hyperkalemia.
  • Dantrolene is the only drug that halts the crisis and prevents death.

choices.text: Treatment involves closed reduction and immobilisation for three weeks
Can be associated with reverse Hill-Sach's lesion
The most common complication is axillary nerve injury
AP and lateral view X-rays are a first-line diagnostic tool

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was brought to the ER with right shoulder pain after he fell on outstretched hands while playing basketball. On examination, there is a loss of contour of the shoulder with the arm being in abduction and external rotation. Which of the following is true about his likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic presentation of an arm held in abduction and external rotation, accompanied by a loss of the normal shoulder contour following a fall on an outstretched hand, suggests a likely diagnosis of anterior shoulder dislocation.

Anterior shoulder dislocation

  • Anterior shoulder dislocation is the most common type of shoulder dislocation, with subcoracoid being the most common subtype.
  • Clinical features
    • Severe pain, restricted movement
    • Flattening of the shoulder
    • The limb is often held in abduction and external rotation. 

Treatment

The treatment for shoulder dislocation involves closed reduction followed by immobilisation for a period of three weeks. Various reduction manoeuvres used for closed reduction: 

  • Kocher’s manoeuvre: The most commonly used method is Kocher’s method. The various steps of this method of reduction are (remember TEAM) T- Traction (along the line of the humerus), E- External (lateral) rotation of arms, A- Adduction of arm, M- Medial (internal) rotation of the arm.
  • Stimson’s gravity method: The patient is left prone with the arm hanging over the side of the bed. Thus, the weight of the limb helps in reduction.
  • Hippocrates’ manoeuvre: Reduction is done by axial traction in the semi-abducted arm, with countertraction given by placing the foot in the axilla. 

Complications of Anterior Shoulder Dislocation

  • Axillary Nerve Injury
  • Deltoid paralysis
  • Sensory blunting over the lateral aspect of the arm - Regimental badge sign
  • MC complication - recurrent shoulder dislocation 

Lesions associated with recurrent anterior shoulder dislocation:

  • Bankart lesion
    • A defect in the anteroinferior part of the glenoid labrum was caused by the humeral head tearing the labrum during the initial dislocation.
  • Hill-Sach's lesion
    • Defect in the posterolateral aspect of the humeral head
  • Bony-Bankart lesion
    • Tear in the antero-inferior aspect of the glenoid labrum with fracture of the glenoid rim. 

Explanation of other options: 

Can be associated with reverse Hill-Sach's lesion (Option B): Reverse Hill-Sachs lesion is seen in posterior shoulder dislocations, not anterior. 

AP and lateral view X-rays are a first-line diagnostic tool (Option D): The first-line diagnostic tool for shoulder dislocation is an X-ray, and at least two views are necessary. Typically, an anteroposterior (AP) view and an axillary view are taken. The axillary view is particularly useful in determining if the dislocation is anterior or posterior by showing the humeral head displaced outside the glenoid.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with progressive back pain and low-grade fever. On examination, there is paraspinal muscle spasm and a straightening of the dorso-lumbar spine. MRI revealed vertebral body destruction and a reduction in intervertebral disc space at two adjacent vertebrae. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and MRI findings are suggestive of TB spine. Medical management with ATT is the mainstay for TB spine without significant neurological deficits or gross deformity. 

TB spine

  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis (TB).
  • Also called Potts disease or tuberculous spondylitis.
  • Most common site: Dorsolumbar > dorsal > lumbar.
  • The most common type of TB spine is paradisical. 

Clinical features:

  • Night pain: Earliest symptoms
  • Tenderness: Earliest sign
  • Paraspinal spasm: Military attitude, positive coin test.
  • Constitutional symptoms: Low-grade fever, Evening rise in temperature, Loss of weight and appetite 

Investigations: 

  • X-ray
    • Straightening of spine: Earliest sign
    • Narrowing of the disc space
    • Erosion of the adjacent vertebral bodies
  • Biopsy: Gold standard investigation.
  • MRI: Investigation of choice; To rule out disc involvement& evaluation of paraplegia 

Complications:

  • Kyphotic deformity
  • Paraplegia
  • Bony ankylosis
  • Abscess: Psoas abscess, Paravertebral abscess, Cold abscess 

Treatment

  • Initially, by anti-tuberculosis therapy and external immobilisation of the neck in a cervical brace or plaster cast for 6 weeks up to 6 months in neurologically intact patients and without signs of instability.
  • Patients with instability or with neurological compromise can be placed on skull tongs traction.
  • Debridement of necrotic bone and anterior cervical vertebral fusion with bone grafts may be offered as an alternative to prolonged immobilisation in cases of bone destruction with severe kyphosis deformity.
  • More urgent indications for operation are to drain a large retropharyngeal abscess to decompress a threatened spinal cord or to fuse an unstable spine. 

Key Takeaways: 

Surgical indications in TB spine

  • Neurologic deficit
  • Spinal instability
  • Progressive kyphosis
  • Failure of medical management

questions.text: A 24-year-old athlete sustained a twisting injury to the knee joint during his training. He recalls hearing a pop sound during the injury, followed by swelling and inability to walk. On examination, there is tenderness and increased forward movement of the tibia in relation to the femur. What is the definitive management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A history of a twisting knee injury associated with a "pop" sound and increased anterior translation on examination (suggesting a positive Lachman test) indicates an ACL tear. In a young athlete, the most definitive management is Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction with a graft.

Anterior Cruciate Ligament Injury

  • Accounts for between 40% and 50% of all knee ligament injuries.
  • Mechanism of injury is typically a valgus load with internal tibial rotation and anterior tibial translation while the knee is in almost full extension.
  • ACL injuries are often the result of noncontact pivoting injuries.

Clinical features

  • They are commonly associated with an audible pop and a hemarthrosis that
  • begins within 12 hours of injury.
  • Instability and inability to return to sport are the most frequent complaints.
  • The Lachman test is the most sensitive examination for acute ACL injuries.
    • The patient’s knee is flexed 20 degrees; with one hand grasping the lower thigh and the other the upper part of the leg, the joint surfaces are shifted backwards and forwards upon each other. Increased anterior movement suggests an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury.

Treatment

  • Treatment is individualised based on age, activity level, instability, associated injuries, and other medical factors.
  • The treatment options available include
    • Nonoperative management
    • Repair of the ACL (either isolated or with augmentation)
    • Reconstruction with either autograft, allograft tissues or synthetics.
  • Conservative management
    • Recommended for elderly patients and individuals who are willing to make lifestyle changes and avoid the activities that cause recurrent instability (Option A rule out)
    • InvolvesRICE protocol, bracing, and quadriceps/hamstring strengthening.
  • Arthroscopic ACL reconstruction with graft
    • Gold standard in young athletes and high-demand patients.
    • The goals of ACL reconstruction (ACLR) are to stabilise the knee joint, restore normal kinematics and prevent early-onset degenerative arthrosis.
    • Graft selection depends on patient factors and the surgeon's preference, and choices usually include:
      • Bone-patellar tendon-bone (BPTB)
      • Four-strand hamstring
      • Quadriceps tendon

Explanation of other options:

Total knee arthroplasty (Option C): Total knee arthroplasty is reserved for advanced osteoarthritis in elderly patients and has no role in isolated ACL injuries.

Arthroscopic repair with sutures (Option D): Open ACL repair with sutures is outdated because the ACL has poor healing potential and repairs fail frequently.

choices.text: Gonioscopy is based on elimination of critical angle
Static perimeters are best to monitor VF defects
RNFL analysis can determine VF loss earlier than perimetry
Goldmann applanation tonometer gives false high reading on a thinner cornea

questions.text: What is not true about glaucoma investigations?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Goldmann applanation tonometer is designed to measure intraocular pressure (IOP) by flattening a constant area of the cornea.
  • It is calibrated for a central corneal thickness (CCT) of 520 μm.
  • Thinner corneas (e.g., <520 μm) may yield falsely low IOP readings, while thicker corneas (e.g., >520 μm) may yield falsely high readings.
  • Thus, the statement "gives false high reading on a thinner cornea" is incorrect (thinner corneas lead to false low readings).




Explanation for Incorrect options:

Gonioscopy (Option A) uses a Goniolens/Gonioprism to eliminate the critical angle, allowing direct visualization of the anterior chamber angle.





Static perimeters (Option B) (e.g., Humphrey Field Analyzer) are gold standard for monitoring progressive visual field (VF) defects in glaucoma.


RNFL analysis (Option C) (e.g., OCT) detects structural damage to retinal nerve fiber layers earlier than functional VF loss on perimetry.

questions.text: A microbiologist is performing a Gram stain. The procedure requires a proper sequence of steps to differentiate between Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria. Which of the following represents the correct order of reagents used in Gram staining?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gram staining is a type of differential staining
  • The sequence of staining a bacterial smear (mnemonic"Methyl GAS")
    • Methyl violet/Crystal violet/Gentian violet: Primary dye
    • Gram's iodine: Mordant
    • Alcohol/Acid alcohol: Decolouriser
    • Safranin: Counterstain
  • Ethyl alcohol or acid alcoholis used for about 30 seconds as a mild decolouriser, which is the critical step in the process.
  • After staining:
    • Gram-positive bacteriaappear purple/violet.
    • Gram-negative bacteriaappear pink.
  • Factors that determine Gram staining:
    • Thickness of the peptidoglycan layerin the bacterial cell wall: Most important factor
      • Thick peptidoglycan layer: Gram-positive
      • Thin peptidoglycan layer: Gram-negative
    • Strength of the dye-iodine complex:
      • Strong complex: Retained in Gram-positive.
      • Weak complex: Washed out in Gram-negative.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with high fever, severe anaemia, and confusion after visiting a malaria-endemic area. Peripheral blood smear shows multiple ring-shaped trophozoites in red blood cells and banana-shaped gametocytes. Which of the following is the most appropriate first-line therapy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient has high-grade fever, severe anaemia, and confusion, with peripheral smear showing multiple ring-shaped trophozoites in red blood cells and banana-shaped gametocytes, which arecharacteristic of Plasmodium falciparum malaria.
  • The first-line treatment forsevere Plasmodium falciparum malaria is an artemisinin-based combination therapy (ACT). ACT rapidly reduces parasite load and prevents complications.

Explanation of other options:

Chloroquine (Option A): Chloroquine is ineffective against most Plasmodium falciparum strains because of widespread resistance, so it is not used in endemic areas for severe malaria.

Primaquine (Option C): Primaquine is an effective gametocidal agent and prevents transmission, but it cannot treat the acute infection on its own and is therefore insufficient for severe malaria.

Chloroquine and Primaquine (Option D): This combination is primarily used for Plasmodium vivax, which, on peripheral smear, appears as single-ring forms and round gametocytes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents with sudden-onset fever, irritability, and diffuse erythematous rash with skin changes as shown in the image. Which of the following toxins is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical presentation and image findings are suggestive of Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSS), caused by Staphylococcus aureus. The condition is mediated by exfoliative toxins A and B (ETA and ETB).

Manifestations of Staphylococcal toxins

Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS)

  • Also called
    • TEN: Toxic Epidermolytic Necrolysis in adults
    • Ritter's disease in children
    • Mucous membrane sparing
  • Due to Enterotoxin A & B or exfoliative toxins A & B, which act against Desmoglein-1 in S.granulosum.
  • Erythema and intraepidermal desquamation take place at remote sites from which S aureus cannot be isolated.
  • The disease is most common in neonates and children less than 5 years of age.

Toxic Shock Syndrome (TSS)

  • Commonly associated with the use ofcontaminated vaginal tampons.
  • The condition is caused byTSST-1 (Enterotoxin F), which acts as a superantigen. (Option A ruled out)
  • TSST-1 leads to massive T-cell activation, resulting in acytokine (lymphokine) storm that causes shock.

Staphylococcal food poisoning

  • The condition is caused bypreformed Staphylococcal enterotoxin A, which is heat-stable and has vagomimetic effects. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ingestion of staphylococcal enterotoxin-contaminated food results in acute
  • vomiting and diarrhoea within 1 to 5 hours.

Alpha toxin-mediated skin manifestations

  • Alpha-toxin (α-hemolysin) causes tissue necrosis and haemolysis, not the superficial epidermal peeling seen in SSS. (Option D ruled out)

questions.text:
Which among the following E. coli pathotypes are correctly paired with the condition they cause?

i) EPEC; Shigellosis-like illness
ii) ETEC; Traveller's diarrhoea
iii) EHEC; Haemorrhagic Colitis
iv) EIEC; Infantile diarrhoea
questions.solution:
Explanation:

EPEC (Enteropathogenic E. coli)

  • An important cause of pediatric diarrhoea
  • Mediated by bundle-forming pili and the locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE), which produces attaching-and-effacing lesions without toxin production.

EIEC (Enteroinvasive E. coli)

  • Resembles shigellosis, causing bloody diarrhoea due to its virulence marker antigen (VMA).
  • Confirmed by a positive Sereny test.

ETEC (Enterotoxigenic E. coli)

  • The most common cause of traveller's diarrhoea.
  • Produces heat-stable and heat-labile toxins.
  • Uses colonisation factor antigen (CFA) for adherence.

EHEC (Enterohemorrhagic E. coli)

  • Especially serotype O157:H7, causes haemorrhagic colitis in adults and haemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) in children
  • Mediated by verotoxins (Shiga-like toxins 1 & 2), which inhibit protein synthesis.
  • For culture, MacConkey agar is commonly used for isolation, and sorbitol-MacConkey agar helps differentiate EHEC O157:H7, as it does not ferment sorbitol.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male with a recent history of trekking presents with fever, rash involving palms and soles, and generalised lymphadenopathy. Laboratory investigations reveal thrombocytopenia. Which of the following tests is most useful in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient's clinical presentation and findings, with a history of trekking pointing to possible tick exposure, suggest a possible tick-borne rickettsial infection. Laboratory confirmation is supported by Weil-Felix positivity, which is screening; indirect immunofluorescence/PCR preferred where available

  • Most rickettsiae have animal reservoirs and are spread by ticks, lice, fleas, or mites, which are prominent components of their life cycles.
  • Following transmission from the salivary gland of infected ticks, the bacteria spread locally, creating a necrotic eschar.
  • The major rickettsial species have a tropism for vascular endothelium.
  • Rickettsiaceae that cause life-threatening infections are
    • R. rickettsii: Rocky Mountain spotted fever
    • R. prowazekii: Louse-borne typhus
    • Orientia tsutsugamushi: Scrub typhus
    • R. conorii: Mediterranean spotted fever
    • R. typhi: Murine typhus

Weil-Felix test

  • An agglutination test for the diagnosis of rickettsial infection.
  • Detects anti-rickettsial antibodies in a patient's serum using cross-reactivity with certainProteus serotypes (OX19, OX2, OXK).
  • Anti-rickettsial antibodies in the serum react withProteus OX antigens (O-polysaccharide of LPS), causing agglutination.
  • Cross-reactivity: Occurs due to structural similarity between rickettsial LPS O-antigen and Proteus OX polysaccharides:
  • Nonspecific and cannot reliably differentiate rickettsial species; mainly used forscreening.

Explanation of other options:

Widal test (Option A): The Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which typically presents with prolonged fever and abdominal symptoms, not palm and sole rash or thrombocytopenia, so it is unlikely in this case.

Paul-Bunnell test (Option C): Detects heterophile antibodies in EBV infection (older version of Monospot)

Monospot test (Option D): Detects heterophile antibodies in infectious mononucleosis, which causes fever and lymphadenopathy but rarely involves rash on the palms and soles or thrombocytopenia, so it is not appropriate in this case.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with fever, muscle aches, and neck stiffness. He reports having consumed a cheese sandwich one week ago. Microscopy of his samples shows organisms with tumbling motility. What is the drug of choice for treating the likely infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

History of consuming contaminated cheese, meningitis-like symptoms, and tumbling motility on microscopy indicate Listeria monocytogenes, the drug of choice for which is ampicillin.

  • Listeria are β-haemolytic, catalase-positive Gram-positive rods.
  • Motility
    • Differential motility: Motile at 25°Cbut is nonmotile at 37°C.
    • This is because peritrichous flagella are produced optimally at 20-30°C but not at 37°C, a temperature typically found in cooler environments like refrigerators, which helps it survive in contaminated foods.
    • Also exhibits characteristic tumbling motilityat lower temperatures.
  • Due to its ability to survive refrigeration (4°C), it is commonly found in stored foods, especially aged soft cheeses, packaged meats, milk and cold salads.
  • Pregnant women and immunocompromised patients are at special risk for infection.

Clinical manifestations

  • Gastroenteritis
  • Meningitis
  • Sepsis
  • In Pregnant Women
    • Causes chorioamnionitis leading to premature rupture of membranes (PROM), abortion, stillbirth, or preterm labor.

Treatment:

  • Meningitis:Ampicillin is the drug of choice, given for 2-3 weeks in combination with Gentamicin for synergistic effect.
  • Cotrimoxazole is given to patients with penicillin allergy.
  • In febrile gastroenteritis, Amoxicillin is recommended in immunocompromised, elderly or pregnant patients.

questions.text: Match the culture medium with the organism isolated
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TCBS agar

  • Thiosulfate Citrate Bile Salt Sucrose agar is the selective medium forVibrio
  • Vibrio cholerae, which ferments sucrose, producesyellow colonies.
  • Non-sucrose-fermenting vibrios appearas green colonies.

Loeffler's serum slope

  • An enrichment medium which allows rapid growth ofCorynebacterium diphtheriae within 6-8 hours.
  • Colonies appear as small, circular, white or creamy and glistening.

MacConkey agar

  • A selective and differential mediumused for Enterobacteriaceae.
  • It contains bile salts, lactose, and the pH indicator neutral red.
  • Escherichia coliferments lactose and produces pink colonies, whereas non-lactose fermenters such as Shigella and Salmonella produce colourless colonies.

BCYE agar

  • Legionellae can be grown on buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar with α-ketoglutarate, l-cysteine, and iron at a pH of 6.9, temperature of 35°C, and 90% humidity.
  • The isolation of large Gram-negative rods on BCYE after 2 to 5 days is presumptive evidence for Legionella.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents with thick mucopurulent urethral discharge one week after unprotected sexual intercourse. Gram staining of the discharge shows neutrophils containing Gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following media is most appropriate for isolating the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the clinical presentation and Gram stain findings, the patient likely has urethritis due to Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Thayer-Martin medium is the selective agar of choice for isolating this organism.

Neisseria gonococcus

Gram-negative diplococci; non-capsulated organism.

Typing methods: Pili-based typing and autotyping (nutrient requirement-based).

Manifestations

  • Gonorrhoea (STD):
    • Males: Urethritis with thick mucopurulent discharge.
    • Females: Cervicitis with thick mucopurulent discharge.
  • Neonates:Ophthalmia neonatorum (most commonly due to Chlamydia, but N. gonorrhoeae is a cause).

Laboratory Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining: Pink-coloured kidney-shaped cocci, mostly intracellular.
  • Culture: Grown on New York City agar or Thayer-Martin medium (selective).
    • Thayer-Martin medium: A complex medium used to isolate Neisseria species, which are fastidious. Selective because it contains antibiotics that inhibit most organisms except Neisseria species.
  • PCR: Molecular confirmation of N. gonorrhoeae.

Treatment:

  • Drug of choice: 3rd generation cephalosporin (Ceftriaxone).
  • Empirical therapy: Azithromycin

Explanation of other options:

Blood agar (Option A): Blood agar is non-selective and may allow overgrowth by normal flora.

MacConkey agar (Option B): A selective medium for Gram-negative bacilli that typically reside in the intestine, not Neisseria.

Sabouraud agar (Option D): Sabouraud agar is used for fungal culture, not bacteria.

questions.text: Corneal graft can be stored in all media except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Basal salt solutions (e.g., PBS) lack essential nutrients (e.g., chondroitin sulfate, antioxidants) and buffers required to maintain corneal endothelial cell health. Glucose alone is insufficient; it can even promote osmotic damage or microbial growth.
  • Corneal storage requires specialized media (e.g., Optisol-GS, MK Medium) that mimic aqueous humor to prevent endothelial apoptosis and maintain transparency.

Storage media for Corneal grafts:

Explanation for Incorrect options:

MK Medium (Option A): A specialized storage medium containing nutrients, antibiotics, and buffers to preserve corneal endothelial viability for a few days.

Cryopreservation (Option B):

  • Freezing techniques can preserve corneas for long-term storage, though not commonly used due to complexity.
  • Endothelial viability is lost- so it's typically used for tectonic/therapeutic purposes rather than optical grafting.
  • Can be stored upto 18 months

Moist Chamber (Option C):

  • Short-term storage (24-48 hours) where the cornea is kept in a sterile container with saline-moistened gauze to prevent dehydration.
  • Whole globe is preserved at 4 degree C temp. with saline humidification up to 48 hours

questions.text: A 5-year-old unimmunized child is brought to the paediatric OPD with fever, sore throat, and severe respiratory distress. On examination, the child had cervical lymphadenopathy. A throat swab was obtained, which on microscopy showed the findings given below in the image. What is the most appropriate initial management for this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The microscopy image showsrod-shaped organisms with metachromatic granules, which, together with the clinical presentation, are suggestive of diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
  • Severe infectionrequires diphtheria antitoxin to neutralise the circulating toxin and antibiotics to eradicate the causative organism.
  • It is a toxin-mediated disease that can cause severe respiratory symptoms, such as a pseudomembranein the throat, myocarditis, and neuropathy.

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory findings
    • Gram staining:Rod-shaped organisms appear violet in colour, often arranged in Chinese letter patterns.
    • Albert staining:Metachromatic (Volutin) granules stain green, also showing the characteristic Chinese letter arrangement.
  • Culture Media:
    • Loeffler's Serum Slope (LSS):
      • Enriched medium that supports rapid growth; colonies may appear within6-8 hours.
    • Potassium Tellurite Agar:
      • A selective mediumfor the organism. Colonies appear black, making it easier to identify.
    • Toxin detection:
      • Toxin production by the bacteria can be confirmed through the Elek test.

Treatment:

  • The primary treatment approaches for diphtheria involve promptly administering antitoxins and antibiotics.
  • Antitoxin functions by neutralising unbound diphtheria toxin circulating in the blood.
  • The antibiotics of choice for treating diphtheria are erythromycin or penicillin G.
  • The mainstay of diphtheria prevention is immunisation with inactivated toxin, diphtheria toxoid. (Option B, C, D ruled out)

choices.text: Mallampati Class II with thyromental distance of 7 cm
Mallampati Class IV with thyromental distance of 5.5 cm
Mallampati Class III with thyromental distance of 6.5 cm
Mallampati Class I with thyromental distance of 7 cm

questions.text: A 52-year-old obese male with a short neck is scheduled for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. On preoperative airway assessment he can open his mouth widely. You are comparing isolated bedside airway predictors (Mallampati class and thyromental distance) for difficult laryngoscopy. Which combination most strongly predicts difficulty?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The finding of Mallampati Class IV - where only the hard palate is visible - combined with a thyromental distance < 6 cm is strongly associated with difficult laryngoscopy and intubation. Both factors independently increase the risk, and their coexistence makes this patient high-risk for airway management challenges.

  • Mallampati classification predicts difficulty in direct laryngoscopy by assessing the visibility of oropharyngeal structures with the mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation.
  • Classes are differentiated on the basis of the structures visualized:
    • Class I: Faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate visible.
    • Class II: Base of uvula and soft palate visible.
    • Class III: Only soft palate visible.
    • Class IV: Only hard palate visible.

  • A thyromental distance < 6.5 cm (~3 fingerbreadths) predicts difficult laryngoscopy; values < 6 cm indicate high risk due to limited mandibular space and impaired tongue displacement.
  • Prediction is strongest when multiple adverse features coexist (e.g., Mallampati IV plus short TMD plus obesity/short neck), rather than either factor alone.

Explanation of Other Options:

Mallampati Class II with thyromental distance of 7 cm (Option A): Indicates moderate visibility and adequate mandibular space; not predictive of difficult intubation.

Mallampati Class III with thyromental distance of 6.5 cm (Option C): Soft palate only visible suggests some difficulty, but thyromental distance is within acceptable range, making it less risky than Class IV with < 6 cm.

Mallampati Class I with thyromental distance of 7 cm (Option D): Represents optimal airway anatomy with minimal predicted difficulty.

choices.text: On Gram stain, it appears as Gram-positive, budding yeast cells.
The treatment of choice is Amphotericin B with fluconazole
Culture on SDA shows brownish-black colonies
The most rapid diagnostic test is the India ink staining

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV-positive male presents with fever, headache, and altered sensorium. MRI brain shows multiple soap-bubble lesions. Which of the following is the most appropriate statement regarding the likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The history of fever, headache, altered sensorium and soap-bubble brain lesions on MRI, in an immunocompromised individual strongly suggests Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis. Gram staining of Cryptococcus neoformans shows Gram-positive, round, budding yeast cells.

  • Meningitis is the most commonly recognised form of cryptococcal disease.
  • Cryptococcosis in immunocompromised patients occurs primarily in those with defects in CD4+ T-lymphocyte function, particularly in patients with AIDS, is the most common systemic fungal infection.
  • Common presenting symptoms include intermittent headache, irritability, dizziness, and difficulty with complex cerebral functions, appearing over weeks or months.

Diagnosis:

CSF Findings (Lumbar puncture):

  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Pleocytosis: >100 WBC/mm³ (lymphocyte predominant)
  • Low glucose levels

Microscopy:

  • India ink staining (negative stain):
    • Demonstratesencapsulated yeast cells (seen in ~50% cases)
    • Capsule appears as aclear halo against a dark background

Antigen Detection:

  • Latex agglutination test (Cryptococcal antigen card test):
    • The most sensitive and rapid testfor the diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis. (Option D ruled out)

Culture:

  • Sabouraud's Dextrose Agar (SDA):Mucoid colonies (Option C ruled out)
  • Niger seed agar (Bird seed agar):Brownish-black colonies (due to phenol oxidase activity)

Biochemical Test:

  • Urease test:Positive; Medium changes from yellow to pink

Treatment

  • Drug of choice (DOC) for cryptococcal meningitis:
    • Liposomal Amphotericin B + Flucytosine. (Option B ruled out)
  • Prophylaxis (in immunocompromised patients):
    • Fluconazole

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male presents with fever, productive cough, and pleuritic chest pain. A bronchoalveolar lavage specimen is obtained, which on Gram staining shows gram-positive lancet-shaped diplococci, as seen in the image below. Which of the following statements regarding the likely causative organism is true?
i. Resistant to optochin and bile insoluble.
ii.Capsule can be demonstrated by the Quellung reaction
iii.Ferments inulin
iv.Shows positive CAMP test
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Organism: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus).
  • Key features:
    • Optochin sensitive and bile soluble → so statement (i) is FALSE.
    • Capsule demonstration: Quellung reaction (capsular swelling test) → TRUE.
    • Inulin fermentation: positive, differentiates it from viridans streptococci → TRUE.
    • CAMP test: characteristic of Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B strep), not pneumococcus → FALSE.

Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • A gram-positive, catalase-negative diplococci.
  • The polysaccharide capsule of S pneumoniae is the major determinant of virulence.
  • The pneumococcal capsule is made up of Polysaccharides & demonstrated on the Quellung Reaction.
  • Based on the composition of the capsular polysaccharide, S. pneumoniae is divided intoover 90 serotypes, which can be identified using specific soluble substance (SSS) typing.

Disease caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae

  • Pneumonia
    • The most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia
    • Most common cause (typical) pneumonia
    • The most common cause of Pneumonia in HIV.
    • Symptoms
      • Pneumococcal pneumonia begins abruptly with a shaking chill and high fever.
      • Cough with production of pink to rusty-coloured sputum
      • Pleuritic chest pain
  • Conjunctivitis
  • Otitis Media
  • Meningitis
    • The most common cause of meningitis in adults and all age groups except neonates]
  • Sinusitis

Diagnosis

  • Gram staining
    • Gram-positive lancet or flame-shaped diplococci.
  • Culture
    • Grow onblood agar and chocolate agar.
    • Showdraughtsman or carrom coin-like appearance due to autolysin activity.
  • Laboratory test (BIO tests):
    • B: Bile soluble
    • I: Inulin fermentation positive
    • O: Optochin sensitive; pneumococcus on blood agar shows partial haemolysis. with sensitivity to the optochin disk
    • CAMP test is negative; S. agalactiae shows positive CAMP tests.
    • Optochin sensitivity and bile solubility help distinguish S. pneumonia from S. viridians.

Explanation to Other Options:

Resistant to optochin and bile insoluble (Option i): Incorrect. S. pneumoniae is optochin sensitive and bile soluble, not resistant/insoluble.

Positive CAMP test (Option iv): Incorrect. CAMP test is a feature of Streptococcus agalactiae (Group B strep), not pneumococcus.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Klebsiella pneumoniae colonies on culture media are glistening and mucoid due to a thick capsule.
Reason (R): Klebsiella pneumoniae is non-motile because it lacks flagella.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Klebsiella pneumoniaeproduces glistening, mucoid colonies due to its thick polysaccharide capsule.
  • Klebsiella pneumoniaeis non-motile because it lacks flagella.
  • However, the reasondoes not explain the mucoid appearance; the mucoid texture is caused by the capsule, not by the absence of flagella.
  • The presence of a polysaccharide capsule forms the basis of a serotyping system.
  • Over 70 capsular types have been defined, including some that cross-react with those of other encapsulated pathogens, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae.
  • Klebsiella also express several types of pili on the cell surface, which probably aid in adherence to respiratory and urinary epithelium.
  • Klebsiella pneumoniae, the most common species, is able to cause classic lobar pneumonia, a characteristic of other encapsulated bacteria.

choices.text: Urgent laparotomy with peritoneal lavage and repair of the source
High-dose intravenous corticosteroids and supportive care
Endoscopic placement of a decompression tube

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with sudden onset severe generalized abdominal pain for 6 hours. He is restless, febrile, and tachycardic. Examination reveals a rigid "board-like" abdomen with marked rebound tenderness. Bowel sounds are absent. An erect chest X-ray shows free air under the right hemidiaphragm. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of diffuse guarding, rigidity, rebound tenderness, and free air under the diaphragm on erect chest X-ray strongly indicates perforation of a hollow viscus with generalized peritonitis, requiring immediate surgical exploration.

  • Causes of peritoneal inflammation:
    • Bacterial (gastrointestinal perforation—peptic ulcer, appendix, diverticulum).
    • Chemical (bile, barium).
    • Ischaemia (strangulated bowel, vascular occlusion).
    • Trauma or postoperative leaks.
  • Clinical clues:
    • Severe abdominal pain aggravated by movement/coughing.
    • Guarding and “board-like” rigidity of the abdominal wall.
    • Rebound tenderness.
    • Absent or reduced bowel sounds.
    • Systemic signs: fever, tachycardia, hypotension in severe cases.
  • Investigations:
    • Erect chest radiograph: free sub-diaphragmatic air is a classic sign of perforation.
    • CT or ultrasound can support diagnosis if needed.
  • Management:
    • Immediate resuscitation with IV fluids, electrolyte correction, nasogastric decompression, urinary catheterization.
    • Broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics.
    • Definitive treatment is urgent laparotomy for source control: closure of perforated viscus, peritoneal lavage, and drainage as indicated.

Explanation of Other Options:

Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics and observation (Option A): Appropriate only as part of pre-operative resuscitation; observation alone delays definitive treatment and increases mortality.

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids and supportive care (Option C): Steroids are not part of acute peritonitis management and can worsen infection.

Endoscopic placement of a decompression tube (Option D): Used in sigmoid volvulus without perforation; not indicated when free intraperitoneal air is present.

Key Takeaways:

  • Guarding, rigidity, and free sub-diaphragmatic air signify perforation with generalized peritonitis.
  • Management requires rapid resuscitation and emergency laparotomy with source control and peritoneal lavage.

choices.text: It passes above the inguinal ligament and is lateral to the femoral vessels
It is more common in men and rarely presents as an emergency
The narrow neck of the hernia sac contributes to a high risk of strangulation
Low (Lockwood) repair is the approach of choice in all cases, including strangulated hernia

questions.text: A 65-year-old thin elderly woman presents with a painful swelling just below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The swelling is irreducible and shows no cough impulse. Which of the following statements about this condition is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • High risk of strangulation: Femoral hernia protrudes through the femoral canal, which has a rigid boundary (lacunar ligament medially, femoral vein laterally, inguinal ligament anteriorly, iliopectineal ligament posteriorly). The tight, unyielding neck predisposes to early incarceration and strangulation, making this an urgent surgical condition.

Femoral Hernia:

  • Epidemiology: Less common than inguinal hernia, but more common in women especially elderly and thin.
  • Anatomy: Swelling lies below the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral vein.
  • Clinical features: Easily missed on examination; often small (1-2 cm) and can mimic a lymph node.
  • Complications: About 50% present as emergency due to obstruction or strangulation.
  • Surgical repair:
    • Elective, reducible cases: Low (Lockwood), inguinal (Lotheissen), or laparoscopic TEP/TAPP approaches.
    • Strangulated/obstructed cases: High (McEvedy) approach is preferred to allow bowel resection if needed.
  • Special variant: Richter's hernia - only part of the bowel wall herniates and may strangulate without obstruction.
  • Surgical Approaches:

Explanation of Other Options:

It passes above the inguinal ligament and is lateral to the femoral vessels (Option A): Femoral hernia lies below the inguinal ligament and medial to the femoral vein, not above or lateral.

It is more common in men and rarely presents as an emergency (Option B): Femoral hernia is more common in women, especially elderly, and 50% present as an emergency with a high risk of strangulation.

Low (Lockwood) repair is the approach of choice in all cases, including strangulated hernia (Option D): Lockwood repair is for uncomplicated elective cases. High (McEvedy) approach is indicated in strangulated or obstructed hernia to allow safe bowel resection.

Key Takeaways:

questions.text: Scabies caused by Sarcoptes scabiei typically involve all sites, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The face is often spared in scabies, especially in adults. It is more commonly seen in children.

Scabies

Causative agent:

  • Caused by mites of the Sarcoptidae family, mainly Sarcoptes scabiei.
  • Related mites: Notoedres cati (cats), Trixacarus caviae (rodents).
  • Variants of scabiei cause scabies in humans and mange in animals.
  • Host specificity is incomplete - mites may transfer between species but survive briefly.

Clinical features:

  • Primary symptom: Severe itching, worse at night and in warmth.
  • Onset: 3-4 weeks after first infection; immediate if reinfected.
  • Typical sites:
    • Finger webs (Option A)
    • Flexor wrists (Option B)
    • Elbows (Option C)
    • Axillae
    • Buttocks
    • Genitalia
    • Female breasts
  • Characteristic lesion: Burrows - thin, raised, brownish, winding tracks on skin.
  • Male genitalia: Itchy papules or nodules, often diagnostic when burrows are absent.
  • Nodules may persist for weeks to months even after treatment.
  • Secondary lesions: Scratches, eczema-like changes, or impetigo due to secondary infection.
  • In endemic areas, combination of itching, skin lesions in typical sites, or affected family members is highly sensitive and specific for diagnosis.

Clinical variants:

  • Infants/young children: More widespread burrows, vesicular or pustular lesions on hands/feet, extensive eczema, crusted nodules on trunk/limbs.
  • Elderly: Numerous burrows on palms and soles, truncal papulosquamous lesions, often with secondary eczema.
  • Crusted scabies: Severe, highly contagious form (described separately).

Treatment:

  • Permethrin 5% cream (2 applications) or
  • Oral ivermectin
  • Benzyl benzoate in children

Key takeaways:

Some mites of public health importance

  • Trombiculid mite: causes scrub typhus
  • Itch mite: causes scabies

questions.text: A 38-year-old non-diabetic, non-hypertensive presents with unilateral transient obscuration for 2-3 days followed by sudden diminution of vision. Which of the following tests would you order?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Unilateral transient obscuration (amaurosis fugax) for 2-3 days followed by sudden diminution of vision suggests retinal artery occlusion (e.g., central retinal artery occlusion [CRAO] or branch retinal artery occlusion [BRAO]) or retinal vein occlusion (CRVO).
  • Amaurosis fugax is often caused by emboli (e.g., from carotid atherosclerosis or cardiac sources) or hypercoagulable states.

Causes for CRAO/CRVO in young patients:

  • Hypercoagulable states - Elevated homocysteine, prothrombotic state (venous >> arterial); arterial events less consistent- APLS, hyperhomocysteinemia are stronger arterial associations.
  • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., vasculitis),
  • Congenital disorders
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Trauma
  • Undetected tumors

Hyperhomocysteinemia:

  • Hyperhomocysteinemia is a well-established independent risk factor for retinal vascular occlusions (arterial and venous) in young, non-diabetic, non-hypertensive patients.
  • Elevated homocysteine promotes endothelial dysfunction, thrombosis, and atherosclerosis, increasing the risk of embolic events.
  • Testing for homocysteine is crucial in unexplained retinal artery occlusions to guide management (e.g., B-vitamin supplementation, anticoagulation).
  • Carotid Doppler (for carotid stenosis), Echocardiography (cardiac emboli), Lipid profile, and thrombophilia screen (e.g., Factor V Leiden) should also be considered.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Serum creatinine (Option B): Assesses renal function but is not specific to retinal artery occlusion.

Serum ACE levels (Option C): Used for suspected sarcoidosis (which causes uveitis, not typical for acute arterial occlusion).

Quantiferon Gold TB test (Option D): For tuberculosis (associated with uveitis or vasculitis, but not classic for acute arterial occlusion).

choices.text: Transitional cell carcinoma of the renal pelvis
Renal cell carcinoma with paraneoplastic manifestations

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with intermittent painless hematuria and dull flank pain for 3 months. He reports recent unexplained weight loss and occasional fever. On examination, a firm, non-tender left flank mass is palpable. Laboratory tests reveal elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), mild hypercalcemia, and hypertension. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic triad of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is flank pain, hematuria, and a palpable renal mass, though all three rarely present together. This patient also exhibits paraneoplastic features - hypertension, hypercalcemia, and raised ESR - which strongly point to RCC.

  • Key Clinical Features of RCC
    • Epidemiology: Most common solid renal tumor; accounts for ~90% of renal malignancies.
    • Risk Factors: Cigarette smoking, obesity, hypertension, exposure to petrochemicals/dyes, chronic dialysis with acquired renal cystic disease.
    • Classic Triad: Flank pain, hematuria (M/C presentation), and palpable abdominal mass (now less common due to early detection).
    • Paraneoplastic Syndromes:
      • Elevated ESR (most common)
      • Hypertension (from renin secretion)
      • Hypercalcemia (from PTHrP secretion)
      • Polycythemia (from excess erythropoietin)
    • Histology: Clear-cell RCC is the most common subtype, arising from proximal tubular epithelium; associated with loss of chromosome 3p and VHL (von Hippel–Lindau) gene mutation.
  • Investigations:
    • Imaging: Triphasic contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) is investigation of choice; MRI for venous invasion.
    • Labs: CBC, ESR, calcium, liver function, alkaline phosphatase (to detect bone/liver metastasis).
  • Management:
    • Localized disease: Partial or radical nephrectomy (nephron-sparing if <4 cm, solitary kidney, or bilateral tumors).
    • Advanced/metastatic disease: Targeted therapy with tyrosine kinase inhibitors (e.g., sunitinib, pazopanib) or immune checkpoint inhibitors; RCC is resistant to chemotherapy and radiotherapy.

Common RCC types

  • Clear Cell RCC (~70–75%)
    • Origin: proximal tubule; golden-yellow, hemorrhagic.
    • Genetics: VHL inactivation, 3p loss.
    • IHC: CAIX (cup-shaped), PAX8+, RCC marker+, CD10+.
    • Behavior: most aggressive of common subtypes.
  • Papillary RCC (~15%)
    • Origin: proximal tubule; papillary/fronded architecture, foamy macrophages, psammoma bodies.
    • Genetics: trisomy 7/17; MET pathway activation (esp. “type 1” morphology).
    • IHC: PAX8+, AMACR+, CK7 variably+.
  • Chromophobe RCC (~5%)
    • Origin: intercalated cells of collecting duct; pale cells with perinuclear halos, “raisinoid” nuclei.
    • Genetics: multiple chromosomal losses.
    • IHC: CK7 diffuse+, KIT (CD117)+, Hale’s colloidal iron+.
    • Behavior: generally indolent; better prognosis than clear cell.
  • Medullary RCC: Associated with sickle cell trait.

Paraneoplastic Syndrome:

Endocrine/Metabolic

  • Polycythemia → ectopic EPO
    • ↑Hb/Hct; ruddy complexion, headache. (Can also see anemia of chronic disease from IL-6- both appear in RCC.)
  • Hypercalcemia → PTHrP (most common), ± 1,25-(OH)±D, or osteolysis
    • Weakness, constipation, AKI; ↑Ca, suppressed PTH.
  • Hypertension → tumor renin production
    • Refractory HTN; ↑renin/aldosterone axis.
  • Cushing syndrome → ectopic ACTH
    • Hyperglycemia, hypokalemic alkalosis, Cushingoid features.
  • Hypoglycemia (non-islet cell) → high-molecular-weight IGF-2 (“big IGF-2”)
    • Fasting or exertional neuroglycopenia.
  • Feminization/gynecomastia → ectopic hCG/estrogens (rare).

Hepatic

  • Stauffer syndrome (non-metastatic hepatic dysfunction) → cytokine-mediated (notably IL-6)
    • ↑ALP/↑GGT, prolonged PT, hepatosplenomegaly ± fever; typically resolves after tumor removal. Icteric (jaundiced) variant exists.

Hematologic/Inflammatory

  • Anemia of chronic disease → IL-6 → hepcidin
  • Thrombocytosis/leukemoid reaction → IL-6, G-CSF.
  • Eosinophilia and elevated ESR/CRP → cytokine excess.
  • AA amyloidosis (rare, chronic inflammation).

Neuromuscular/Others

  • Peripheral neuropathy/polymyositis-like syndromes
  • Dermatomyositis (rare association)
  • Fever, cachexia → cytokines (IL-6/TNF-α).

Explanation of Other Options:

Transitional cell carcinoma of the renal pelvis (Option A): Presents with painless hematuria but lacks the classic triad or paraneoplastic syndromes seen in RCC.

Wilms' tumor (Option C): Pediatric renal malignancy typically affecting children <5 years old, not adults.

Medullary sponge kidney (Option D): A benign congenital disorder presenting with nephrocalcinosis and recurrent stones, not a solid renal mass or paraneoplastic features.

choices.text: Air or contrast enema reduction under radiologic guidance
Observation and repeat ultrasound after 12 hours

questions.text: A 10-month-old male infant presents with recurrent episodes of colicky abdominal pain, passage of "red-currant jelly" stools, and a palpable sausage-shaped mass in the right iliac fossa. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows the finding demonstrated in the image below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The ultrasound demonstrates the target sign, which is pathognomonic for acute ileocolic intussusception in infants. In a stable child without peritonitis, non-operative radiologic reduction with an air or contrast enema is the treatment of choice.

Acute Intussusception:

  • Definition & Pathogenesis
    • Intussusception is telescoping of one segment of the intestine into the adjacent distal segment.
    • Most common in children <2 years; peak incidence 5-10 months.
    • Often idiopathic, preceded by viral infection or Peyer's patch hyperplasia.
  • Clinical Features
    • Intermittent severe colicky pain, inconsolable crying.
    • Vomiting, abdominal distension.
    • Red-currant jelly stools due to mucosal ischemia.
  • Palpable "sausage-shaped" abdominal mass, typically in the right iliac fossa.
  • Imaging
    • Ultrasound: Diagnostic modality of choice.
      • Target sign (or doughnut sign) - concentric rings representing bowel within bowel.
      • Pseudo Kidney Sign
  • Barium Swallow:
    • Claw Sign
    • Coiled Spring Appearance
  • CT scan may also show the target sign but is rarely required in classic pediatric cases.
  • Management
    • Radiological reduction with air or contrast enema is first-line in hemodynamically stable children without peritonitis or perforation.
    • Surgery is indicated if:
      • Signs of peritonitis or perforation,
      • Failed non-operative reduction,
      • Pathological lead point suspected (e.g., Meckel's diverticulum, polyp).
  • Complications if Untreated
    • Bowel ischemia, gangrene, perforation, peritonitis.

Explanation of Other Options

Immediate laparotomy without further imaging (Option A): Reserved for patients with peritonitis, perforation, or failed enema reduction, not for a stable child with a diagnostic ultrasound.

Observation and repeat ultrasound after 12 hours (Option C): Risk of bowel ischemia and perforation; immediate intervention is required once diagnosis is confirmed.

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids (Option D): No role in the acute management of intussusception.

choices.text: Primary closure with a Graham omental patch

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of chronic NSAID use presents with sudden-onset severe epigastric pain and board-like rigidity of the abdomen for 4 hours. Upright chest X-ray reveals free gas under the diaphragm. After initial resuscitation and intravenous antibiotics, exploratory laparotomy is performed. The perforation in the first part of the duodenum measures 0.8 cm with healthy surrounding tissue. Which of the following is the most appropriate surgical management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

For small (<1 cm) perforations of the duodenum with healthy margins, the standard of care is simple closure reinforced with a well-vascularized omental (Graham) patch to seal the defect and reduce leak risk.

  • Pathophysiology & Indications
    • Perforation of a chronic duodenal ulcer causes sudden severe pain and diffuse peritonitis.
    • Upright X-ray typically shows free sub-diaphragmatic gas.
    • Early surgery is crucial, especially in elderly or delayed cases where mortality can reach 30%.
  • Surgical Management
    • Graham patch: Healthy omental tongue sutured over the perforation with interrupted seromuscular stitches.
  • Larger (>3 cm) or fibrotic ulcers may require antrectomy with Billroth II or Roux-en-Y reconstruction.
  • Perioperative Principles
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and antifungals.
    • Nasogastric decompression and peritoneal lavage.
    • pylori eradication and long-term acid suppression to prevent recurrence.

Explanation of Other Options:

Primary closure without omental reinforcement (Option A): Higher leak risk; standard of care includes omental patch reinforcement.

Antrectomy with Billroth II reconstruction (Option C): Reserved for giant (>3 cm), fibrotic, or malignant ulcers; not indicated for small perforations with healthy margins.

Duodenostomy with wide peritoneal drainage (Option D): Considered only for very large or difficult-to-close perforations, not for a small, healthy-edged ulcer.

choices.text: Administer intravenous 10% calcium gluconate followed by high-dose epinephrine boluses
Immediate intravenous bolus of 20% lipid emulsion at 1.5 mL/kg followed by infusion
Give intravenous magnesium sulfate 2 g and prepare for synchronized cardioversion
Rapid infusion of 0.75% bupivacaine to antagonize sodium channel blockade

questions.text: A 30-year-old parturient undergoing epidural analgesia for labor suddenly develops circumoral numbness, metallic taste, tinnitus, and agitation immediately after administration of a test dose of local anesthetic. Within minutes she progresses to generalized tonic-clonic seizures followed by hypotension and wide-complex ventricular tachycardia. Which of the following next steps is the most appropriate to both treat the acute cardiovascular toxicity and improve the chance of successful resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient shows classical progression of local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) - early CNS excitatory signs (tinnitus, metallic taste, circumoral numbness, agitation, seizures) followed by cardiovascular collapse with ventricular tachyarrhythmia.

  • Intravenous 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the recommended first-line treatment for bupivacaine-induced LAST that is refractory to standard resuscitation. Lipid infusion acts as a "lipid sink", binding lipophilic local anesthetics, particularly highly protein-bound and lipid-soluble agents like bupivacaine, and improves cardiac conduction and contractility.
  • Recommended dose: 5 mL/kg IV bolus over 1 minute, followed by 0.25 mL/kg/min infusion, with repeat bolus if cardiovascular stability is not restored.
  • If CV stability is not restored, repeat the 1.5 mL/kg bolus up to two additional times and increase infusion to 5 mL/kg/min. Do not exceed ~10 mL/kg in the first 30 minutes.
  • Supportive care includes airway management, 100% oxygen, benzodiazepines or propofol for seizures, and cautious use of vasopressors (preferably small doses of epinephrine ≤1 mcg/kg).
  • In LAST-modified ACLS, use small-dose epinephrine (≤1 mcg/kg); avoid vasopressin, lidocaine, and procainamide; amiodarone is preferred for refractory ventricular arrhythmias.
  • Bupivacaine is especially cardiotoxic due to slow dissociation from cardiac Na+ channels and is more likely to cause refractory ventricular arrhythmias compared to lidocaine or ropivacaine.

Related important points and concepts:

  • Risk factors: High vascular injection site (e.g., intercostal block), pregnancy, acidosis, hypoxemia.
  • CNS signs: Circumoral numbness → tinnitus → metallic taste → agitation → seizures → coma/respiratory arrest.
  • Cardiac signs: Initially tachycardia/hypertension (from CNS excitation or epinephrine admixture) → conduction delay, ventricular arrhythmias, hypotension, and cardiac arrest.
  • Prevention: Calculate maximum safe dose; aspirate before injection; incremental dosing (“every dose is a test dose”); use epinephrine-containing test dose to detect intravascular injection.

Explanation of other options:

Calcium gluconate with high-dose epinephrine (Option A): Useful for hyperkalemia or calcium channel toxicity, not for sodium channel blockade of LAST. High-dose epinephrine worsens arrhythmias and is not recommended.

Magnesium sulfate and cardioversion (Option C): Appropriate for torsades or specific ventricular arrhythmias but does not address the underlying lipophilic toxin.

Rapid infusion of 0.75% bupivacaine (Option D): Would worsen toxicity; bupivacaine is the causative agent and has the highest risk of refractory cardiac arrest among local anesthetics.

Key Takeaways:

  • LAST is a life-threatening emergency. Early CNS warning signs must be recognized.
  • 20% lipid emulsion therapy is the cornerstone of management for severe cardiovascular toxicity, especially with bupivacaine.
  • Prevention includes meticulous technique and adherence to maximum dose recommendations.

choices.text: Left eye complete blindness with loss of contralateral direct and ipsilateral consensual light reflex
Left eye complete blindness with loss of ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual light reflex
Left eye complete blindness with loss of ipsilateral direct and contralateral consensual light reflex
Left eye complete blindness with marcus-gunn pupil on right side

questions.text: What will be the consequence if the left optic nerve is cut?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Effect on Vision:

  • Cutting the left optic nerve severs all visual pathways from the left eye, resulting in complete blindness in the left eye.

Effect on Pupillary Light Reflex:

  • The afferent pathway of the light reflex (which carries light sensation) travels through the optic nerve.
  • Ipsilateral (Left) Direct Reflex:
    • When light is shone into the left (blind) eye, no sensory signal reaches the midbrain due to the severed optic nerve.
    • Thus, neither pupil constricts (no direct reflex in left eye and no consensual reflex in the right eye).
  • Contralateral (Right) Consensual Reflex:
    • When light is shone into the right (normal) eye, the consensual reflex should cause the left pupil to constrict.
    • However, because the left optic nerve is cut, the afferent pathway from the left eye is blocked, so the left pupil does not constrict in response to light in the right eye.

Conclusion:

  • Left eye complete blindness
  • Loss of left direct reflex (no constriction of left pupil when light is shone into left eye).
  • Loss of right consensual reflex (no constriction of left pupil when light is shone into right eye) (Option A, C ruled out).
  • Marcus Gunn pupil (afferent pupillary defect) is observed in the affected eye (left eye), not the right side (Option D ruled out).

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and redness and vision FC close to face in OPD the next day after cataract surgery. There are cells in Anterior chamber and cornea is very hazy. Retina can't be seen but USG B scan is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of TASS
  • Key Clinical Features Supporting TASS:
    • Timing: Onset within 24 hours after surgery (endophthalmitis typically occurs 2–7 days postoperatively).
    • Anterior Segment Involvement:
      • Severe corneal edema ("very hazy cornea") due to toxic damage to the endothelium.
      • Significant anterior chamber inflammation (cells).
    • Absence of Posterior Segment Involvement: Normal B-scan helps rule out endophthalmitis, which usually shows vitreous opacities.
    • Vision Loss: Profound vision loss (FC close to face) can occur in both TASS and endophthalmitis, but the rapidity and anterior findings favor TASS.

TASS:

  • A non-infectious inflammatory reaction caused by a toxic substance entering the anterior chamber during surgery.
  • Common culprits include contaminated solutions, enzymatic detergents, or metals from instruments.
  • Management:
    • TASS: Treated with intensive topical corticosteroids (e.g., prednisolone acetate every hour) to reduce inflammation.
    • Endophthalmitis: Requires urgent intravitreal antibiotics and possibly vitrectomy.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Endophthalmitis (Option A): Usually has later onset (≥2 days), more prominent vitreous involvement (abnormal B-scan), and often less corneal edema.

Sympathetic Ophthalmia (Option C): Occurs weeks/months after surgery/trauma and is bilateral; not an acute post-op complication.

Uveitis (Option D): Non-specific; post-op inflammation is common, but not to this degree. TASS is a distinct toxic/sterile inflammatory reaction.

choices.text: Transient hypocalcemia due to parathyroid insufficiency
External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve injury

questions.text: A 50-year-old professional singer undergoes a near-total thyroidectomy for a large multinodular goiter. Eight hours later, she complains of mild throat discomfort and progressive voice fatigue while attempting to speak in a high pitch. On examination, she has a slightly husky voice, but no stridor. Serum calcium is 8.4 mg/dL and Chvostek's sign is equivocal. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Selective difficulty in producing high-pitched sounds with borderline calcium levels and absence of classic tetany indicates injury to the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve, which tenses the vocal cord and controls pitch.

Post-Thyroidectomy Complications:

  • External Branch of Superior Laryngeal Nerve Injury (Most Common)
