    • Subtle symptoms: loss of high-pitch phonation, voice fatigue, inability to project voice.
    • Often missed unless patient is a professional voice user or tested for pitch.
  • Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN) Palsy
    • Hoarseness, breathy voice, weak cough; bilateral lesions can cause stridor.
    • Detected on laryngoscopy; incidence declines to ~0.5 % at 3 months if nerve identified.
  • Hypocalcemia / Hypoparathyroidism
    • Presents 2-5 days post-op with paresthesias, carpopedal spasm, positive Chvostek/Trousseau signs.
    • Borderline serum calcium soon after surgery is common but rarely symptomatic this early.
  • Hemorrhage / Neck Hematoma
    • Rapid neck swelling, airway compromise in first 24 h.

Explanation of Other Options:

Transient hypocalcemia (Option A): Early borderline calcium without tetany or perioral numbness is usually asymptomatic; does not cause selective pitch loss.

Unilateral RLN palsy (Option B): Produces coarse hoarseness and weak cough, not isolated loss of high-pitch phonation.

Early hypocalcemic laryngospasm (Option D): Presents with stridor and carpopedal spasm; absent here.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a long history of chronic hepatitis B and cirrhosis presents with weight loss and vague right upper quadrant pain. Laboratory studies reveal markedly elevated alphafetoprotein levels. Triple-phase CT of the liver shows a 3.5 cm solitary lesion with arterial phase enhancement and rapid washout in the portal venous phase. Which of the following is the most significant risk factor for the development of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hepatitis B virus infection:

  • Most important global risk factor for HCC (especially in Asia and sub-Saharan Africa).
  • Can cause hepatocarcinogenesis even without cirrhosis.
  • Transmitted perinatally in high-prevalence regions → leads to chronic infection.
  • Integrates into host genome, promoting genetic instability and tumor formation.
  • Globally accounts for the majority of HCC cases.

Hepatocellular Carcinoma:

  • Most common cause worldwide: Chronic HBV infection (>50% of cases).
  • Other risk factors: Chronic HCV infection, aflatoxin exposure (e.g., contaminated rice), chronic alcohol exposure, obesity, and diabetes mellitus.
  • Diagnosis: Triple-phase CT or MRI of the liver is standard.
  • Tumor Marker: PIVKA (Best), AFP
  • Management: Surgical resection or liver transplantation based on Barcelona Clinic Liver Group (BCLC) staging and Milan criteria.

Fibrolamellar Variant:

  • HBV is not a risk-factor.
  • Female predominance
  • Tumor Marker: Neurotensin
  • Common in young individuals.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chronic alcohol consumption (Option A): Important contributor but accounts for a smaller proportion of global HCC cases compared to HBV infection.

Diabetes mellitus and obesity (Option C): Recognized independent risk factors, but less significant than HBV in global incidence.

Exposure to aflatoxin-contaminated grains (Option D): Causes seasonal/geographic variation and synergizes with HBV, but not the leading worldwide cause.

choices.text: 160°C at normal pressure for 30 minutes
121°C at 15 lb pressure for 15 minutes
121°C at 15 lb pressure for 30 minutes

questions.text: What are the ideal temperature and pressure conditions used in an autoclave to achieve sterilisation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The standard autoclave conditions are 121°C at 15 lb pressure for 15 minutes. This setting is effective in destroying not only vegetative bacteria but also the more resistant forms, such as bacterial spores.

  • An autoclaveis a method of moist heat sterilisation.
  • Its mechanism of action iscoagulation and denaturation of microbial proteins.
  • Steam under pressurefacilitates deeper penetration of heat into materials like dressings and instruments.
  • There is adirect relationship between pressure and the temperature of steam.
  • Steam under pressure attains a temperatureabove 100°C, which enhances microbial killing, including spores.
  • Control of Autoclave: Spores of Bacillus stearothermophilus.
  • Autoclaves are mainly used to sterilisesurgical instruments, dressings, and heat-resistant pharmaceutical preparations.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with right lower quadrant abdominal pain that initially started near the umbilicus, accompanied by anorexia, nausea, and a low-grade fever of 38 °C. On examination, there is marked tenderness and rebound tenderness in the right iliac fossa. His total leukocyte count is 15,000/mm3 with a left shift. Based on the Alvarado (MANTRELS) score, what is the total score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Alvarado (MANTRELS) score is a clinical tool for diagnosing acute appendicitis. Each symptom, sign, or laboratory finding contributes to the total score.

  • Calculation for this patient:
    • Migratory right iliac fossa pain: 1
    • Anorexia: 1
    • Nausea/vomiting: 1
    • Tenderness in RIF: 2
    • Rebound tenderness: 1
    • Elevated temperature: 1
    • Leukocytosis (>10,000/mm³): 2
    • Left shift of neutrophils: 1
    • Total = 10/10

A score ≥7 is strongly predictive of acute appendicitis and usually warrants surgical intervention.

(Other options ruled out)

  • Key Points:
    • Score 5-6: Compatible with appendicitis, warrants observation or imaging.
    • Score 7-8: Probable appendicitis, surgical evaluation advised.
    • Score 9-10: Definite appendicitis, surgery strongly indicated.

Table: Alvarado (MANTRELS) Scoring System:

  • Score ≥7: Strongly predictive of acute appendicitis.
  • Score 5-6: Equivocal, needs imaging.
  • Score ≤4: Appendicitis unlikely.

choices.text: The tract will curve to open in the posterior midline.
The tract will pass in a straight radial line to the internal opening.
The tract will open into the anterior midline regardless of location.
The tract will invariably extend above the levator ani into the supralevator space.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a chronic discharging sinus 3 cm from the anal verge at the 2 o'clock position (anterior quadrant). There is no history of tuberculosis or Crohn's disease. According to Goodsall's rule, which of the following statements best predicts the course of the primary fistulous tract?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Goodsall's rule states that external openings anterior to a transverse line through the anus typically have straight, radial tracts to the internal opening, whereas those posterior to this line generally follow a curved path to the posterior midline.

  • Key Concepts of Goodsall's Rule
  • Key Concepts of Goodsall's Rule
    • Anterior external openings: Track runs straight toward the nearest point on the dentate line.
    • Posterior external openings: Track curves to the posterior midline internal opening.
    • Exceptions: Anterior openings more than 3 cm from the anal verge may follow a curved posterior course.
  • Clinical Assessment of Fistula-in-Ano
    • Identify site of internal and external openings.
    • Determine course of primary tract and any secondary extensions.
    • Imaging such as MRI fistulogram is useful for complex or recurrent fistulae
  • Management:
    • Definitive treatment is surgical (fistulotomy or seton placement) based on sphincter involvement.

Park's Classification:
Intersphincteric (~45%)

  • Tract runs in the intersphincteric plane from internal opening to perianal skin.
  • External sphincter not crossed.
  • Usual op: fistulotomy (if low); watch for secondary intersphincteric abscess.

Transsphincteric (~30%)

  • Tract passes through both internal and external sphincters to the ischioanal fossa and then to skin.
  • “Low” vs “high” depends on height through external sphincter.
  • Low: fistulotomy; High: seton, LIFT, advancement flap to protect continence.

Suprasphincteric (~20%)

  • From internal opening → up in intersphincteric plane above the puborectalis → arches over it → down through levator into ischioanal fossa → skin.
  • Management: draining seton ± staged procedures (risk to continence if divided).

Extrasphincteric (~5%)

  • Tract goes from rectum/rectosigmoid through levator ani to skin, bypassing sphincter complex.
  • Often secondary to trauma, foreign body, Crohn's, or pelvic sepsis.
  • Treat cause first; sphincter-sparing approaches (no simple fistulotomy).

Explanation of Other Options:

The tract will curve to open in the posterior midline (Option A): Applies to posterior external openings or anterior openings >3 cm from the anal verge, not to this 3 cm anterior lesion.

The tract will open into the anterior midline regardless of location (Option C): Internal openings may be midline, but the course is not "regardless of location"; it follows Goodsall's rule.

The tract will invariably extend above the levator ani into the supralevator space (Option D): Supralevator extension suggests a high fistula or secondary spread and is not predicted solely by the external opening site.

choices.text: Immediate wide local excision of the tumour including biopsy tract
Incisional biopsy through a transverse skin crease at the most prominent area of the mass
Image-guided core needle (Tru-cut) biopsy after local staging investigations
Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) of the lesion

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents with a painless, progressively enlarging deep thigh mass for 4 months. MRI of the entire thigh reveals a well-circumscribed lesion beneath the fascia, measuring 8 cm, with no bone involvement. Chest CT shows multiple small nodules in the lung apices. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management to establish the diagnosis and guide definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Soft-tissue sarcoma is suspected in any deep, painless, enlarging mass >5 cm. As per Bailey & Love, a definitive diagnosis requires histology obtained via a planned core (Tru-cut) or image-guided biopsy performed after local staging. The biopsy track must be placed so it can be excised during the final wide resection to prevent tumour seeding.

Diagnostic and Management Principles of Soft-Tissue Sarcoma:

  • Clinical Red Flags:
    • Mass >5 cm, increasing in size, deep to fascia, or recurrent after prior excision.
    • Often painless, which delays presentation.
  • Investigations:
    • MRI of the whole involved compartment to delineate local extent and detect skip lesions.
    • CT chest for lung metastases (most common site).
    • Image-guided core biopsy is preferred; open/incisional biopsies risk contaminating multiple planes and complicating later excision.
  • Histology:
    • Spindle-cell morphology is frequent (e.g., undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, synovial sarcoma).
  • Definitive Treatment:
    • Wide surgical excision including the biopsy tract, with adjuvant radiotherapy to reduce local recurrence.
    • Chemotherapy has a limited role.

Explanation of Other Options:

Immediate wide local excision (Option A): Contraindicated before histological confirmation and proper staging; may compromise margins and oncological outcomes.

Incisional biopsy through a transverse skin crease (Option B): Incorrect approach; transverse incisions and poorly planned tracts increase the risk of tumour seeding and complicate subsequent definitive resection.

Fine-needle aspiration cytology (Option D): Insufficient for sarcoma diagnosis; does not provide adequate tissue architecture for grading and subtyping.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoes a routine fundus examination. The ophthalmologist documents the presence of microaneurysms, dot and blot hemorrhages, and hard exudates in the posterior pole. This clinical picture is most consistent with a diagnosis of which stage of diabetic retinopathy?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The findings described are classic lesions of diabetic retinopathy. Their combination and location are key to staging the disease according to the International Clinical Diabetic Retinopathy Disease Severity Scale.

Lesions and Their Significance:

  • Microaneurysms:
    • The earliest clinically detectable sign. They appear as tiny, round, red dots.
    • Pathology: Outpouchings in the capillary wall caused by pericyte loss and capillary wall weakness.
    • Significance: Their presence alone defines Mild NPDR.
  • Dot and Blot Hemorrhages:
    • Description:
      • Dot hemorrhages: Small, round intraretinal hemorrhages located in the inner nuclear layer.
      • Blot hemorrhages: Larger, darker, and more irregular hemorrhages located in the outer plexiform layer.
    • Pathology: Caused by the rupture of weakened capillaries and microaneurysms.
    • Significance: The presence of hemorrhages and microaneurysms indicates a more advanced stage than Mild NPDR.
  • Hard Exudates:
    • Yellowish-white, waxy, well-defined deposits with sharp margins, often arranged in clumps or rings (circinate rings) in the posterior pole.
    • Pathology: These are lipoproteins leaking from incompetent capillaries and microaneurysms. They are composed of lipid-laden macrophages and serum lipoproteins.
    • Significance: Their presence, especially in the posterior pole, signifies increased vascular permeability and, together with hemorrhages beyond isolated microaneurysms, are consistent with ≥ moderate NPDR.

Staging:

According to the International Clinical Diabetic Retinopathy Disease Severity Scale:

  • Mild NPDR: Only microaneurysms.
  • Moderate NPDR: Characterized by the presence of more than just microaneurysms but less than severe NPDR. This includes:
    • Microaneurysms
    • Hemorrhages (dot and blot)
    • Hard exudates
    • Cotton-wool spots may also be present.
  • Severe NPDR: Defined by specific "4-2-1" rules (e.g., hemorrhages in 4 quadrants, venous beading in 2 quadrants, IRMA in 1 quadrant). The question does not mention these features.
  • Proliferative Diabetic Retinopathy (PDR): Defined by the presence of neovascularization or vitreous/preretinal hemorrhage, which are not mentioned.

Diabetic retinopathy:

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): In a woman with a suspicious breast lump, the combination of clinical examination, imaging (mammography/ultrasonography), and core needle biopsy provides nearly 100 % diagnostic accuracy and guides therapy including sentinel node biopsy and HER2-targeted treatment when indicated.
Reason (R): Triple assessment simultaneously establishes tumour receptor status (ER, PR, HER2) and basal-like markers (e.g., for triple-negative breast cancer) without the need for additional tissue sampling.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Triple assessment
    • Clinical breast examination
    • Imaging (mammography and/or ultrasound)
    • Tissue sampling (FNAC or preferably core biopsy)
    • Has a near-perfect diagnostic accuracy when the three components are concordant.
    • This allows early planning of definitive surgery and sentinel lymph node biopsy.
  • Therapeutic implications: HER2 over-expression, if demonstrated on immunohistochemistry or FISH, supports adjuvant or neoadjuvant trastuzumab therapy. Patients with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) require systemic chemotherapy and closer surveillance.
  • Key point: While the biopsy component of triple assessment provides tissue for histopathology, receptor testing (ER/PR/HER2) and basal markers for TNBC are performed as additional immunohistochemical studies- not automatically obtained by the act of “triple assessment” itself. Separate laboratory processing is required.

choices.text: Immediate escharotomy of the right arm is indicated to prevent vascular compromise.
Total fluid requirement in the first 24 hours is approximately 4 L, half to be given in the first 8 hours from arrival.
Hypertonic saline is preferred initially because it reduces tissue oedema and prevents compartment syndrome.
Colloid infusion with human albumin should be started within the first 4 hours to maintain oncotic pressure.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man (weight = 70 kg) is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after a kerosene-stove explosion. He has deep dermal and full-thickness burns involving the anterior trunk and both upper limbs. Examination shows a tense, circumferential burn around the right arm with rapidly worsening distal pain and pallor. Urine output is 10 mL over the first hour. Which of the following statements regarding his initial management is most accurate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Parkland formula: Fluid requirement = 4 mL × %TBSA × body weight (kg) (using Ringer’s lactate/Hartmann’s).
    • Burn area: Anterior trunk = 18% + both upper limbs = 18% → 36% TBSA (Rule of 9s).
    • Fluid = 4 × 36 × 70 ≈ 10 L in first 24 h.
    • Half (≈5 L) is infused in the first 8 h from the time of burn, not from arrival, so with a 30-minute delay the first half must be given within the remaining 7.5 h.
  • Escharotomy indication: Circumferential deep burns can create a non-compliant eschar causing compartment syndrome with distal ischaemia, requiring urgent escharotomy to restore perfusion.
    • When to do it (any limb/digit or chest/abdomen with circumferential/near-circumferential deep burns):
      • Vascular compromise signs: pain out of proportion, pallor/coolness, paresthesia, delayed/absent cap refill, absent/weak Doppler, tense non-compressible eschar.
      • Compartment pressure >30-40 mmHg (if measurable).
      • Chest/abdomen: rising peak/plateau pressures, hypoventilation, paradoxical chest wall motion, impaired ventilation.
    • Ringer Lactate: Balanced solution → less hyperchloremic metabolic acidosis and less edema than large-volume NS.
    • Monitoring: Urine output goal is 5-1 mL/kg/h; this patient’s 10 mL/h (<0.15 mL/kg/h) indicates inadequate perfusion.

TBSA assessment

Count only partial- and full-thickness areas (exclude erythema).

Burn depth (clinical features & healing)

Explanation of Other Options:

Total fluid requirement in the first 24 hours is approximately 4 L, half to be given in the first 8 hours from arrival (Option B): This underestimates the patient’s needs. Using the Parkland formula (4 mL × %TBSA × weight), the correct 24-hour requirement is about 10 L, not 4 L, and the clock starts from the time of burn, not from hospital arrival.

Hypertonic saline is preferred initially because it reduces tissue oedema and prevents compartment syndrome (Option C): Hypertonic saline can cause hypernatraemia and renal dysfunction and has no proven advantage over crystalloids for initial burn resuscitation. It is not recommended as first-line therapy.

Colloid infusion with human albumin should be started within the first 4 hours to maintain oncotic pressure (Option D): During the early post-burn capillary-leak phase, colloids worsen tissue oedema. Albumin or other colloids are considered only after the first 12 hours once capillary integrity begins to recover.

questions.text:
Which of the following pathogens requires biosafety level-4 handling?
i. Ebola virus
ii. Mycobacterium tuberculosis
iii. SARS-CoV-2
iv. Marburg virus
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Biosafety levels (BSL) are used to identify the protective measures needed in a laboratory setting to protect workers, the environment, and the public.
  • Biosafety level 4 is the highest in the World Health Organisation system of safety and containment.
  • Marburg and Ebola viruses fall into this risk group: BSL-4.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535351/

choices.text: Emergency right hemicolectomy with primary anastomosis
Endoscopic decompression with flatus tube placement and elective resection
Immediate exploratory laparotomy with Hartmann's procedure

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with progressive abdominal distension, absolute constipation, and mild vomiting for 2 days. He has a history of chronic constipation and antipsychotic use. On examination, the abdomen is markedly distended and tympanic, with mild diffuse tenderness. No hernia sites are involved. An erect abdominal radiograph shows a massively dilated loop of colon running diagonally from the right lower quadrant to the left upper quadrant with two fluid levels. No small bowel air is seen. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The classic radiographic finding of a massively distended colonic loop running diagonally across the abdomen with two fluid levels in an elderly patient with chronic constipation is highly suggestive of sigmoid volvulus, which is the most common type of large bowel volvulus in adults. Initial management is endoscopic decompression using a rigid/flexible sigmoidoscope with flatus tube placement, followed by elective sigmoid colectomy to prevent recurrence.

  • Elderly patients with chronic constipation and psychiatric medication use are at high risk for sigmoid volvulus.
  • Sigmoid volvulus typically presents with progressive distension, absolute constipation, and early tympany.
  • The radiograph shows the classic “coffee-bean” or inverted-U sign with a loop of bowel extending from the right lower to the left upper quadrant and absence of rectal gas.
  • Endoscopic decompression is the first-line treatment when there is no evidence of bowel gangrene or perforation.
  • Definitive management is elective sigmoid colectomy after decompression to prevent recurrence.
  • Caecal volvulus, in contrast, usually presents with an acute obstruction and shows the caecum displaced to the left upper quadrant on imaging, often requiring surgical resection or caecopexy.

Comparison Table: Sigmoid vs Caecal Volvulus

Explanation of Other Options:

Emergency right hemicolectomy with primary anastomosis (Option A): Indicated for caecal volvulus or when gangrene is suspected, not first-line for uncomplicated sigmoid volvulus.

Caecopexy with caecostomy (Option C): Used for caecal volvulus when bowel is viable, not appropriate for sigmoid volvulus.

Immediate exploratory laparotomy with Hartmann's procedure (Option D): Reserved for perforation or gangrene in sigmoid volvulus, not initial management in a stable patient.

Key Takeaways:

  • Sigmoid volvulus is the most common large bowel volvulus; X-ray shows the coffee-bean sign.
  • Initial treatment is endoscopic decompression, followed by elective resection to prevent recurrence.
  • Caecal volvulus usually requires surgical management as endoscopic decompression is ineffective.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with a painless, gradually enlarging left scrotal swelling. On standing, a "bag-of-worms" consistency is palpable above the testis and the swelling reduces partially on lying down. Transillumination is negative. Doppler ultrasound demonstrates retrograde venous reflux.
Assertion (A): Microsurgical varicocelectomy or percutaneous embolization is the treatment of choice to improve fertility in men with clinically significant varicocele and abnormal semen parameters.
Reason (R): Varicoceles commonly cause infertility by raising intratesticular temperature and impairing spermatogenesis.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Both statements are correct and the pathophysiology of raised intratesticular temperature directly explains why surgical correction improves fertility outcomes.

  • Varicocele hallmark: Dilated pampiniform plexus giving a classic "bag-of-worms" feel, usually left-sided due to left renal vein drainage and possible “nutcracker” effect.
  • Fertility impact: Increased venous pressure → higher intratesticular temperature → impaired sperm count, motility, and morphology.
  • Management: Symptomatic or fertility-related varicocele is best treated with microsurgical varicocelectomy (lowest recurrence, fewer complications) or percutaneous embolization.
  • Hydrocele contrast: Hydrocele is a fluctuant swelling that transilluminates, encloses testis and epididymis, and is usually painless; treatment is surgical only if large or symptomatic (Lord’s plication or Jaboulay’s eversion).
  • Ultrasound role: Doppler demonstrates venous reflux in varicocele and excludes renal or retroperitoneal masses when indicated.

Comparison Table: Hydrocele vs Varicocele

Key Takeaways:

  • Hydrocele: Transilluminates, encloses testis, usually idiopathic or secondary.
  • Varicocele: Bag-of-worms feel, left > right, infertility risk, negative transillumination.
  • Imaging: Doppler US confirms varicocele reflux and rules out renal/retroperitoneal pathology.
  • Management: Hydrocele → surgical plication/eversion if symptomatic; Varicocele → microsurgical varicocelectomy or embolization when fertility is affected.

questions.text:
What is the interpretation of this test when the Maddox rod is placed in front of the right eye as shown in this picture and the patient's response is as given:


What the patient sees:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Maddox rod test with the rod over the right eye and the response - the red streak is seen to the right of the light, demonstrates uncrossed diplopia.
  • This finding is diagnostic for a latent inward misalignment of the visual axes, known as
  • The Rule for Interpretation:
    • The patient is asked where the vertical streak is in relation to the white light.
    • "Uncrossed" diplopia indicates esodeviation.
    • "Crossed" diplopia indicates exodeviation.
  • Applying the Rule to the Right Eye:
    • Maddox Rod on the Right Eye: The right eye sees the red streak.
    • The patient reports the streak is to the RIGHT of the light.
    • This is a report of UNCROSSED diplopia (the red image is on the same side as the eye seeing it).
    • Uncrossed diplopia means the eyes are misaligned in an Esodirection.
  • Since the Maddox rod is on the right eye, this esodeviation is measured from the perspective of that eye. Therefore, the diagnosis is Esophoria.
  • Corrected with 'Prism Base out'.

choices.text: Age >55 years, WBC count >16 x 109/L, Blood glucose >11 mmol/L
Serum calcium <2.0 mmol/L, Base deficit >4 mmol/L, Fluid sequestration >6 L
LDH >350 U/L, AST >250 U/L, PaO2 <8 kPa
Blood urea nitrogen rise >5 mg/dL, Serum albumin <32 g/L, AST >200 U/L

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are assessed within 48 hours of admission as part of Ranson's criteria for predicting the severity of acute pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Ranson criteria predict the severity of acute pancreatitis and involve parameters assessed at admission and again at 48 hours. A score of ≥3 indicates a severe attack.

  • Parameters assessed within 48 hours include:
    • Haematocrit fall ≥10%
    • Blood urea nitrogen rise >5 mg/dL (1.8 mmol/L) despite fluids
    • Serum calcium <2.0 mmol/L
    • Base deficit >4 mmol/L
    • Fluid sequestration >6 L
    • Arterial oxygen saturation (PaO2) <8 kPa (60 mmHg)
  • Hence, Serum calcium <2.0 mmol/L, Base deficit >4 mmol/L, and Fluid sequestration >6 L are correct.

The Ranson and Glasgow scoring systems to predict the severity of acute pancreatitis: In both systems, disease is classified as severe when three or more factors are present.

Ranson's Criteria:

  • Severe acute pancreatitis: Ranson score ≥3 within 48 hours.
  • Imaging: Contrast-enhanced CT is the gold standard for assessing severity and complications.

Glasgow Scoring System

  • A Glasgow score ≥3 within 48 hours of admission indicates severe acute pancreatitis requiring intensive monitoring and aggressive management.

Explanation of Other Options:

Age >55 years, WBC count >16 × 109/L, Blood glucose >11 mmol/L (Option A): These are admission parameters, not 48-hour parameters.

LDH >350 U/L, AST >250 U/L, PaO2 <8 kPa (Option C): LDH and AST are admission parameters; only PaO2 <8 kPa is a 48-hour parameter.

Blood urea nitrogen rise >5 mg/dL, Serum albumin <32 g/L, AST >200 U/L (Option D): Rise in blood urea nitrogen is a 48-hour parameter, but serum albumin and AST >200 U/L are not part of Ranson's 48-hour criteria.

choices.text: Start intravenous unfractionated heparin and proceed to urgent surgical embolectomy
Begin intra-arterial thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator immediately
Perform only duplex ultrasonography to localise the site of occlusion before intervention
Observe with systemic anticoagulation alone if Doppler venous signals are audible

questions.text: A 64-year-old man with a history of atrial fibrillation presents with sudden-onset severe pain, numbness, and coldness in his left leg for 3 hours. Examination reveals pallor, absent distal pulses, and paraesthesia. Doppler signals are absent. The limb is cold, and passive movement of the toes elicits severe pain. Which of the following is the most appropriate immediate step in management after rapid bedside classification of the limb?
questions.solution:
Explanation

  • Diagnosis: Sudden onset of severe limb pain, pallor, paraesthesia, pulselessness, and poikilothermia indicates acute limb ischaemia (ALI), most likely embolic due to atrial fibrillation.
  • 6 Ps of ALI: Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paraesthesia, Paralysis, Poikilothermia.
  • Rutherford classification: This patient has Class IIb (immediately threatened limb) because of severe pain, sensory deficit beyond toes, and absent Doppler arterial signals. Immediate revascularisation is needed.
  • Management Steps:
    • Immediate IV unfractionated heparin (5,000 U bolus) to prevent thrombus propagation.
    • Urgent surgical embolectomy using a Fogarty catheter is indicated for embolic occlusion with threatened limb.
    • Delay beyond 6 hours risks irreversible tissue loss and amputation.

Table: Rutherford Classification of Acute Limb Ischaemia

Explanation of other options:

Begin intra-arterial thrombolysis with tissue plasminogen activator immediately (Option B): Thrombolysis is reserved for Rutherford IIa (marginally threatened) limbs when ischaemia is less severe and time to revascularisation allows; not appropriate for immediately threatened limbs needing urgent surgery.

Perform only duplex ultrasonography to localise the site of occlusion before intervention (Option C): Imaging should not delay treatment in Class IIb limbs. Immediate heparin and surgical revascularisation are indicated without waiting for confirmatory imaging.

Observe with systemic anticoagulation alone if Doppler venous signals are audible (Option D): Observation with anticoagulation is suitable for Class I viable limbs, not for immediately threatened limbs with absent arterial signals and sensory-motor deficit.

Key Takeaways:

  • Acute limb ischaemia with absent arterial Doppler signals and neurological deficit is Rutherford IIb → requires immediate heparinisation and surgical embolectomy.
  • Delay beyond 6 hours usually leads to irreversible limb loss.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with severe pain and swelling around the elbow after a fall on an outstretched hand. An Xray taken revealed a fracture of the distal humerus, as shown below. Which of the following signs/tests would be most likely positive in this child?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The X-ray shows a displaced supracondylar humerus fracture, which is commonly associated with injury to the median nerve, particularly its anterior interosseous branch.

Injury to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve results in the inability to make a circle with the thumb and index finger, producing the OK sign.

Nerve Injury in Supracondylar Fracture

  • The radial nerve, median nerve or ulnar nerve may be injured.
  • The most commonly injured nerve is the median nerve, specifically the anterior interosseous branch, which potentially causes an inability to perform the "ok" sign (Kilo Nevins sign).
  • The patient is unable to make the ‘OK sign’ – pinching with the thumb and index finger joints flexed, like a ring, because of weakness of the flexor pollicis longus and flexor digitorum profundus. 

Explanation of other options:

Wrist drop (Option B): The presence of wrist drop indicates radial nerve injury, which is commonly associated with fracture of the shaft of the humerus.

Claw hand (Option C): In supracondylar fractures, claw hand usually results from iatrogenic ulnar nerve injury due to careless pin placement in surgical fixation of the fracture, but it is rare.

Froment sign (Option D): Froment’s sign tests for ulnar nerve dysfunction, specifically assessing the adductor pollicis muscle. It is positive when the thumb flexes while trying to hold a piece of paper between the thumb and index finger. This sign is not typically seen in supracondylar humerus fractures.

choices.text: IV bisphosphonate and outpatient observation because imaging is already positive
Focused (minimally invasive) right inferior parathyroidectomy, using intra-operative PTH criteria to confirm cure
Four-gland exploration with subtotal (3(1/2)-gland) parathyroidectomy because she is <50 years old
Genetic testing for familial hypocalciuric hypercalcaemia (FHH) prior to any surgery

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman has 6 months of recurrent nephrolithiasis and diffuse bone pain. Examination is unremarkable. Labs show: total Ca 3.05 mmol/L, phosphate low, PTH inappropriately elevated; creatinine normal. Alkaline phosphatase is mildly raised. Twenty-four-hour urinary calcium is increased. Neck ultrasonography suggests a 1.8-cm hypoechoic oval lesion inferior to the right thyroid lobe; 99mTc-sestamibi shows concordant focal retention in the same area. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The presentation and biochemistry are classic for primary hyperparathyroidism due to a solitary adenoma; concordant sestamibi + ultrasound localisation supports a focused parathyroidectomy, and intra-operative PTH drop (Miami criterion: fall into normal range and to <50% of peak by ~10 min) confirms cure.

  • “Stones, bones, abdominal groans, psychiatric overtones” have largely been replaced by more subtle or asymptomatic presentations, but renal stones and bone pain still occur; ↑Ca with inappropriately ↑PTH and ↓phosphate establishes PHPT (biochemical diagnosis).
  • FHH must be excluded when hypercalcaemia is mild; a 24-h urinary calcium that is elevated makes FHH unlikely (FHH shows hypocalciuria).
  • Localisation imaging guides strategy, not diagnosis. Sestamibi (MIBI) and neck ultrasound are first-line and, when concordant, allow a minimally invasive (focused) parathyroidectomy with cure rates comparable to four-gland exploration.
  • Intra-operative PTH monitoring: a drop to normal and to <50% of the highest pre-excision value at 10 minutes (Miami criterion) predicts single-gland cure.
  • Indications for surgery in PHPT include age <50 years, serum Ca > upper limit by ≥0.25 mmol/L, skeletal/renal criteria, symptoms (stones, bone disease). She meets multiple triggers (age <50, symptomatic stones, hypercalcaemia).
  • Hungry bone syndrome risk is higher with elevated bone turnover (e.g., raised ALP); anticipate postoperative transient hypocalcaemia and manage with calcium ± vitamin D.
  • MEN associations: PHPT can occur in MEN1 and MEN2A; multigland disease prompts bilateral neck exploration, but this case has imaging-concordant single-gland disease.

Miami criteria (IOPTH) during parathyroidectomy:


Explanation of other options:

IV bisphosphonate and outpatient observation because imaging is already positive (Option A): Incorrect. Bisphosphonates can transiently lower calcium but do not treat the source; symptomatic PHPT or guideline-positive disease requires definitive surgical excision of the adenoma despite positive imaging.

Four-gland exploration with subtotal (3½-gland) parathyroidectomy because she is <50 years old (Option C): Incorrect. Age <50 is an indication for surgery, not for routine bilateral exploration. Four-gland exploration is reserved for discordant/negative imaging, familial/MEN, lithium-related or multigland disease. Concordant imaging supports a focused operation.

Genetic testing for FHH prior to any surgery (Option D): Incorrect. FHH is suggested by hypocalciuria (Ca/Cr clearance ratio <0.02). This patient’s urinary calcium is elevated, making FHH unlikely; genetic testing is not required before proceeding to surgery.

Key Takeaways:

  • PHPT is a biochemical diagnosis: ↑ionised/total Ca with inappropriately ↑PTH, ↓phosphate.
  • Concordant sestamibi + ultrasound → focused parathyroidectomy with intra-op PTH confirmation (Miami criterion).
  • Exclude FHH with low urinary calcium; elevated urinary calcium supports PHPT.
  • Surgery is indicated in age <50, symptomatic disease (stones/bone), or guideline skeletal/renal thresholds.
  • Anticipate post-op hypocalcaemia/hungry bone, especially with high bone turnover.

questions.text: Nalgonda technique for defluridation is in what sequence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The Nalgonda technique uses lime and alum in sequence for defluridation.

Nalgonda technique:

  • Developed by the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (NEERI), Nagpur.
  • A chemical defluoridation method for safe drinking water.

Process steps:

  • Addition of lime and alum in sequence.
    • Flocculation - formation of chemical flocs.
    • Sedimentation - settling of flocs with fluoride and impurities.
    • Filtration - to obtain treated, fluoride-free water.
  • Effective in reducing fluoride levels to a safe range.
  • Moderately expensive but suitable for community-level application in endemic fluorosis areas.

Alum + bleaching powder (Option D) is not used in the Nalgonda technique. Bleaching powder can be used after the technique to clean the water.

choices.text: The most common cause in children is a supracondylar humerus fracture
Emergent fasciotomy of the affected compartment is essential
Pain with passive stretching is an early finding
Delta pressure > 30 mm is diagnostic of compartment syndrome

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the ER after he sustained a crush injury to his forearm. If compartment syndrome is suspected, which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Compartment syndrome occurs when increased pressure within a closed fascial compartment compromises tissue perfusion, leading to ischemia and necrosis.

  • The most common cause in children is supracondylar humerus fracture.
  • The definitive treatment is emergent fasciotomy of the affected compartment.
  • Pain on passive stretch is the most sensitive early clinical sign.
  • Diagnostic thresholds:
    • Absolute compartment pressure ≥ 30–45 mmHg, or
    • Delta pressure (diastolic BP – compartment pressure) < 30 mmHg.
      Thus, the statement that “Delta pressure > 30 mm is diagnostic” is false.

Compartment syndrome

  • Surgical emergency resulting from increased pressure within a closed anatomic space and leading to reduced capillary blood flow below the threshold for local tissue perfusion and oxygen delivery.
  • Prolonged ischemia secondary to a missed or delayed diagnosis may result in irreversible muscle or nerve damage within a compartment.
  • Compartment syndrome is a clinical diagnosis; a high index of suspicion is critical after crush injuries and limb reperfusion.
  • In children, the most common cause is a supracondylar humerus fracture. (Option A ruled out)
  • The most common symptom associated is pain that does not subside with analgesics and pain out of proportion to the signs.

6Ps of compartment syndrome

  • Pain on passive stretch (Option C ruled out)
  • Pain
  • Pallor
  • Pulselessness
  • Paraesthesia
  • Paralysis
    • Late signs: Paraesthesia, pallor, pulselessness, and paralysis.
    • Pain on passive stretching of the affected compartment is among the earliest and most sensitive findings associated with compartment syndrome.

Diagnosis:

  • Compartment pressures should be measured in all equivocal cases and in unresponsive patients with a manometer.
  • Compartment pressure > 30mm is diagnostic of compartment syndrome. 

Treatment: Fasciotomy

  • A surgical procedure that involves cutting the fascia, or connective tissue, that surrounds a muscle compartment to relieve pressure. (Option B ruled out).
  • The delta pressure thresholdis used to decide the need for fasciotomy in suspected compartment syndrome.
  • Delta pressure (ΔP) =Diastolic blood pressure (DBP) − Compartment pressure
    • ΔP ≤ 30 mmHg→ indicates need for urgent fasciotomy.
    • ΔP > 30 mmHg → may be monitored if clinical signs are stable.

choices.text: Activity of RPE and outer segment of photoreceptors
Any lesion proximal to photoreceptor may have normal EOG
A low EOG is seen in Best disease

questions.text: False statement about EOG is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The Arden index (also called the light-to-dark ratio) is a key measurement in the electrooculogram (EOG) test.
  • It compares the electrical potential of the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) in light-adapted and dark-adapted states.
  • Normal Arden index is typically ≥ 1.85 (or 185%).
  • A value below 1.65 (165%) is considered abnormal, and values between 1.65 and 1.85 are borderline.
  • Therefore, an Arden index < 185 (or <1.85) is not normal; it indicates dysfunction of the RPE-photoreceptor complex.

Clinical Relevance:

  • The EOG is abnormal in diffuse RPE disorders (e.g., Best disease, chloroquine toxicity) but normal in localized diseases (e.g., AMD) or lesions proximal to the photoreceptors.

Explanation for Incorrect options:

Activity of RPE and outer segment of photoreceptors (Option A): The EOG primarily reflects the function of the RPE and the photoreceptor outer segments (especially cones).

Any lesion proximal to photoreceptor may have normal EOG (Option C): Lesions proximal to the photoreceptors (e.g., inner retinal layers, optic nerve) do not affect the EOG, as it is generated by the RPE-photoreceptor complex. Thus, EOG remains normal in conditions like optic neuropathy.

A low EOG is seen in Best disease (Option D): Best disease (vitelliform macular dystrophy) is characterized by a profoundly reduced Arden index (<1.65) due to RPE dysfunction. It is an autosomal dominant disorder due to the mutation in the BEST 1 gene.

The various stages include: Stage I (previtelliform), Stage II (vitelliform), Stage III (pseudo hypopyon), stage IV (vitellruptive).
